La Dolce Vita means ‚ÄúLive the Sweet Life‚Äù. Italy is about happiness, pleasure and enjoying the finer things in life. If you see around you in Italy, you will realize that there‚Äôs no rush: people are doing things they enjoy and are not running to get a life. They are savouring the life they have.
When you meet someone in Italy, they don‚Äôt ask ‚ÄúWhat do you do for a living‚Äù. Instead, they ask ‚ÄúWhat do you do for living‚Äù. Notice the subtle difference.
‚ÄúWhat do you do for a living‚Äù means what you do to earn a living. ‚ÄúWhat do you do for living‚Äù means what you do for living your life. For living a sweet life. For living La Dolce Vita!
I visited Italy in September (2024) and while I created a somewhat rushed itinerary, I enjoyed every moment of it. In the following sections, I will walk you through those 5 days in which I covered 5 of the best Italian cities (okay 4, Vatican City is a separate country I get it).
Recommendations
If you need to travel much from one city to the other, in order for you to minimise carrying luggage and frequent check-in and check-out, it is recommended that you stay at one place and do day trips from there. In our case, we had 2 such base camps: Rome and Florence and from these 2 cities, we did Naples, Capri, Vatican, and Venice. In such a case it is further recommended that your hotel/Airbnb is near the train station (Roma Termini in our case) so that you can reach there by walking every morning. If this is not possible, atleast ensure that your stay is near a tram station through which you can then reach the train station easily. Typically, what I‚Äôve noticed is that European cities have train stations near the city centre, making it easy for tourists to travel and watch the main attractions. Alright, now onto the trip.
Rome immigration took time, but as soon as we stepped out of the airport, we realized that this trip cannot go wrong. Any trip that includes Italy is a good trip. When you move towards the center of the city, you realise that that‚Äôs where the history is. The real Rome is the ancient monuments, like the Colosseum. I wanted to try the top restaurants so I had already booked a few places for the next few days‚Äô lunches. Right after checking into an Airbnb, we headed to Naumachia near the Colosseum. Everything: Bruschetta, Pizza and Pasta were superb.
We then did a long guided tour of Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. If you‚Äôre into history, this is for you. The Colosseum, needless to say is magnificent and is bound to take your breath away.
While on the way back from Collosseum, we chanced upon a lovely street (which we later realised was one of the best streets for shopping in Rome), Via Cavour. It was on this street that I tasted real gelato for the first time.
Make sure you take stuff home from a nearby Carrefour store for the dinner!
Vatican is one of the most well-kept countries/cities in the world. It has beautiful gardens, fountains and buildings.
Ensure that you don‚Äôt exit the Vatican gates before visiting the St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica. It is extremely beautiful from the outside and even more from the inside.
While exiting the Vatican City, don‚Äôt forget to admire these famous stairs!
Coming back from the Vatican City to the City Center/Train Station is probably the best route. Although it is about 5‚Äì6 kms long, it includes the Trevi Fountain, the Pantheon, Spanish Steps, famous Piazzas (public squares) and some of the best coffee and pizza places in Rome.
I used this map for getting back from Vatican on foot: https://maps.app.goo.gl/NyfvV6j8L7kXuj5H6?g_st=ic
IMO, you do not need a guided tour for Trevi, Spanish Steps and Pantheon.
Don‚Äôt forget to keep a coin for tossing it in the Trevi fountain!
On the way back, we found a way to perhaps the best cafe in Rome: Trecaffe! Obviously, I had done a lot of research beforehand for us to ‚Äúfind our way‚Äù to this place.
At the risk of repeating myself, as much as possible, you must travel on foot in Rome. You will find a lot of good stuff to admire on the way. For example:
We took a train from Rome to Naples and then a (rough, bumpy) ferry to Capri. This was without doubt (and after some heated debate with my sister) the best place we visited across Switzerland and Italy. An island cannot get better than this ‚Äî I got to know what ‚Äòliving the Capri dream‚Äô truly meant.
With low rocky hills in the backdrop, a rich market crowded by tourists from USA and a ton of beautiful boats to add a touch of affluence, the view was too complex to be imagined. It was enchanting to say the least. There was too much going on in one picture.
The best part of the one-day outing was the Ferry ‚Äî which takes you around the island and you see the iconic Faraglioni. Stella, di Mezzo and di Fuori: Capri‚Äôs legendary trio of sea giants. These are three towering rock formations which jut out from the Mediterranean just off the island‚Äôs coast.
Then I absolutely HAD to do the Capri chairlift: a short 20 min journey that offers breathtaking views of the island and the sea.
Capri was a tour but full of colours and sea. Some images cannot be captured on camera ‚Äî no video can do justice to such places, they have to be experienced. Unless all 5 senses are used, you won‚Äôt get to really experience a place like Capri.
We didn‚Äôt spend a lot of time in Naples but it seemed to be another interesting city to explore. This is the birthplace of pizza and we would have loved to have one here if we would have had more time. (Part of the reason why we didn‚Äôt have enough time was we were finding cake for my sister as it was her birthday)
We shifted base from Rome to Florence on Day 3 and immediately post checking in, set out for the Duomo. We managed to reach there, but only after stopping at a hundred fashion shops.
From wallets to handbags, flee markets to Zaras and superb flatbread sandwiches to the best gelato, Florence has it all. It is worthy of being called the fashion capital (although Milan is the real OG).
The Duomo turned out to be a stunning sight. Its magnificence can be seen in the image below.
Florence is famous for its leather and flee markets are unsurprisingly packed.
The other thing (probably the most important one too) Florence is famous for is the gelato. As a matter of fact, it is the origin of gelato. I did my own research before I came here and here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve gathered. Thank me later.
These are the top 3 gelato shops in Florence. But, I‚Äôve not tried any of them as I was more fascinated by the crowd at a store of a native Italian chocolate brand: Venchi.
The gelato was the most scrumptious frozen dessert I‚Äôd eaten yet and fine enough to bring me back to Florence some day. Highest quality stuff for sure.
Zara, Sephora and Ferragamo stores were of the size of shopping malls, complete with cafes, lounge areas and rooftop bars.
Overall, Florence had a unique vibe, with fashion and food being highest priorities of people. Here is my attempt to capture the vibe in a video.
There‚Äôs a world famous sandwich shop in Florence: All‚Äô Antico Vinaio. While I would recommend everyone to try, I‚Äôve had better ones for sure. Rather, let‚Äôs just say it is a different kind of sandwich: one that is not very soft and has some crunch in it.
Imagine a city that is comprised of 120 islands connected by 438 bridges. A city void of roads but full of canals and boats. A city home to some of the finest shops, restaurants and architecture. Venice is that city, except it is also a culture hub and has a rich history. When I reached Venezia Santa Lucia, we just saw a huge canal and big buildings but the real charm of Venice was its streets.
Every alley is a postcard in Venice.
The streets were full of charming shops: the top brands in the world, Venetian glass (Murano/Burano glass), and local leather stuff. Then there were some extremely picturesque shops like these.
The alleys, shops and canals of Venice really took our breath away. The Gondola ride, though short, was pretty good and gave us the truest flavour of Venice.
If you have a few (thousand) Euros and have a tendency to shop, Venice is the place to be. The stores here are alluring and would not disappoint!
Proper planning of your trip is icing on the cake as it ensures that you make the most out of the limited time you have. For my trip, I had planned to the extent that I had booked lunch at some great restaurants as well. This minimized surprises and maximized the time spent on sight seeing.
Any trip that includes Italy is a good trip. It really is a land where appreciation is deeply ingrained in the culture. You learn to appreciate the finer things in life and in turn live a happier one!
The Creator made Italy from designs by Michelangelo. ‚Äî Mark Twain
I hope this gave you an idea of Italy from a tourist‚Äôs lens and will help you plan your own trip. If you enjoyed reading this, you would like the documentation of my experience in Switzerland as well:
medium.com
If you have any questions or simply want to chat about Switzerland/Italy, please reach out to me at ashwingoyal154@gmail.com or at https://www.linkedin.com/in/ashwin-goyal1/.
Until next time.

Title: Why Is Italy the Worst Country I‚Äôve Ever Visited?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
3
Listen
Share
We‚Äôve all seen the recent trend of tourists being splashed by water in Barcelona, protests going on worldwide to stop tourism. In this blog, I‚Äôm going to share my own personal experience in the locations I‚Äôve visited. I‚Äôm not saying it‚Äôs like this in all of Italy. I will only share what happened to me, in which location, and why I won‚Äôt ever visit again. The mission by the locals was accomplished.
After traveling for 6 months, I regretfully have to say that Italy was the worst country I have ever visited. Again, this is my personal experience. If someone went to the worst part of Slovakia and said Slovakia is the worst country ever, I‚Äôd be offended as well because that‚Äôs not fair. But if they said they visited specific parts of Slovakia and had a bad experience, I‚Äôd have to accept it because that‚Äôs a fact. So please do the same with my experience.
What pisses me off the most is that Italy is probably the most Instagrammed country in the world, with better PR than Goebbels had for his propaganda. If you don‚Äôt get this reference, please Google who Goebbels was and what he did, as it‚Äôs important.
All I see on Instagram when I search for Italy are beautiful beaches, delicious-looking food, and sunny weather. That‚Äôs all true, but you never see the other side of anything. It‚Äôs one of those ‚Äútoo good to be true‚Äù scenarios.
To give you more context, I visited Rome, Calabria, Puglia, and Sardinia. What they all had in common, apart from Puglia, was that everyone tried to rip me off one way or another ‚Äî looking for opportunities to charge me more or not give me any sort of refund despite being in the right.
I‚Äôve blogged about my 45-day stay in Calabria before. You can read those blogs, as I won‚Äôt go into detail here. To summarize, I was just a walking wallet for the locals, who were quite rude to the point where I almost didn‚Äôt want to leave my apartment anymore. Not to mention, I was sexually assaulted in broad daylight. But the nature was beautiful, aside from all the rubbish everywhere.
Anyway, let me tell you about my family vacation in Sardinia. We booked an entire apartment for us and three small kids. The owner was a Czech couple who seemed very nice. They had a Facebook group renting out the place to other Czechoslovaks to make some money. The reviews were amazing, they sent pictures, a detailed PDF on where to eat, how to get to different beaches, and so on. The pictures were, of course, amazing. We booked it, and they also recommended a good, well-reviewed car rental service at a reasonable price.
Everything seemed‚Ä¶ too good to be true. We landed, and the car rental guy was supposed to wait for us in front of the building. We messaged him, and he replied that he‚Äôd be there in a few minutes. After 10 minutes, he messaged saying there was traffic and he‚Äôd arrive in an hour. After staying there, I can say that in Sardinia, in October, there‚Äôs no such thing as traffic. So that was the first lie.
In 35 minutes, he messaged that he needed to wash the car because it was dirty, so he‚Äôd be there in 20 minutes. Just pure nonsense. Anyway, he arrived in an hour, apologized for being late, and told us the car was clean and he wanted it clean when we returned it. He showed us the contract, which took around 15 minutes.
We got in and were leaving the airport. We told him we had 10 minutes free, so we needed to pay when we left. He argued that we only stayed for 5 minutes, so there was no problem. We said there was no way we had only stayed for 5 minutes. By that point, it had been at least 15 minutes. He came with us to the gate and at least paid the fee to let us out. We stopped at the closest shop before driving an hour to our apartment. The car constantly displayed a red alert. We called him, and he told us we were going too slow. Have you ever heard of a car alert that triggers when you‚Äôre driving within the city‚Äôs speed limit because you‚Äôre not going fast enough? Okay.
We got back from the shop, opened the rear door, and the weather strip fell off. It took us 5 minutes to get it back and close the door properly. After that, we decided not to open that door again. We safely arrived at our apartment, thank God.
The apartment was, of course, much smaller than in the pictures, which were taken at angles to make things look bigger. It was clean, apart from the floor, which gave us black socks in 5 minutes. There was supposed to be a couch that converted into a bed. It didn‚Äôt ‚Äî it was just a couch. The mosquito nets were half-broken, so we couldn‚Äôt leave the windows open at night unless we wanted to be bitten. No air conditioning either.
The balcony had a great view, but the pictures didn‚Äôt show the fence, which blocked off the garden. We thought the kids could run around in the area, but the fence was too close for that to be possible. The balcony had no roof, so privacy was minimal, and we found grape leftovers on the balcony. As we later found out, our neighbors were throwing organic waste into the garden, supposedly to feed the turtles. My question is, why throw it onto your neighbor‚Äôs balcony? After seeing a huge rat running across our balcony, we really didn‚Äôt understand this habit at all. Our neighbor finished a watermelon and threw it into our garden, right in front of us, as if flipping us off.
Our upstairs neighbor was a crazy German woman who shouted at someone every evening, scaring the kids. The neighbors who threw the watermelon were smoking weed regularly. This was supposed to be a very kid-friendly place, as the Czech owners had told us. Right‚Ä¶
The balcony didn‚Äôt close properly, so we froze during windy nights, and mosquitoes got in easily. One day, it rained heavily, and with no roof on the balcony and no drainage system, our apartment got slightly flooded. We messaged the owners, who replied after 4 days, saying it was strange because it ‚Äúnever really rains in Sardinia.‚Äù A total lie, but okay. No apology or anything.
We also found a huge bug after lifting the couch cushions. That was truly disgusting. We were really worried about bugs and the kids. This place was a nightmare. You might think, ‚ÄúOh, that was just false advertising from the Czech owners. So why are you mad at Italy?‚Äù
From the second day, every time we got into the car, we smelled fuel. We realized the day before, the car had been sprayed with some sort of perfume, now we knew why ‚Äî to cover the fuel smell. After two days of driving, the kids started getting headaches and feeling sick, so we contacted the rental company. We then noticed a puddle under the car. The rental company came within 2 hours to give us a new, better car. Honestly, this was incredible service, or maybe they were genuinely scared something would happen to us and the three small kids.
We got a car that was totally an upgrade. We were impressed and happy with the company. We even forgave the guy for being an hour late on day one. That evening, we drove 2.5 km to get ice cream and back, planning a trip for the next day. The next morning, we started the car, and a notification appeared saying we had a flat tire. We checked, and sure enough, there was a nail in it. So, the question was: did the company hand it to us that way? Or were we just that unlucky in 5 km? Or, as we‚Äôd heard, was it locals slashing tourists‚Äô tires, which is apparently common in Sardinia? The car had a sticker showing it was a rental, so everyone knew we were tourists.
We went to the beach to calm down. The beaches were nice, and the sea was clean, apart from glass everywhere. Again, not very child-friendly. The rental guy gave us a number for assistance, but we said we‚Äôd try to put the spare tire on and drive to a mechanic to avoid higher cost. He said the car did not had a spare tire. It did.
We found the spare tire but it was half-deflated, and the screws were too tight to loosen. Even my big and strong brother-in-law couldn‚Äôt budge them.
We contacted the rental guy, and he said, ‚ÄúCall assistance, but you‚Äôll have to pay for it.‚Äù To be fair, yes, it was our problem, as we couldn‚Äôt prove the nail had been there or that a local had done it on purpose. Facts. We called the assistance number, but it didn‚Äôt exist. We checked the insurance papers in the car ‚Äî it was the same number, still didn‚Äôt exist. The guy gave us another number, but it was all in Italian. We waited for an English option, but after 3 minutes, the automation started repeating in Italian. We told the guy there was no English option, and he insisted there was.
We tried again, and after 3 minutes, we got connected. I asked to speak to someone in English. The operator said, ‚ÄúOne moment.‚Äù After 9 minutes on hold, the call dropped. The guy told us to call a mechanic instead, and while he was helping, if he‚Äôd just called the assistance line himself, it would have been sorted in 5 minutes. Instead, he kept messaging us instructions for half a day. This was getting ridiculous. We kindly asked if he could make the call, and he replied,
‚ÄúIs it a problem for you to make that call? I don‚Äôt understand.‚Äù
He finally called a mechanic, and of course, it was all sorted super fast. The mechanic didn‚Äôt speak a single word of English, by the way.
We got the nail out, and it was strange-looking, sharpened like a razor. This wasn‚Äôt a normal nail; it was a setup. And guess what? At another beach, we saw a couple changing their tire in the parking lot. How interesting‚Ä¶
The local shops were more expensive than the poshest shops in London. We went to one restaurant, but otherwise, we cooked, despite the apartment not having an oven or microwave. You could say tourists drive up prices for locals, but if that‚Äôs true, it‚Äôs greed. So whose fault is that? Also, I‚Äôve never seen supermarkets where two fruits or veggies are wrapped in plastic. We bought some fruit and veggies and generated more plastic waste than we would for a huge shop back home. Where‚Äôs the EU now? Why do small countries have to stick to the rules, but big countries can do what they want? We went to another big supermarket ‚Äî same story.
Putting a nail in the tire of a car that clearly carries kids because it has 7 seats is disgusting. Of course, I don‚Äôt have proof‚Ä¶
We were quite happy to leave, in the end. We returned the car to the rental guy. Our flight was at 8 AM, so we needed him at the airport at 6:30 AM. There was a 30-euro fee for returns before 8 AM. Fair enough. But when we messaged him, he replied, ‚Äú7:15 is better.‚Äù Excuse me? I‚Äôm paying you 30 euros to get your lazy ass up 45 minutes earlier, and you say 7:15 is better? What is wrong with these people?
Anyway, he agreed to 6:30 in the end and was actually there, thank God. We returned the car completely clean, and he said it wasn‚Äôt clean. Okay. Then he said fixing the tire was 250 euros because they had to tow the car to the tire shop (fair enough), but only because the spare tire was half empty (which was his fault). Daylight robbery, in my book.
He gave us a car with constant alerts, a broken door, and leaking fuel. He almost killed us and three kids. And because the spare was half-empty, he had to tow the car, which cost 250 euros. I even started thinking he put the nail in the tire himself to get that money.
My conclusion: Please travel within your own country. Forget visiting other countries. Traveling is good and important, so get your experiences, but then spend your time inside your own country. People will appreciate it, the economy will appreciate it, and you‚Äôll actually have a nice time! That‚Äôs what I‚Äôm going to do from now on ;)
Get more updates and stories from me on my Insta and TikTok. You can find some on my YT channel as well.

I was so lucky to be able travel to Italy for my honeymoon over the Christmas holiday back in 2023. It was truly one of the great experiences of my life and I will cherish those memories for as long as I have access to them.
I grew up in an area that was heavily influenced by Italian-American culture and have Italian roots through my father‚Äôs family. We‚Äôve all wanted to go back and reconnect with the heritage. I was not able to back to the ancient roots that my family can trace into southern Italy and Sicily, but getting to see some of the countries‚Äô most famous cities first is the way to go fro me.
We whirled our way through Rome, Florence, and Venice, with some other stops along the way as well. I‚Äôm not a travel expert by any means, but I have some tips that I think would be helpful to any first time travelers to Italy.
I am eagerly awaiting the day I feel confident enough to tackle Italy without a translator. Until then though, I‚Äôm very happy to travel with a group. The Disney crew we toured with was relaxed, very family centric, and we had two incredible guides.
While our guides took care of translating and guiding my wife and I got to just enjoy the incredible‚Ä¶

Italy, the land of pasta, pizza, and picturesque landscapes, beckons travelers from all corners of the globe. My recent journey to this enchanting country left an indelible mark on my heart, mind, and taste buds. As I reminisce about my Italian adventure, I invite you to join me on a virtual tour through the cobblestone streets, ancient ruins, and vibrant culture that define this remarkable destination.
From the moment I set foot in Italy, I was captivated by its timeless treasures. The majestic Colosseum in Rome stood as a testament to the grandeur of the Roman Empire, while the iconic Leaning Tower of Pisa in Tuscany invoked a sense of wonder and awe. Each corner I turned revealed a new marvel, from the art-filled halls of the Vatican Museums to the romantic canals of Venice.
No trip to Italy would be complete without savoring its delectable cuisine. I delighted in mouthwatering pizzas topped with fresh mozzarella and basil, indulged in creamy gelato on sweltering afternoons, and savored the robust flavors of homemade pasta dishes. Every meal was a culinary masterpiece, a symphony of flavors that celebrated the country‚Äôs rich gastronomic heritage.
Beyond its architectural wonders and culinary delights, Italy boasts a cultural richness that is simply unparalleled. I found myself immersed in the passionate rhythms of Italian opera, enchanted by the graceful movements of traditional folk dances, and inspired by the timeless works of Renaissance artists. Whether wandering through bustling marketplaces or strolling along tranquil vineyards, I felt a profound connection to Italy‚Äôs storied past and vibrant present.
As I reflect on my unforgettable journey through Italy, I encourage you to embark on your own adventure and discover the magic of this extraordinary country. Whether you‚Äôre drawn to the ancient ruins of Rome, the rolling hills of Tuscany, or the sun-drenched shores of the Amalfi Coast, Italy offers something for every traveler.
To help you plan your Italian getaway, I invite you to explore my affiliate link, where you can find exclusive deals on flights, accommodations, and guided tours. By booking through my link, you‚Äôll not only gain access to special discounts and promotions but also support my continued exploration of the world‚Äôs most captivating destinations.
Italy is more than just a destination; it‚Äôs a journey of sights, sounds, and soul-stirring experiences. From the majestic ruins of ancient Rome to the sun-kissed shores of the Mediterranean, this remarkable country invites travelers to explore its timeless treasures and vibrant culture. As you embark on your own Italian adventure, may you be inspired by the beauty, history, and passion that define this enchanting land. Buon viaggio! (Safe travels!)

Title: Italy: Where everything tastes great and nothing ever goes wrong.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The world is a peculiar place. Two million young Italians have left their homeland since 2008, some of them moving to Birmingham. But why? If my armchair experience is anything to go by, they can‚Äôt be bored of the food, music, drinks, books or films ‚Äî and I‚Äôd be surprised if they were trying to escape the weather. And yet wherever you go in the world you meet Italians looking for a better life! This is a particularly personal conundrum as my great, great, great, great grandad left Swiss-Italy (Switally‚Ñ¢) to move to the UK and so in a way I am too part of the great exodus‚Ä¶
In addition to joy, the Italians even get some of the world‚Äôs best history, a mindboggling array of dates and facts‚Ä¶ Their empires include the Roman, the Etruscan, the Catholic, the Venetian and Genoese. They even collapse with style, breaking up into 100s of microstates until‚Ä¶ in 1861 the House of Savoy (famous for its cabbages and truffles) brought most of the present states together and then almost immediately went back to Empire building ‚Äî taking bits of Libya, Eritrea, and Somalia and even Austria into the fold. World War I saw Trento and Trieste included, before Mussolini and his dancing fascists took power and were unceremoniously destroyed. Since 1946 its been a democratic republic‚Ä¶ and that is where this week‚Äôs book begins, or at least where the first of them begins as I read Elena Ferrante‚Äôs Neopolitan quartet ‚Äî four books charting a strong female friendship from the birth of Italian democracy to pretty much the present day. If you haven‚Äôt yet read them you probably should, they are beach books with feeling, intelligence, history and anger. They cover politics, sexuality, the complexities of friendship, and the many frustrating flaws of men. Whilst I must admit that by the final book, I had lost love for any of the characters and felt it had all become a bit formulaic I‚Äôd none-the-less call the books a publishing triumph‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶but still not as good as the Italian film le quatro volte. Though not a word is spoken, I was rapt from beginning to end. It stars goats, charcoal and a particularly impressive dog, and if that is not enough to whet your appetite, it tackles the concept of reincarnation with perfection. It was one and a half hours of my life so well spent that I‚Äôll never be the same again. I think it is true to say it was the best film I have ever watched. Michelangelo Frammartino is a genius and I can‚Äôt wait to watch more‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶ and I can‚Äôt wait to listen to more Italian music, beautiful relaxing Italian music‚Ä¶ I only just touched the sides of what is available, not even daring to start listening to opera or rap but none-the-less I have a 62 song 3.5 hour playlist that I put on whenever I need to relax or take myself away from the day to day. And yes it does include Prisencolinensinainciusol‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶And Ennio Morricone, the soundtrack artist that I listened to whilst attempting to not get hate mail by veganising Sicilian chicken spaghetti. I chose this dish out of the millions of possible Italian regional treats as I had bought my first ever bottle of Frappato, a delicious, light, fruity Sicilian red. We had a wonderful evening but obviously I was unable to create a dish as perfect as when we went out and had actual Italians cook for us‚Ä¶ we ate gnocchi, pizza and ravioli, veganised with care and matched with harmonising wines, but nothing prepared us for our final Italian meal‚Ä¶ made by one of the Italians who have left the hell that is Italy to come to #BeautifulBirmingham ‚Äî Pavarotti‚Äôs private chef! Though vegan options were lacking, there were great veggie specials on ‚Äî I remember potato on pizza and lemon on the pasta, I remember a starter of baked bread topped with buffalo mozzarella. I remember wine, and laughter and joy. But I cannot remember the name of a single thing‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶you see it turns out that Italy doesn‚Äôt just do incredible savoury food, music, literature, films and wine‚Ä¶ it also excels at gelato, tiramisu, coffee and after dinner drinks‚Ä¶ These last few weeks have been full of Sambuca, Strega, Montenegro, Amaro and more. Each restaurant seemed to have its own, and it would, of course, have been rude not to try them‚Ä¶
And so I have come to my word count, having not even found time to espouse about the joy of reading Italian poetry and trying to get my head around the difference between the regions. But I must stop, thank Italy and the Italians for their travelling ways and for sharing their bounteous culture with us all, everywhere, all the time. And now I head to Jamaica!
--

‚ÄúTwo weeks in just Italy?‚Äù
That was the reaction from a few friends when I told them our plan. The usual Europe itinerary? Hit a few iconic cities, snap some Insta-worthy shots, and bounce to the next country. But I wanted more - more connection, more moments, more‚Ä¶ Italy.
I wanted to slow down. Sip cappuccino (though I‚Äôm an occasional coffee person), not just chug it between landmarks. Watch sunsets in sleepy hill towns. Wander into unexpected alleys and let the day unfold.
And now, as I write this mid-journey, I already know this isn‚Äôt a one-time trip. This is the beginning of a long-term love story. There‚Äôs just so much here - culture, food, landscapes, art, people - that it‚Äôs impossible to do it justice in one go.
Next time? I‚Äôm heading to the Dolomites, Sardinia, Puglia, Sicily, Cinque Terre‚Ä¶ and definitely carving out more time for Lake Como. But this first trip? It gave us the perfect taste of la dolce vita. A beautifully paced, soul-stirring two weeks through:
This trip had it all - breath-taking views, slow mornings, and ridiculously good food, üçùüç∑and so many memorable moments. Every place felt like a living postcard - only better in person. From cappuccino-fuelled mornings ‚òï to sunset wine among the vineyards üçá, Italy gave us everything: art, romance, flavour, and those unforgettable, effortless chill vibes.
And if you‚Äôre wondering whether two weeks is enough?
It isn‚Äôt.But it‚Äôs a damn good start. üáÆüáπ‚ú®
Italy is a year-round destination, but when you go makes all the difference in the vibe you‚Äôll experience.
Verdict?If you‚Äôre after that perfect balance of good weather and fewer crowds, go for the shoulder season - especially October. üç∑

A Vaporetto day pass (‚Ç¨25) provides unlimited rides and is a cost-effective way to explore.
Picked up our car rental and drove through the Tuscan countryside, its rolling hills, cypress trees, and vineyards painting a picturesque landscape.

Title: ITALY: WHY WE LOVE YOU
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When I think about Italy, I think about a place I never ever want to leave. It reminds me of places in Disney I dreamed of as a young girl, hoping my dashing prince in a dazzling amour would steal me away to, and we would ride into beautiful lands, under the soothing breeze in the evening sun. I asked a friend how he would describe how Italy makes him feel, and he said ‚ÄúRomance. A date night in Venice driving an expensive car wearing a white shirt and having on good perfume and her wearing a sundress and red lipstick‚Äù.
We all have our various descriptions of how Italy makes us feel. One thing we would all agree on is that Italy is a place where our dreams come alive!
When I think of Italy I think of peace, beauty, and history. It‚Äôs not just a country, it‚Äôs an experience, a lifestyle, it‚Äôs an unending sweet memory for everyone who gets a taste of ‚Äúla dolce vita‚Äù.
REASONS WHY ITALY HAS OUR HEARTS
La Dolce Vita
This translates to English ‚ÄúThe sweet life‚Äù. This embodies a lifestyle that is the core of Italy‚Äôs identity. It‚Äôs more than just a saying, it‚Äôs a philosophy, an attitude, and an outlook on life that makes even the mundane aspects of life fulfilling. It is a lifestyle that enjoys the sweetness of life, its pleasures, slow leisures, relaxations, and the finest things it offers. After the popular film of the 1960s la Dolce Vita by the outstanding director Federico Fellini, this phrase became a popular phrase attached to the country. In its broadest sense, ‚Äúla dolce vita‚Äù is about savoring life‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääenjoying good food, company, and the beauty of the world around us. It‚Äôs about finding joy in the small, everyday moments, whether it‚Äôs a leisurely meal with friends, a walk through a sunlit city street, or enjoying a glass of wine at sunset. The phrase encapsulates a spirit of hedonism, but it‚Äôs not necessarily about excess; rather, it‚Äôs about balance‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätaking the time to appreciate life‚Äôs sensory pleasures. The ease of this lifestyle is why every single person desires to attach themselves to the luxury of this idea.
Art
Italy is considered one of the birthplaces of western art, giving expression to one of the most celebrated artists in human history, the most fascinating architectural wonders throughout the world hailing from its origin. From the ruins of ancient Rome to the modern art galleries of Milan, Italy‚Äôs rich artistic heritage, its art continues to evolve, influencing and shaping global art for centuries. Cities like Florence, Venice, and Rome became the cultural epicenters of Europe, drawing innumerable people to the awe of its rich beauty. So many people come to Italy and all they can take away from these cities is the depth of thoughtfulness, talent, creativity, and genius that produces such great art. Artists like Leonardo da Vinci with Monalisa, and Michelangelo Buonarroti, known for his sculpture David and his work on the Sistine Chapel ceiling, which remains one of the most revered artistic achievements in history. From the roadside views to the elaborate museum, Italy is the home of art. We will forever love it!
Food
If there‚Äôs anything Italy is associated with it‚Äôs the many delicacies it offers. It is a country where cuisine is not merely about nutritional sustenance but a reflection of the country‚Äôs history, culture, and regional diversity. Italian food is celebrated globally for its simplicity, flavor, and use of high-quality, fresh ingredients. Food in Italy is more than a meal; it‚Äôs an integral part of the Italian way of life, a social experience, and a manifestation of family, tradition, and place. From the rich pasta dishes of the south to the taste-fulfilling risottos of the north, and creamy pizza from Naples, you‚Äôll find rich, hearty dishes like lasagna, tortellini, and bolognese sauce a delight. From Rome to southern Italy, to Milan and all its beautiful cities, each of them comes with its specialties, curated with expertise and care. Food in Italy is an expression of love, pride, and tradition. Italian families often pass down recipes from generation to generation, and meals are a time for bringing people together. Whether in a bustling trattoria, a family kitchen, or a high-end restaurant, food is central to Italian life, fostering community and connection. Many Italian celebrations‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsuch as Christmas, Easter, and regional festivals‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääare marked by elaborate feasts that showcase the country‚Äôs diverse culinary heritage. This is why we love Italy
Natural and Man-made Awes
Italy isn‚Äôt just known for its art, food, and lifestyle, it‚Äôs blessed with the most gorgeous nature, with stunning landscapes the snow-capped peaks of the Alps in the north to the golden beaches of the Mediterranean coast, and the historic architecture that graces its cities and towns, Italy‚Äôs natural beauty and man-made structures continue to top the world‚Äôs most popular tourist attractions. Italy‚Äôs varied topography is dominated by mountain ranges, with some of the most dramatic peaks in Europe. These mountains offer breathtaking views and a wide range of outdoor activities, like skiing, hiking, and mountaineering.Italy‚Äôs coastline stretches for more than 7,000 kilometers, offering some of the most beautiful beaches in Europe.
The glistening shores of the Amalfi Coast and the pristine sands of Sardinia are its main locations. The country‚Äôs beaches cater to every taste‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhether you‚Äôre seeking luxury resorts, charming coastal villages, or quiet, hidden coves.
Last but not least, the Italian architecture is renowned for its rich history, artistic expression, and innovative design, influencing architectural styles around the world for centuries. From ancient Roman engineering feats to modern design movements, Italy has been a cradle for groundbreaking ideas in architecture. The foundation of Italian architecture can be traced to ancient Rome, where monumental structures like the Colosseum, Pantheon, and Roman Forum showcased the mastery of arches, vaults, and concrete construction. Romans perfected the use of concrete, allowing them to build large-scale structures with unprecedented durability and grandeur. We know so well that Italy‚Äôs beauty will continue to transcend time and generations just as it always has.
Love & Romance
Italy is often synonymous with love and romance, a country where passion is its culture and history. With romantic cities to its art, literature, and food, Italy has long been a symbol of romance, drawing couples from around the world to experience the magic of its cities and countryside. Many of Italy‚Äôs cities have a natural allure for lovers. Venice, with its winding canals and romantic gondola rides, is perhaps the most famous destination for romance. The city‚Äôs dreamy atmosphere, with its ancient palaces, narrow alleys, and bridges like the Rialto and the Bridge of Sighs, evokes a sense of timeless love. The Gondola ride along the canals remains one of the most iconic romantic experiences.
The floating city Florence, birthplace of the Renaissance, is another city that captured the hearts of lovers. Its art, architecture, and breathtaking views like Piazzale Michelangelo or the top of the Duomo are perfect settings for romance. Florence also hosts the Vasari Corridor, a hidden passage that once connected the offices of the ruling Medici family with their private palace, offering an air of mystery and history for lovers to explore. With movies, music, and tales that show us Italy‚Äôs beautiful love and romance in our everyday world, like my friend when saying he thinks of Italy, he thinks Romance, it‚Äôs the same for millions around the globe, It‚Äôs a universal feeling.
Culture
Italian culture is one of the richest, most diverse, and influential in the world. Its long history, shaped by ancient civilizations, the Roman Empire, the Renaissance, and centuries of regional traditions, has given Italy a unique cultural identity that continues to resonate globally. Italian culture blends art, music, cuisine, fashion, architecture, and family life into a living celebration of beauty, passion, and creativity. Italy is renowned as the origin of some of the world‚Äôs most important art movements, including the Renaissance, which emerged in the 14th century and reached its peak in the 16th century. The works of artists such as Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael, and Titian still stand as monumental achievements in the history of Western art. Italy is home to countless masterpieces housed in museums, churches, and palaces. With its people who are warm and receptive to strangers on travel explores, to the rich language, and festivals of its several descents, Italy‚Äôs depth and cultural diversity cannot be ignored.
There are so many reasons to love Italy and these are a few. When we think about Italy our hearts burst with excitement and longing for the experiences it gives us! Italy is such a great country and its greatness is still waiting to be discovered!
What are your favorite things about it?
--
--

Title: Italy ‚Äî Sceneries
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Italy is not just a destination ‚Äî it‚Äôs a journey through centuries of art, passion, and flavor, where every corner tells a story and every meal is a celebration.
I have been in Germany for almost a year as a medical Ph.D. student. This is the first time for me to travel in Europe except for Germany and to my pleasure, Italy is the first country I visit here. So it‚Äôs a good time to tell you about my recent life here.
Our routines are as follows:
City ‚Ññ1: Milan
City ‚Ññ2: Venice
City ‚Ññ3: Florence
City ‚Ññ4: Pisa
City ‚Ññ5: Rome
Place ‚Ññ6: Vantican
Milan Catheral (Duomo di Milano)
I stood in front of the Milan Cathedral, completely captivated ‚Äî its delicate spires stretched into the sky like frozen music, and as I wandered through its vast, echoing interior, I could almost feel the weight of history in every carved stone and shaft of light. And its rooftop offers panoramic views of Milan and the Alps on clear days.
Unfortunately, we didn‚Äôt have an opportunity to reach the roof of it but we reserved St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica roof ticket which we look more forward to it.
Milan Central Station (Stazione Centrale)
Walking into Milan Central Station felt like stepping into a grand palace disguised as a train hub ‚Äî its towering arches, ornate stonework, and sheer scale make it one of the most majestic railway stations I‚Äôve ever seen, blending Fascist-era power with Art Deco elegance.
City ‚Ññ2: Venice
We only spent half a day in Milan and then took the fast train from Milan to Venice. You can see a lot of luxury shops there, but we are not rich enough, so why not leave earlier, right?
Right outside the train station, Ponte degli Scalzi was my first real step into Venice ‚Äî it gave me that instant ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really here‚Äù moment, with boats gliding under its stone arch and the Grand Canal unfolding before me.
Barefoot bridge(Ponte degli scalzi)
Rialto bridge
The Rialto Bridge is pure drama ‚Äî crowded, grand, and full of life. Standing at its peak, I watched gondolas, vaporettos, and reflections dance along the Grand Canal, Venice‚Äôs main artery pulsing with history.
St. Mark‚Äôs Square
St. Mark‚Äôs Square felt like the heart of an empire ‚Äî wide, majestic, and echoing with footsteps and pigeons. Surrounded by grand architecture, I stood in awe beneath the domes of the Basilica and the watchful eye of the Campanile.
Ponte dell‚Äô accademia (academy bridge)
Ponte dell‚ÄôAccademia gave me my favorite panoramic view of the Grand Canal. The soft curve of the water, historic facades, and distant dome of Santa Maria della Salute ‚Äî it all looked like a living painting.
Murano island (without picture)
In Murano, the furnaces burn hot and the glass glows. The island buzzes with centuries-old craft, and watching the artisans shape molten glass felt like peeking into a world of tradition and skill. I find it a bit crowded and boring.
Burano
Burano stole my heart. It was peaceful, almost dreamlike ‚Äî with fewer tourists, quiet alleys, and rows of cheerful, colorful houses reflected in calm canals. It felt like a hidden storybook village where time slows down.
City ‚Ññ3: Florence
Florence is a city that feels both intimate and immense ‚Äî it‚Äôs small enough to walk across, yet bursting with history at every turn. With its narrow streets, lively piazzas, and Renaissance beauty, it thrives quietly, blending daily life with timeless art. Everything is close: cathedrals, cafes, museums, and the river Arno. It‚Äôs a place where convenience meets cultural depth.
Uffizi Gallery
The Uffizi Gallery is a treasure trove of Renaissance masterpieces. Walking through its elegant corridors, I stood face to face with Botticelli‚ÄôsBirth of Venus ‚Äî graceful, ethereal, and iconic ‚Äî and just steps away,Primavera (Spring), bursting with life and symbolism. Giotto di Bondone‚Äôs Madonna Enthroned stood solemn and powerful, a bridge between medieval devotion and the early stirrings of the Renaissance. Every room held a window into centuries of beauty, belief, and brilliance.
Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo Buonarroti and Raphael Sanzio are three of the most famous and influential artists of the Italian Renaissance. They‚Äôre often considered the ultimate ‚Äútrio‚Äù of Renaissance genius.
Giotto di Bondone‚Äôs Madonna Enthroned
Spring
Botticelli‚Äôs Birth of Venus
Gentleman -Raphael
Santa maria novella square (piazza santa maria novella)
Old bridge (ponte vecchio)
Michelangelo square
Santa croce square (piazza santa croce)
Pisa
Pisa is more than just its famous leaning tower ‚Äî it‚Äôs a charming, walkable city with a laid-back vibe and deep historical roots. The heart of the city, Piazza dei Miracoli, feels almost surreal, with the Leaning Tower tilting beside the grand cathedral and baptistery, all glowing white against the green grass.
If you come here, don‚Äôt forget to take the iconic pictures with the Leaning Tower.
City ‚Ññ5: Rome
Rome (Capital) is a vast, booming city where ancient ruins and modern life collide in an exhilarating rhythm. It‚Äôs busy, loud, and alive ‚Äî cars zip past thousand-year-old monuments, and every corner holds a piece of history. At the Colosseum, I stood where gladiators once battled, imagining the roar of the crowd echoing through time. The Borghese Gallery offered a quieter side of Rome ‚Äî intimate rooms filled with masterpieces by Bernini, Caravaggio, and Canova. And at the Trevi Fountain, surrounded by crowds and coins tossed in mid-air, I joined the tradition, making a wish in front of its dramatic baroque sculptures.
Colosseum
Borghese Gallery
Trevi Fountain
Place ‚Ññ6 Vatican
Italy was breathtaking and full of unforgettable sights ‚Äî from Venice‚Äôs canals to Rome‚Äôs ancient ruins ‚Äî but there was never enough time to see it all. It was beautiful, intense, and exhausting in the best way.

Title: How Italy Ruined Me
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
After almost three years of living semi full-time in Italy, I can confidently say this place has changed us in ways we never anticipated. But to be fair, we didn‚Äôt think much about the life lessons this move would bring.
We‚Äôre adaptable people-anyone who‚Äôs lived abroad has to be-but every time we return to the U.S. or our other ‚Äúhome‚Äù in the Czech Republic, we feel a jolt of culture shock.
This place ruined the old me-the version of myself who didn‚Äôt know how to live at a slower pace or appreciate a good bottle of olive oil for under $20. Living in Italy has reshaped our habits and redefined how we experience the everyday. These things have become essential to our lives, and honestly, I don‚Äôt see us giving them up anytime soon.
Groceries are a basic need, right? You buy food, you eat. Simple. But what absolutely boggles my mind is how, in some places, this necessity is so expensive that it feels more like a luxury.
In Italy, staples like olive oil, cheese, eggs, butter, and fresh produce are not only affordable but consistently high in quality. I don‚Äôt need to hunt down an overpriced boutique grocery store (eff you, Whole Foods) just to find something decent-it‚Äôs always available, whether I‚Äôm at the discount supermarket or the farmers‚Äô market in town.
Of course, specialty items like peanut butter (because let‚Äôs face it, that‚Äôs not exactly an Italian staple) come with a higher price tag, but I‚Äôm okay with that. What I‚Äôm not okay with is paying $6 for a loaf of bread in the U.S. If you can justify that, we probably wouldn‚Äôt see eye to eye on much else, either.
This affordability doesn‚Äôt just make life easier-it frees up our budget for other things we value. In places where groceries would devour half our paycheck, living in Italy has been a much-needed breath of fresh air.
When I think about raising my four-year-old daughter here, the word safe is the first thing that comes to mind. I‚Äôd feel completely at ease sending her down the street to the local shop to buy apples and walk back home on her own. That‚Äôs the level of trust I have in our community.
It‚Äôs an old-world kind of safety, the kind that existed before everyone started worrying about every possible bad thing that could happen. Here, my daughter plays outside without constant supervision. Sometimes, she even wanders into a neighbor‚Äôs house (without me even knowing), spends time watching them cook or knit, and inevitably leaves with a sweet treat.
This kind of freedom and peace of mind is something I could never put a price on. A sense of tight-knit community is one of the most romanticized aspects of living in Italy, and for good reason-because it‚Äôs true.
We live near the cusp of what you‚Äôd call southern Italy, and let me tell you-southern Italy has its own unique rhythm. You either thrive in it, or it‚Äôll drive you crazy.
Here, rules are more like suggestions, and there‚Äôs an unspoken agreement that not everything needs to be taken too seriously. It‚Äôs not anything goes, but there‚Äôs a collective sense of, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs not sweat the small stuff.‚Äù
People splash Sambuca liqueur into their morning coffee at the bars without a second thought before heading to work, and they casually drive home from hunting trips with wild boars strapped to the hoods of their cars. It‚Äôs wild, untamed, and utterly charming-depending on how you see the world. This relaxed attitude is a stark contrast to environments where everything feels rigidly structured.
It‚Äôs an atmosphere that gives us the freedom to color outside the lines, live a little more creatively, and just breathe.
We lived in NYC before moving to Italy, so we already had a taste of what it‚Äôs like to rely on walking. But here, it‚Äôs taken to another level, mostly out of necessity and pre-modern infrastructure.
In many small towns and villages, the streets are so narrow that driving is either impractical or downright impossible. It‚Äôs just easier (and makes you look less silly) to walk.
What I love most about this is how it turns walking into an everyday habit, not just something you do for exercise or leisure. Walking more will change your life, people! Even when we‚Äôre traveling elsewhere, I‚Äôm the one constantly suggesting, ‚ÄúShould we just walk?‚Äù Italy has made walking an essential-and joyful-part of life.
We also recently spoke with an American man who spent three consecutive months in Italy and, during that time, lost 20 kg (44 lbs) just from walking more. He didn‚Äôt do any other type of exercise. Now those are numbers!
I‚Äôve always identified as a Type A personality. I‚Äôm organized, efficient, and thrive on getting things done. So, when we first moved here, Italy‚Äôs slower pace felt like a direct challenge to my way of being.
But over time, I realized it was a gift. The lack of urgency that defines life here has forced me to slow down and reevaluate what‚Äôs truly important. Reality check: most of it isn‚Äôt a life-or-death situation, no matter how much I make it out to be. Sure, I still get things done, but now I do it in a calmer, less stressful environment.
It‚Äôs a lesson I didn‚Äôt know I needed, and I‚Äôll take this slower, more intentional way of living over a high-pressure, fast-paced one any day.
If you love history, art, or anything with a story to tell, Italy is like living in a time capsule-in the best way possible. Every street, piazza, and weathered wall feels like it has a tale to share, and I can‚Äôt ever get enough of it.
Walking through ancient town centers or exploring centuries-old villas doesn‚Äôt just make me happy-it reminds me why I love being here. There‚Äôs no sterile, cookie-cutter vibe. It‚Äôs history, charm, and soul, all bundled into daily life.
There‚Äôs a depth to living here that I can‚Äôt find in places that feel like they were built last week. It‚Äôs not just about aesthetics; it‚Äôs about the soul of the place. Italy is just f*cking charming, plain and simple. Who wouldn‚Äôt want to be surrounded by that?
‚Äî
Living in Italy has certainly reshaped what we value in our daily lives, from the simplest routines to the bigger picture. It‚Äôs not just the habits we‚Äôve picked up; it‚Äôs the mindset shift that‚Äôs changed what we prioritize.
Have you ever lived somewhere that altered your perspective in ways you didn‚Äôt expect? I‚Äôd love to hear your stories.
Originally published at https://rootlessinitaly.substack.com.

Title: The Italian Escapade: Chronicling My Travels Across Italy (Part 1)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Traveling through Italy and immersing in its culture and lifestyle have always been on my bucket list. I was supposed to go in March 2020, but as fate would have it, the whole world came to a grinding halt, no thanks to Covid-19. Italy became the epicenter of the pandemic in Europe and immediately went into lockdown.
In a blink of an eye, my long-awaited trip burst into flames. I remember wallowing in self-pity, lying on my bed for days, trying to reconcile in my head just how a viral disease could bulldoze my meticulously-planned vacay. (Yes, this sounds selfish against the backdrop of millions of people getting infected and dying at an alarming rate, but hey, I can‚Äôt help how I felt!)
The silver lining was that I was able to claim my money back for the airfares, accommodations, and museum/gallery entrance tickets. All except ItaliaRail due to its no-refund policy for the e-tickets I bought.
Fast forward to May 2022. I dared to revisit my Italian trip. Determined to experience Italy to the fullest, I decided to go during the low season ‚Äî mid-December. I planned to cover 4‚Äì5 cities, so I allocated 14 days for this trip, including the 2 days spent in the skies.
Being a borderline obsessive-compulsive planner, I identified the cities, the tourist spots, and the ‚Äòoff the beaten‚Äô tracks to explore as early as May. Then, I started booking my flight tickets, accommodations, and entrance tickets for museums and churches.
I waited until November to book train tickets when I was confident enough that Italy and/or Malaysia were not going into any kind of lockdown again. This time, I held back my excitement. Well, if the trip was canceled again, I didn‚Äôt want to go through another episode of bottomless depression.
And oh, my husband was my travel companion. I toyed with the idea to go it alone but he was worried about my safety, so he came with me anyways, letting me dictate the whole travel plans. You see, our ideas of dream vacations have often collided, and this one proved to be no different, as you‚Äôll find out later in my story. As he succinctly put it, his role was my bodyguard and navigator. In retrospect, I was grateful he came along because I‚Äôm bad at reading maps and have no sense of direction.
The cities on my list:
‚úî Milan (Lombardy region)
‚úî Bologna (Emilia-Romagna region)
‚úî Cinque Terre (Liguria region)
‚úî Florence (Tuscany region)
‚úî Rome (Lazio region)
Initially, Milan wasn‚Äôt on my wishlist because it‚Äôs relatively more metropolitan than the other cities. The things that most appeal to me are historical architecture, quaint towns, rustic countryside, and coastal scenery. So, Rome, Florence (and its surrounding Tuscan towns), and Cinque Terre fit the bill.
But most airlines from Kuala Lumpur (KL) only fly to either Milan or Rome. Cinque Terre is closer to Milan. I suppose it made sense to arrive in Milan, visit the above-named cities while gradually proceeding south, and finally depart from Rome after completing the journey.
As I wasn‚Äôt keen on spending one whole day exploring Milan, I decided to book a full-day tour of Lake Como, which is a 2-hour drive away from the city center. Who knows, I might bump into George Clooney!
I was checking out other nearby cities from Milan and happened upon Bologna. I found out they have not one but two leaning towers ‚Äî Asinelli and Garisenda. Did you know that Asinelli is taller than the famous Pisa? Asinelli slants at 97.02 m; Pisa pales in comparison with 57 m! And just like that, Bologna was added to my itinerary.
I‚Äôm a firm believer in planning my trips, especially to places I‚Äôve never been before to avoid unexpected disappointment. I once heard of a friend who went to Rome and thought of just winging it. They arrived on Saturday but only decided to go to the Vatican Museums on Sunday. They were greeted by museum doors wide shut! Had they checked the opening days in advance, they could‚Äôve gone on Saturday instead and experienced the grandeur of the exhibits.
Yet, my meticulous planning can still be derailed by other external circumstances. You‚Äôll find out in subsequent entries.
As we‚Äôll be staying 2‚Äì3 days in each city and moving around by train from one city to the next, my husband said it‚Äôd be wise to use backpacks. I was apprehensive because now I had to pack fewer clothes and necessities.
As a result, I had to spend every evening washing and drying clothes. During our stay in Florence, I made my husband go to a coin-op laundry because our Airbnb accommodation has no space to hang and dry our clothes.
In hindsight, we should‚Äôve brought suitcases. The cities we went to (except for Cinque Terre) are pretty flat and walkable. In 2 of the cities, we had to walk some 30 minutes from the train station to our Airbnb, so lugging my backpack the whole way caused me back pain and made me more short-tempered with my travel companion (since it was his idea to use backpacks).
December is wintertime in Italy. So, we packed winter jackets and thermal wear. But how do I fit these bulky items into my backpack? Thank God for vacuum-sealed bags! By putting the bulkier stuff into the bags and sucking out the air inside them, I had more space in my backpack to fill other things. Apart from clothing items, we brought:
‚úî Toiletries (in small bottles)
‚úî Medicines (flu tablets, cough lozenges, painkillers)
‚úî Instant noodles, pre-cooked packed rice, and condiments (for nights when we‚Äôre too tired from all the sightseeing during the day)
As linens also take up space, I made sure all our Airbnbs provide them so we don‚Äôt have to bring our own.
The Italians are a proud nation. Although most of them can speak English, their default is their mother tongue.
Armed with this knowledge, I learned some basic Italian to get by with polite greetings and menu ordering. This proved to go a long way because most Italians I met were more appreciative and helpful if I greeted them in Italian before switching to English (usually to ask for directions).
Once I‚Äôve identified the cities, it gets easier to map out my travel plans. I had a list of must-see places in my head (e.g., the Colosseum, Pantheon, Vatican Museums, Uffizi Gallery, Michelangelo‚Äôs David). From these places, I‚Äôd expand to find nearby historical/notable spots, preferably within walking distance.
For example, in Rome, Pantheon is on my hit list, but the famous fountains (di Trevi and dei Quattro Fiumi) are also near the vicinity. So, it made sense to do it all on the same day!
Knowing which places you want to visit in advance also helps in allocating how many days you want to stay in a city so you can book accommodations and train tickets accordingly. There are many historical places, galleries, and plazas I want to see in Florence. On top of that, I want to go see the Tuscan countryside too. So, 4 days in Florence.
For museums, galleries, palaces, and churches, be sure to note down these details:
‚úî Opening hours and days
‚úî Entrance fees
‚úî Possibility for online booking (to skip long queues)
The opening hours and days will help you determine which day and time you should go to these attractions.
Also, I can‚Äôt stress enough the advantages of online booking. Most times, I had to hide the smirk on my face when walking up to a museum entrance with my online booking documents and simply sailed past the long line of people.
We arrived in Milan bright and early. Knowing that our apartment wasn‚Äôt ready yet, I had planned to go to the Milan Cathedral and Sforza Castle first. So, we took the Malpensa Express train from the airport to Milan Central station. Luggage storage facilities are available in major train stations like this one, so don‚Äôt worry about dragging your heavy bags around.
The Milan Cathedral, or Duomo di Milano in Italian is a magnificent sight to behold. It was tiring being on a long-haul flight, so we opted not to climb up to the rooftop that‚Äôs famous for its gargoyles, spires, and statues.
Pacing myself outside the cathedral and examining the Gothic architecture built from intricately-carved marble, I was awestruck. Gargoyles and statues in every imaginable shape and form lining up the exterior also add to the enigma. I‚Äôm sure each of them has its own unique story.
The term ‚ÄòDuomo‚Äô refers to a church, built as, or having the features of, a cathedral, for that particular city. So, if you‚Äôre in Siena and saw the Siena Cathedral, you‚Äôll know that it‚Äôs also called Duomo di Siena.
As with any other popular tourist spot, watch out for unsolicited sellers. As the courtyard attracts flocks of pigeons, most peddlers would offer you maize in plastic bags. Their M.O. is to come up to you to offer to take pictures or directly hand you the packed maize while you‚Äôre engrossed in taking pics or vids on your own. In short, the highest probability of it happening is when you let your guard down.
I grossly underestimated how cold it was and had only one winter coat in my carry-on to wear. The temperature was between 1‚Äì3¬∞C with light showers in between. I might have suffered from imaginary frostbite!
As it was nearing Christmas, there were cute and colorful stalls set up in front of the Duomo. I bought a wool scarf at one of the stalls to try to keep warm.
Not able to withstand the cold any longer, we walked into Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, another well-known Milan landmark that also happens to be a high-end shopping gallery. It‚Äôs right next to the cathedral. The price tags didn‚Äôt stop us from doing a bit of window shopping.
Cold and hunger proved to be a bad combination, so we hunted for food. There‚Äôs a place nearby called Panzerotti Luini, based on our research. It sells fried panzerotti, a savory turnover much like calzones. We had the ones with tomato and mozzarella filling, and man, it was so good! Or was it because we were famished? I really couldn‚Äôt tell.
Then, off we went to Sforza Castle by train from the Duomo station. The journey took only 10 minutes. Castello Sforzesco is a medieval fortress built in the 14th century but was restored and renovated by Francesco Sforza, the Duke of Milan in the 15th Century. It had since undergone renovation and expansion throughout the centuries and even survived WWII bombings. Now an art gallery, you can buy tickets to view the art collection in it.
We roamed around the castle grounds while listening to a busker playing ‚ÄòHey Jude‚Äô with his guitar. The whole scene played out like an Instagram reel!
In the afternoon, we checked in to our Airbnb. Our gracious host, though trying her best to be accommodating, can only speak Italian, bless her soul. The only English she spoke was ‚Äòthank you‚Äô. Thank God for Airbnb messaging with its auto translator function. She used it to give instructions on using appliances in her apartment. My first question was of course, how to turn on the heating system.
Our body clocks seemed to think that it was past midnight (following Malaysian time) so after settling down, we took a long nap.
We had to drag ourselves out of bed around 5 pm. We were supposed to go to Navigli canals. Knowing that it‚Äôd get colder, we decided to take an Uber to go there instead of taking the train.
Only Uber Premium was available, charging up to 40 EUR during this peak time. Gritting my teeth, we hopped into the Volvo S60.
It was 6 pm, the city was jammed up, and our driver was in the foulest mood. He almost ran over a cyclist. In retaliation, the cyclist banged the roof of the Volvo sedan. Our driver got out and there was a screaming match.
He went after the cyclist as he pedaled away, but maybe remembering he had passengers, thought better of it, and went back inside the car. He casually turned around to us and said, ‚ÄúAlways happens‚Äù. I giggled awkwardly, suppressing my heart attack.
The rest of the journey was uneventful with the driver speeding through intersections, seemingly oblivious to cars that might come from the left or right junctions. Finally, we arrived after almost 60 minutes, when it was supposed to be a 25-minute ride in normal hours.
Like Venice, Milan used to be linked with canals. In fact, the canals were built to ferry workers and raw materials back and forth to expedite the construction of famous Milano landmarks ‚Äî the Duomo being one of them. As motorized land vehicles began to dominate the transportation system, most of the canals were cemented over, but the Navigli survives. Today, it becomes a trendy, canal-based neighborhood.
Although we arrived when it was already dark, the Navigli seemed to have only woken up! There are plenty of cafes and bars alongside the canals, made even more charming with Christmas lights. We strolled along the canals, observing the locals making their way to these places for dinner and drinks. (Italians usually have their dinner pretty late, around 8‚Äì9 PM).
No annoying peddlers were trying to sell us trinkets, so we savored the laid-back, nighttime ambiance.
Aware that we‚Äôd have to start our day early for a full-day Lake Como tour tomorrow, we decided to leave at 9.30 PM just when the music from the bars was about to go full-blast.
We learned our lesson and took the train instead to head back to our rented apartment. It was a cheaper, more boring ride back.
Stay tuned for my next entry on our Lake Como trip. Spoiler alert: No sightings of George Clooney or any Hollywood celebrity, whatsoever!

Title: 5 Things I Didn‚Äôt Know About Italy Before Moving Here
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
1
Share
Think you know Italy? Think again.
Though I knew a fair amount about Italian culture before moving to Calabria last year, I‚Äôve learned a few things that have surprised me now that I‚Äôm here.
In the U.S., we are used to being spoiled by friends and family for our birthdays, aren‚Äôt we?
Here, it‚Äôs the opposite. You, the birthday girl, are supposed to take out your loved ones to celebrate you. I think it‚Äôs to offset the cost of the gifts that they give you.
This year, I avoided breaking the bank by having a party at my house instead. But I almost made a faux pas by offering to split a meal the day after my birthday with my ‚ÄúItalian mamma‚Äù until I remembered this strange cultural norm and quickly went to pay for our lunch.
I have never been big on blowdrying my hair, but in Italy, I get raised eyebrows.
It turns out, Italians believe in what they call a colpo d‚Äôaria, literally a hit of air. It causes, or so they believe, headaches, colds, and a litany of maladies. And having wet hair invites it.

Title: Living in Italy as an international student
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

1
Listen
Share
If you are a new student in Italy from another country, this story is for you! I‚Äôve been living in Turin for about 5 years and want to share my experiences with you. If it helps even one person, I‚Äôll be happy. ü•∞
First, I give a brief introduction about myself. When I was in my own country (Iran, Tehran), I studied software engineering and working as a front-end web developer for 3 years. After a 5-year gaps, I returned to academia. ü§ìüìö
I moved to Italy, Turin in August 2019 and graduated in December 2022. I studied in Politecnico di Torino to get a Master‚Äôs degree in Computer Engineering with a Data Analytic specialty. I began working for one year as a business data Analyst; you can read more about my job experience here.
Before moving forward, I need to point out that these are just my personal observations and views; other people may have different experiences.
Okay, let‚Äôs have a look at the challenging parts of studying and living in Italy. ü§üüèº
Without a doubt, the most difficult aspect for me was Italian language! Yes years of studying English from bottom of my heart was nothing! ü•≤ (Believe me I get used to study English as a hobby) and the fact is nearly 97% of the Italian population speaks Italian and only 13% of Italians speak English. English is a mandatory school subject in Italy, however it‚Äôs not taught very well.
The main reason my Italian hasn‚Äôt improved much, because my master‚Äôs degree was in English and I was surrounded by international students and academics, and when I started working, I noticed it was essential to know Italian language, and most of the recruiters will ask you about the level of your language and personally I lost some job opportunities just because I can‚Äôt speak Italian well. ü•≤
Even if you work in a large company with foreign colleagues, don‚Äôt expect them to switch to English during the internal meetings, in coffee or lunch time; trust me, it‚Äôs hard for them and need to put more efforts. People in shops, post offices, and nearly everywhere speak Italian. ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
So, even if you don‚Äôt want to stay in Italy for ever, I recommend that you start learning Italian as soon as you decide to come here. ü§ù üáÆüáπ Knowing the language will greatly improve your quality of life, as well as your ability to make friends and integrate. When you first try to speak Italian, Italians are quite helpful if they feel that you are making efforts. So, don‚Äôt be shy; start talking, even if you only know a few words, use them. üí™üèº
For the first year as a student on a tight budget, it was difficult for me to rent my own flat (In Italian: monolocale), So I lived in a shared house with other flatmates and roommates, but for the second and third years I had my own room in the university dormitories.
If you would like to live in a shared house, you should be prepared for the challenges that come with coexisting and living with other people. However, it might be helpful at first to not feel alone and making friendships and meet people who have a similar situation as you.
To find a house, try to check the Facebook or Telegram groups. Prices vary depending on location, proximity to universities, and city centre. Furthermore, it depends on the place where you live; for example, rent is more expensive in Milan or Rome than in Turin.
Overall, the process of finding a house takes time, so be patient and don‚Äôt be disappointed, especially at the start of the academic year, when new students will arrive, so begin searching earlier.
For the first year, I recommend having your own room in a shared house. Living with Italian flatmates can help you enhance your language skills during your free time too. üòé
If you want to preserve your state scholarship, you must pass specific credits each year, which requires dedication to studying. Most courses, aside from the exam, have a project that should be worked on during the semester, as well as a large amount of material to study DURING the semester; I emphasise DURING because if you study in Iran, you get used to studying a few days before the exam üòÖ but this does not work in Italy at all üò£, and you should actively study, and you will most likely pass on the first call, but some exams you can pass or get your desired score after the second or third call. The lowest score is 18 ü§åüèº, and the maximum is 30 ‚úåüèº.
I suggest doing other activities in your free time, such as joining a gym, going to nature, to avoid becoming overwhelmed and burnt out from only studying. ü•µ
Thinking about staying in Italy in the future depends on your preferences; if you know Italian well and like good food üçïüçùüç∑(who doesn‚Äôt?! üòÑ) and sunny weather ‚òÄÔ∏èüåä ‚õ±Ô∏è, then Italy is your place ü§ù or you may prefer to stay in a country that has better facilities for immigrants (like Germany, Netherlands, Belgium or Canada or America).
Italy lacks infrastructure for immigrants; as an example in order to obtain a driver‚Äôs licence, I need to know Italian (at the B1 level) or you can get a passport after ten years! While In other countries, you can obtain earlier than this. Also consider that the base salary and expenses are lower in compare with the other countries.
I hope you enjoyed this story, please let me know your feedback or if you want to know more about living in Italy.
Have a nice day and thanks for reading! ü•∞

Title: Welcome to ‚ÄòItaly Is My Home‚Äô
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Ciao amico!
Hungry for la vera esperienza italiana? BENVENUTO!
You are at the right place, my friend. Come inside, I will show you what Italy has to offer.
Let‚Äôs have a glass of Martini until the ham, olives and cheese magically appear on our plates.
We are having so much fun making them disappear faster than they appeared.
Eros Ramazzotti singing in the background reminds us about how long we have forgotten to feed our souls too. Pi√π bella cosa, Un emozione per sempre, Se bastasse una canzone, Un altra te are food for the soul.
Italy lifts your spirit.
The food makes you want more out of life, the wine melts any sense of separation, the music allows you to be yourself again and the 28 centuries of history still being written are proving that anything is possible.
You can hear Robert De Niro in the background saying on TV that ‚ÄúItaly has changed. But Rome is Rome.‚Äù
When you finish the last sip of Martini and the last bite of prosciutto and cheese, you start looking around. You notice photos and paintings from all Italian artists.
Italians don‚Äôt need to have the original pieces next to their name. They cherish their ancestors in every home and the original piece is in a place of honor.
Here, everybody‚Äôs rich, because everybody has a bit of Da Vinci, Caravaggio and Michelangelo in themselves.
You begin to understand better when you see the quote from the corner of the room ‚ÄúThe only wealth which you will keep forever is the wealth you have given away.‚Äù ‚Äî Marcus Aurelius.
The Trevi Fountain took 30 years to be built. The Pantheon is still standing after 2000 years.
This the place where time fades away and eternity reigns, and my wealth is your wealth.
What is time? What is the true wealth?
All the wealth, wisdom and joy are in this very moment and nothing can take them away from you.
The beautiful streets of Rome are taking you now to a different country, Vatican, where you notice how the grandest church out of the 100.000 churches in Italy is taking away all the boundaries between the physical and the spiritual world.
The genius of Michelangelo is shaking your perception of reality.
Life as you know it becomes a dream once you get lost in the divine characther of his creations and the pure nature of the Supreme Consciousness becomes the ‚Äònew‚Äô reality.
You don‚Äôt believe God is real until you see the masterpieces of Michelangelo.
After you see them, you don‚Äôt believe God isn‚Äôt real. Spiritual is material and material is spiritual.
The immaterial has materialized through the human being.
We are all a big family.
And what do big families do in Italy? They eat!
The smell of pizza reignites your senses and the taste takes you through all its 1000 years of history.
The wine makes your soul dance.
Italy is the place where you live in the present fully and completely. Before you go there you live in the future, and after you leave, you live in the past, because the heart will take you there and your soul will stay there long after you‚Äôve left.
Here, at Italy Is My Home, I invite you to discover Italy and to live la vera esperienza italiana.
Join me on this magical journey, the journey of la dolce vita.
You can find more of my posts on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Diamond. Don‚Äôt forget to come back here on Medium anytime you want. You are always welcomed!
Saluti!

Hello you!
If you know me, you know how much I obsess over the movie Eat Pray Love and Julia Roberts‚Äô performance in it. Here‚Äôs the tweet ‚Äî oh, I mean, X post ‚Äî I saved up to express this goal of mine.
One of my favourite scenes from the movie is when Julia eats pasta and drinks wine in Italy. That moment, along with her performance, is pure bliss.
Today, I watched Emily in Paris, Season 4, Part 2. Spoiler alert!
I saw a similar scene where Emily and Marchello eat Italian food with the same sense of bliss, making me feel warm and smile. It reminded me how much I longed for that full Italian experience, just like Julia Roberts in Eat Pray Love.
Italy, await me. I‚Äôll see you soon!ü•Ç
Read about what made me smile on Day 16.

Over the past seven years, I‚Äôve lived in Southern Italy for at least three months a year. In the past two years, my partner and I have lived in Italy full-time, most of it in the south.
Between November of 2019 and November of 2021, we hadn‚Äôt actually been back to the States. When we finally were able to go back without fear of being denied re-entry to Italy, we realized there were so many little tricks we learned along the way.
My first experience in southern Italy came in the spring, when I flew over from China to visit my mom, who happened to be renting an apartment in a small town.
Coming from the Southeast in America to this small, damp town located in the foothills of the Cilento, my mom had her radiators on full blast.
During one particularly chilly afternoon, we were offered a coffee from a neighbor up the road. When we arrived at her house, we found the entire family in the kitchen, huddled around a TV, fire merrily dancing in the fireplace. The neighbor explained that in the winter, families will retreat to one room, usually the one with a fireplace or wood pellet stove. Gas, the main source of heat, is expensive, and‚Ä¶
