DAILY ADVENTURES
The weather was: Sunny
Day / date: 01/07/2016
Destination: Rome
Plans for the day: Land, check-in, get food and rest, and see some sites.
My daily adventures: See earlier notes for info on today.
We also picked up some water from a Marian fountain; I‚Äôve consumed most of it though.
I‚Äôm also impressed with the number of drinking fountains in Rome that are free to use, and the quality of the water that comes from these. Apparently there are 1300+ in Rome, which is really impressive.
My desire to learn Latin has substantially increased.
******
The weather was: sunny
Day / date: 02/07/16
Destination: Roma, Italia
Plans for the day: Revisit some Churches, visit the Colosseum, Colosseum night tour, and take photos, Trastavere, look for gifts.
My daily adventures: We went to the Roman Forum, which was spectacular! We stumbled upon an ancient Marian Church that is on display there until September. We got a lot of photos, so that was exceptionally well timed.
The Colosseum was fascinating, and it was incredible to tick it off the bucket list. The night tour of it was even more exceptional. Pizza from the corner shop was okay but not the best. Really cheap though. At the Colosseum, we met an Australian woman who said she thought that the Italians lived in a museum. I thought she was pretty accurate with that comment.
******
The weather was: sunny
Day / date: 03/07/16
Destination: Roma, Italia and Vatican City
Plans for the Day: Attend Mass, visit the Vatican, Check out of hotel, join and commence our two-week tour.
My daily adventures: Went to Vatican, St Peter‚Äôs Square. Bought 300 Euro odd-dollars‚Äô worth of Rosaries, etc. which we had blessed in the Papal blessing. Moved to the new hotel. It has a bigger room but has a less comfortable bed. We met our Tour Director (Lambros in Gk. or Alex in Italian) then Mum and I went and had chips and lasagne (which was beautiful) at a local Italian restaurant that her and Courtney had eaten at year‚Äôs prior.
******
The weather was: sunny
Day / date: 04/07/16
Destination: Roma, Italia
Plans for the day: Sistine Chapel, St Peter‚Äôs Basilica, Roman Forum, Colosseum, Dinner.
My daily adventures: This was our first day with the tour.
Sistine Chapel ‚Äî amazing! We will definitely need to revisit this & St. Peter‚Äôs basilica to spend more time taking it in. The tour guide was great, but I felt we didn‚Äôt get as much time in the Colosseum and Forum as was necessary. I was very grateful we had visited them previously. Dinner was good, consisting of bruschetta, pasta with peas, lasagne, chicken and potatoes, then gelato and coffee.
I‚Äôm not sure how these places are able to make a profit, so I assume it is through bulk cooking that they are able to do so. Dinner was accompanied by a flute player and a guitarist, which was nice.
P.s. Today we also met our bus drive Pino.
******
The weather was: sunny with clouds
Day / day: Tuesday 05/07/16
Destination: Roma, Pisa, Montecatini ‚Äî Italia
Plans for the day:
My daily adventures:
On our way from Rome I felt really sick from the bus motion. Consequently I loaded up on my travel tables. As of lunchtime (now), I‚Äôm in a medically induced tiredness. We then went to Pisa and saw the leaning tower. Lunch was pizza and biscotti from some street shops. We opted to check out the Cathedral, Baptistery and the cemetery rather than climb the tower. I tried European Maccas there. We had dinner @ Montecatini at a local winery / olive oil farm. The food and wine were delicious and we had great company.
******
The weather was: Sunny with clouds
Day / date: 06/07/2016 ‚Äî Wednesday
Destination: Florence, Italia
Plans for the day: visit Florence
My daily adventures:
We went to Florence today and got to do a tour with a local guide. From there we went to a local market sitting on a bridge. There is lots of jewellery and leather in Florence, but it is expensive. The highlight of the day for me was paying 15 Euro to go to the Cathedral, baptistery and Museum. We saw some relics, etc. Back at Montecatini, we went to the Funicular and then had dinner at the hotel. I then had a few drinks at the bar.
******
The weather was: sunny
Day / date: 07/07/16
Destination: La spezia, cinque terre, Levanto, Genoa, Italia
Plans for the day: Have pesto, check out local village markets, possibly visit the beach, go somewhere nice for dinner
My daily adventures: Today we went to la spezia to catch a train to the cinque terre. Whilst there we visited Vernazza and Monterosso. At Vernazza I looked at the Church, went up to the tower and walked around. At Monterosso we walked around the old section, had pesto @ Ristorante ‚ÄòDa Ely‚Äù and I ought a beach towel for 10 Euro. We then caught a train to Levanto, where our bus took us to our accommodation in Genoa, a nice, four star hotel. We then went to dinner at a place recommended by our tour Director Lambros, but I didn‚Äôt think it was that great.
******
The weather was: Sunny with clouds, cloudy
Day / date: 08/07/2016
Destination: Genoa, Milan, Lake Maggiore, Italia
Plans for the day: as above, with tour dinner
My daily adventures: We had a tour of Genoa with a local guide. They were very knowledgeable, but I didn‚Äôt find Genoa as impressive as some of the other locations we have visited. From there, we drove to Milan. I checked out the Cathedral, had Maccas for lunch, bought some Galati and visited the local shops. We then went to Lake Maggiore. We‚Äôre staying in a nice hotel here, although we had to get the bed adjusted from a double to a twin share. We had dinner on a nearby island as part of the tour, sitting with two Australia couples.
******
The weather was: sunny with clouds
Day / date: 09/07/2016
Destination: Lugano, Switzerland
Plans for the day:
My daily adventures: We took the bus from Lake Maggiore to Lugano, crossing the boarder into Switzerland. From there, we went to Monte Tamaro, where we had some lunch and got to see an amazing view. To do this, we had to catch a chair lift up and back. After this, we came back to the hotel.
******
The weather was: sunny with clouds
Day / date: 10/11/2016
Destination: Verona and Venice, Italy
Plans for the day:
My daily adventures: we left our hotel and went to Verona, where we had a tour of the place and got to touch the boob of the statue of Juliet. We had lunch there and I had really nice pasta. From there, we drove to our hotel near Venice. At night, we went to dinner in Venice and had a quick look around. The food wasn‚Äôt too great (in my humble opinion) but Venice was beautiful.
******
The weather was: sunny with clouds
Day / date: 11/07/2016
Destination: Venice, Italy
Plans for the day:
My daily adventures:
We went to Venice via boat again. After finding some people in our group that got separated from the group, we did a gondola ride, which was stunning. After that, we went and got a replacement earring for Julie, before getting lunch. I had pasta and a 500ml bottle of Chianti to myself, which left me a little drunk for the afternoon. We didn‚Äôt get to see inside St. Mark‚Äôs Basilica, but we were able to see other churches, including S. Giovanni Basilica. We had some ice cream, looked at shops, went back to the hotel and had dinner with some Spanish and NZ friends.
******
The weather was: Sunny (Assisi) Cloudy (Ravenna)
Day / date: 12/07/2016
Destination: Ravenna and Assisi (Dante‚Äôs tomb is in Ravenna)
Plans for the day: Drop off Mirtza‚Äôs prayer in Assisi. Visit the Basilica.
My daily adventures: On the way to Ravenna we saw the longest river in Italy (650 km) and the church where the musical scale was invented. At Ravenna, we visited the Arian baptistery and the Church of St. Francis, along with Dante‚Äôs sepulchre. On the way to Assisi, we stopped for lunch and had a lasagne. At Assisi, we visited the Basilica, which was amazing! Three churches on top of one another! We bought some things at the gift shop and then headed over to our hotel in Perugia for the evening, where we had dinner.
‚ÄúThis is a beautiful country.‚Äù (My reflection in the margin at 3:15pm on bus in rural area on the way to Assisi)
******
The weather was: sunny
Day / date: 13/07/2016 ‚Äî Wednesday
Destination: Pompeii
Plans for the day: visit Pompeii, survive the long bus ride.
My daily adventures: We left our hotel early this morning to drive to Pompeii, then Sorrento. On the way we watched a movie, ‚ÄòMy life in ruins‚Äô (a comedy allegedly w/ Tom Hanks as the producer about tours). When we got to Pompeii, I had some Pasta, bought some post cards and a booklet on the place. We then took a tour of part of Pompeii, which is so impressive! We arrived at Sorrento about 5:00pm.
******
The weather was: sunny
Day / date: 14/07/2016
Destination: Capri, Italy
Plans for the day:
My daily adventures: We went on a ferry to Capri. Unfortunately, I was sick on the way over and on the bus after. This caused me to miss the chair lift. Afterwards, we went to a Museum and had lunch, followed by a walk to some scenic spots and a ride on the funicular. We headed back to the hotel for a nice buffet and went for a walk with some friends through Sorrento, stopping at a wine bar for a drink.
******
The weather was: raining
Day/date: 15/07/2016
Destination: Positano, then Rome
Plans for the day: Visit Positano, get to Rome, wash clothes for tomorrow.
My daily adventures: We caught a bus to Positano, where it was raining. This is the only day so far that it has been raining whilst we have been on tour. We checked out Santa Maria Assunta Esan Vito whilst there. From there, we made our way back to Rome, only stopping briefly at two places to get some food and to have a toilet stop, because traffic jams caused us some delays. The dinner was a bit disappointing, but the company was nice with a brief tour on the bus following at night, along with a stop over at Trevi Fountain.
******
The weather was: sunny
Day / date: 16/07/2016
Destination: Roma, Italia
Plans for the day: Move hotels, make our plans for the rest of the week, get a nice lunch / dinner, go site seeing.
My daily adventures: We had breakfast with our kiwi friends prior to moving to our old hotel. 140 Euro a night to sleep on a couch, as Mum had the bed. Anyway, we went and checked out the temples of portuna and Hercules, the mouth of truth and related basilica, another church and basilica, picked up some holy water, crucifix and prayer card, ate pizza and Maccas, washed clothes. I bought a guide to the pantheon (which we revisited) and read it, and also bought a bottle of cheap Chianti for consumption prior to the trip home.
******
The weather was: sunny
Day / date: 17/07/2016
Destination: Roma, Italia
Plans for the day: Mass @ Pantheon, visit catacombs
My daily adventures: Today we went to Mass @ the Pantheon. This was cool, as they turned on all the lights and cleared the tourists out for it. There were only 18 or so people 5 minutes beforehand, but it ended up with about 100 or so. From there, we met up with Anita & Ryan after lunch and walked to the catacombs. These were so impressive, and definitely worth the 8 Euro to get in. After this, we bought some pizza and had it on our hotel‚Äôs rooftop.
******
The weather was: sunny
Day / date: 18/07/2016
Destination:

Revisiting Romans 9
One of the religious topics I have most disputed in the last few years is, ‚ÄòDoes God love all men?‚Äô Historically, I have said no on the basis of Romans chapter 9.
After hearing a sermon on 1 Timothy 2:4 (God desires all men to be saved and to come to a knowledge of the truth), I knew I could not accept an understanding that requires two wills in God or the verse to be interpreted to mean, ‚Äòall elect men‚Äô, not ‚Äòall men‚Äô.
The only section for which I had not been able to come to a reasonable conclusion about was this section in Romans 9, particularly:
Material consulted during the process included:
I understood the Calvinist position well, but was unable to understand the Catholic position on this scripture. They are not quite Calvinistic, Lutheran or Arminian. Nevertheless, a sermon by Adrian Rogers (not Catholic) helped me along with various writings of Thomas Aquinas (summa theologica and his notes on Romans) to finally see how people with other paradigms hold their position.
This position seems to me to make better sense of the particular text, of the scriptures as a whole, and of the Catholic position. Consequently, this post constitutes a retraction of my former position (unless it can be sufficiently demonstrated otherwise that this position is wrong).

Title: WHAT ARE THE TOP THREE THINGS ITALY IS KNOWN FOR?
Content:

Listen

Italy, a land of stunning landscapes, rich history, and unparalleled culture, has captivated the hearts of travelers and scholars for centuries. From its ancient ruins to world-renowned cuisine, Italy boasts an array of symbols and traditions that have left an indelible mark on the world. In this article, we will explore the top three things for which Italy is most renowned: its art and architecture, its cuisine, and its fashion.
Italy has been at the forefront of artistic innovation for centuries, playing a pivotal role in the development of Western art. The country is home to some of the most significant and influential artists in history, such as Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, and Caravaggio. Their masterpieces, which adorn galleries, churches, and public spaces across Italy, continue to inspire generations.
When it comes to architecture, Italy has some of the most recognizable landmarks in the world. The Leaning Tower of Pisa, the Colosseum in Rome, and St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica in Vatican City are just a few examples. Each of these structures tells a story, not only of architectural prowess but also of the cultural and historical significance of their times.
The Renaissance, which began in Italy during the 14th century, marked a significant turning point in the realm of art and architecture. This period saw the rebirth of classical ideals, leading to the creation of breathtaking works that continue to draw art lovers from all corners of the globe. Florence, often regarded as the cradle of the Renaissance, is particularly famous for its contributions to art and culture, with its Uffizi Gallery housing masterpieces that tell the story of human expression.
Italian cuisine is world-famous, celebrated for its fresh ingredients, bold flavors, and regional diversity. The country‚Äôs culinary history tells a story of simplicity and tradition. Every dish carries a deep connection to the land and the people, making Italian food as much about love and family as it is about sustenance.
Some of the hallmark dishes of Italian cuisine include pasta, pizza, and risotto. Each region has its own variations and specialties. For instance, in Naples, the classic Margherita pizza showcases a simple yet delightful combination of tomatoes, mozzarella, and basil. In contrast, pasta dishes like Tagliatelle al Rag√π resonate deeply within households and are often made from scratch.
One of the key aspects of Italian cooking is the emphasis on fresh, high-quality ingredients. The Mediterranean climate allows for the cultivation of exceptional produce, such as ripe tomatoes, fragrant basil, and rich olive oil. Italian cuisine encourages the use of seasonal ingredients, resulting in dishes that not only taste exceptional but also reflect the cycle of nature.
Italy is often regarded as the fashion capital of the world, with cities like Milan and Florence leading the charge in haute couture and luxury design. Italian fashion has a distinctive style that embraces sophistication, innovation, and craftsmanship. Renowned designers like Gucci, Prada, and Versace have made their mark not only on the runways of Milan but also in the hearts of fashion enthusiasts globally.
Milan Fashion Week is one of the most prestigious events in the fashion calendar, where designers unveil their latest collections to the world. This event showcases a mix of established fashion houses and emerging designers, illustrating the dynamic nature of Italian fashion. The impact of Italian style permeates beyond clothing; it influences accessories, jewelry, and even the world of home design.
What sets Italian fashion apart is its commitment to craftsmanship and attention to detail. Many Italian brands uphold a tradition of artisanal techniques, ensuring that each piece embodies quality and elegance. The ‚ÄúMade in Italy‚Äù label is synonymous with luxury and is a mark of pride for designers and craftsmen alike.
Italy is rich in artistic heritage across various regions. Key areas include:
Italian cuisine varies significantly by region due to geographical factors, climate, and local produce. For instance, Northern Italy features creamy risottos, while Southern Italy is known for its robust tomato-based dishes. Each region‚Äôs traditions and ingredients uniquely shape its culinary offerings.
Italian fashion is influenced by historical and cultural factors, including art, architecture, and societal changes. The elegance of Renaissance art often influences contemporary designs, while modern-day Milan serves as a hub for global fashion trends, blending tradition with innovation.
To truly immerse yourself in Italian culture, consider:
The ‚ÄúMade in Italy‚Äù label signifies quality, luxury, and craftsmanship. It represents products made in Italy, often using traditional methods and high-grade materials, thereby reflecting Italy‚Äôs dedication to excellence in design and production.
Italy, with its enchanting art, delectable cuisine, and impeccable fashion sense, stands as a beacon of culture and heritage for the world. Each of these three aspects intertwines with the identity of the Italian people and showcases their contributions to art, food, and style. Whether you‚Äôre an avid art enthusiast, a food lover, or a fashion aficionado, Italy offers a rich tapestry of experiences that celebrate what it means to be Italian.

Title: Buying an apartment in Italy ‚Äî or how to survive a sanatoria
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I am a Finnish software developer who recently moved to Italy. This is the third episode in a series of posts where I write about my experiences in living in my new home country.
The observations are written by someone who has lived most of his life in the Northern Europe: first around 30 years in Finland and then some years in the Netherlands.
This post is not strictly part of the same canon as the previous ones as I wasn‚Äôt yet living in Italy at the time the events took place. But the story is still worth telling because it revolves around the same topic as the previous episode: bureaucracy, oh yes!
Around August 2021 me and my girlfriend were looking for an apartment to buy in Sardinia. We went to see a couple of places and found an interesting one. In October, after a careful calculation of our financial status, we decided to make an offer for the apartment. To our surprise the offer was accepted! I started dreaming about sitting on my own patio staring into the sunset while enjoying an ice-cold Ichnusa non filtrata.
I had heard horror stories on how the bureaucracy in Italy can be extremely slow. My pessimistic expectation was that drinking Ichnusa on the patio would have to wait around early spring 2022. Magari!
I wanted to make sure that I have everything ready when the time comes to sign the papers and make the notary act. I applied for a codice fiscale in the Embassy of Italy in the Hague. I contacted my bank in Finland to apply for a mortgage, and I even had the purchase proposal translated into English for them. I made all the necessary arrangements to have all my finances available with a few clicks of a button. My bank told me that after signing the documents for the mortgage, it could take even up to a week for the funds to be available. I assured them that one week is nothing when dealing with Italian bureaucracy.
At the same time, my girlfriend was also applying for a mortgage in an Italian bank. One of the requirements for the mortgage was that there should be a technical inspection done on the apartment. Sounds reasonable. The real estate agent told us that since the building is relatively new, from the early 2000s, and the apartment is quite small, the technical inspection is just a formality, and that there shouldn‚Äôt be any issues with it.
The inspection was done around December, and we were anxiously waiting for the statement to be released. Around middle of February we received a message from the agent that all lights are green, and that everything is ready for signing the purchase agreement. I withdrew the mortgage and liquidated my other assets. I was proud of myself for being fully prepared and having everything ready. Finnish efficiency at its best ‚Äî I‚Äôm not going to be the bottleneck. We agreed that we would sign the purchase agreement March 1st. I could almost taste the Ichnusa.
Things started getting delayed by a few weeks but I wasn‚Äôt worried. I guess minor delays were expected and nothing out of the ordinary. But then we heard that there is an issue that was noticed in the technical inspection. This is the first time I heard the horrifying word: sanatoria. Sanatoria in itself is not a bad thing, it‚Äôs actually good. But the problem is when the sanatoria has not been done, in other words the sanatoria is unresolved. In the context of real estate, this means that someone has improvised and built something funky without proper permissions and violated the building regulations. In Finland this means building an illegal sauna too close to the shore. Legally, you cannot sell an apartment that has an unresolved sanatoria. (Though, this being Italy, of course there‚Äôs always a way.)
The technical inspection declared that there was a mismatch between the official documents and the reality. According to the documents there should be a small balcony in the bedroom. In fact, there was no balcony but there is a window. This was a surprise both to us and the owner of the apartment. But doesn‚Äôt sound like too big of a problem, right? One might think that it would be a bigger issue if there was a balcony that shouldn‚Äôt be there. And yes, that‚Äôs true. It didn‚Äôt seem like a big problem. But while the balcony didn‚Äôt exist, whoever genius who built the apartment had decided to make the bedroom slightly larger than it was supposed to be. And that‚Äôs not good.
What is the solution? You need to find a way to make the documents and the reality aligned. So you have to either grab a hammer and start building a balcony, or you need to amend the documents. I don‚Äôt know how to build a balcony and I would expect that adjusting the paperwork is easier so that‚Äôs what we decided to do. Practically, this means that you need to have a good connection with the municipality officials and you need to hire a local geometra to come make measurements, and draw new blueprints, etc. Obviously, depending on the size of the sanatoria, all of this costs money, but time is the bigger problem. The owner would pay for the sanatoria but it can take a long time to get it resolved, even years.
Apparently, in Sardinia this is a common problem. There are many houses that have an unresolved sanatoria which effectively means that you cannot sell or buy them. Our agent came up with a marvellous (though not a unique) idea: Rather than signing the purchase agreement at this moment, we could make a private agreement with the owner stating that we pay some lump of money right now in advance, then we would wait for the sanatoria to be resolved, I could already go drink Ichnusa on the patio, and after that we would finalise the deal and sign the purchase agreement. Sounds amazing, right? Wrong. If you‚Äôve read my previous posts, you already know that I‚Äôm not a big fan of this kind of unorthodox arrangements. We kindly rejected the idea.
The agent assured us that the sanatoria should be definitely resolved by the end of May. Time passed, our offer expired, we renewed the offer, winter turned to spring, Ichnusa got warm, and spring turned to summer. The offer expired again in June and we renewed it for one final time. It expired again in July and we decided not to renew it anymore. We hadn‚Äôt heard anything from the agent for a long time. I still had all the earmarked money lying in my bank account. I was sad and disappointed.
In July I went for a trip to Scotland with my friends. We booked a rental car and drove around while sipping whisky: Edinburgh, Inverness, Isle of Skye, Fort William, Oban, Glasgow, and back to Edinburgh. I highly recommend Scotland as a travel destination. I learned that Speyside whisky is not my favourite but I do like Highland whisky. And it was confirmed that I especially enjoy the smoky ones from Islay. Also, after having tasted a whisky it‚Äôs nice to compare your experience with maestro L√ºning, Horst L√ºning, and see what is his interpretation of it. I challenge you to come up with as many adjectives to describe the whisky as Horst does.
Anyway, by the end of our heavily peated trip in Scotland I received a message from my girlfriend that suddenly things are moving fast with the apartment. By some miracle the sanatoria had been resolved and that, if we are still interested, the owner is willing to sell the apartment for the same price as we initially offered. We had to act fast, because the mortgage proposal provided by the Italian bank for my girlfriend was expiring in September, and at this moment we were almost in August. August in Italy is the peak holiday season so finding a notary to notarise the purchase agreement could be extremely difficult, but luckily the agent already had one available.
Finally, grazie a Dio, in the beginning of August we bought the apartment. It only took around 10 months after we made the initial offer. The purchase happened at the same time as we were about to move from the Netherlands to Italy, which felt a bit overwhelming in the beginning. However, the combination of living in the mainland Italy, in Frascati, and having a beach house in Sardinia has turned out to be a fantastic concept. And Ichnusa does taste pretty damn good when you enjoy it on your own patio.
Random observations about the whole process:

Content:

I recently came back from a three month working culinary tour of Italy where I fell truly, madly, deeply, in love with pasta. I am a young cook from Massachusetts and embarked on the journey to awaken my senses to the culinary center of the universe that is Italy (apologies to the French). After spending about a month in Florence, eating anything and everything I could get my hands on, I decided to spend the second month volunteering on a farm in the rural city of Citt√† di Castello, about an hour and a half east of Florence. For one month I planted seeds, milked goats, mowed grass, and for the turning point‚Ä¶made pasta. I had made homemade pasta a handful of times before; my dad always made it around Christmas time and I had taken a class about it earlier in the trip. But for some reason, learning it here was completely different. I was taken to another planet when I was making pasta on the farm ‚Äî it was a transcendental experience for me, if you will. I fell in love with the art of it and knew that I had to continue when I arrived back to the states.
Handcrafted pasta had taken hold of me and wasn‚Äôt letting go anytime soon. Here I am, a few months later, back in the states and it‚Äôs grip is stronger than ever ‚Äî I recently opened an Italian inspired handcrafted pasta business, Allora Pasta Co. I use the recipe that I learned from the woman in Italy and take the same time, care, and love as I did then. I focus on carefully sourced ingredients ‚Äî working with local farmers as much as possible to ensure a delicious, quality product you can feel good about eating and sharing with your loved ones.
While I can‚Äôt share my secret pasta recipe with you, I will share a few of my favorite sauces to go along with your pasta of choice. Whip up one of these bad boys, grab yourself a bag (or 5) of Allora, a bottle of Prosecco and you‚Äôll be transported to a little caffe set upon cobble stone streets and beautiful churches in the center of Rome. To learn more about Allora Pasta Co. and my Italian adventures, visit www.allorapasta.com.
Aglio e olio (Garlic and Oil)
Italy‚Äôs most beloved sauce and a staple of Italian cooking, aglio e olio is simple to make but offers a complex flavor that will have any guest impressed by your skills.
6 tbsp and 2 tbsp of extra virgin olive oil
4 cloves of garlic, sliced thin
1/2 cup pasta water, mmm starchy = creamy
Red pepper flakes (if you like a little kick!)
Salt and pepper to taste
Make this recipe after the pasta has already been cooked and reserve 1/2 cup of pasta water. Add the garlic and 6 tablespoons of oil to a large, hot (this is important) pan. Add red pepper flakes for that little kick. Cook over medium heat until garlic is light brown. Transfer your fully cooked pasta and the pasta water to the pan, rev up that heat, and cook‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcontinually stirring and tossing until a creamy sauce forms and coats all of the pasta. Remove from heat and add the remaining 2 tablespoons of olive oil, stir well to combine.
Basil Almond Pesto
Deriving from Genoa, Italy, Pesto has been around for centuries. While this isn‚Äôt the exact ‚ÄòItalian recipe‚Äô it is an adapted version I think you will find delectable to your taste buds.
2 cups packed fresh basil leaves
2 cloves of garlic
1/4 cup slivered almonds
2/3 cup extra virgin olive oil
1/2 cup grated parmesan cheese
Salt and pepper to taste
Combine basil, garlic, and almond in food processor and pulse until all is coarsely chopped. Slowly add the oil and process until fully incorporated and smooth. Transfer the mixture into a large mixing bowl and stir in the cheese. Salt and pepper until perfection!
Tuscan Rag√∫
Ah, ‚Äòmeat sauce.‚Äô The perfect addition to any pasta dish. Turning a light snack into a hearty, wholly satisfying meal. Add the ingredients to a crock pot and simmer for a few hours to invite an even more complex flavor over for dinner.
1 cup stock of choice (veggie, chicken, or beef)
14oz ground beef
3.5oz ground pork, such as ground sausage
2 medium white onions
3 peeled tomatoes
1 celery stick
1 carrot
2 glasses of red wine, 1 to sip and 1 for the sauce üòâ
1 cup of milk
Salt and pepper to taste
Add a drizzle of oil to a medium sized pot and brown the vegetables on a medium-high flame, add 1/2 cup of the stock to keep from burning. Season with salt and pepper. Once browned, add the meat and continue to brown. Add the wine (1 cup) and let it reduce and eventually evaporate. Stir in tomatoes and milk. Add more broth if necessary to avoid sticking. Cook on low flame for an hour or so ‚Äî until all the meat is cooked through and the flavors have come together. Salt and pepper to taste.
All recipes have been adapted from ones I had learned during my time in Italy.

Content:

Italy, a country renowned for its rich history, breathtaking landscapes, and delectable cuisine, carries with it several nicknames that reflect its unique identity. These monikers capture the essence of the nation and the various aspects that make it special. In this article, we will explore Italy‚Äôs most popular nicknames, their meanings, and what they signify about this beautiful country.
One of Italy‚Äôs most famous nicknames is ‚ÄúBel Paese,‚Äù which translates to ‚ÄúBeautiful Country‚Äù in English. This nickname encapsulates Italy‚Äôs extraordinary natural beauty, encompassing everything from its picturesque countryside, rolling hills, and stunning coastal regions to its historic cities filled with architectural marvels.
The name ‚ÄúBel Paese‚Äù is frequently used in art and literature to describe the aesthetic beauty of Italy. It represents Italy‚Äôs legacy of art and culture, where countless artists, musicians, and writers have drawn inspiration. From the scenic landscapes of Tuscany to the grandeur of Venice, it is no surprise that Italy is celebrated for its beauty.
Italy is often colloquially referred to as the ‚ÄúBoot‚Äù due to its distinctive shape resembling a high-heeled boot on the map. This playful nickname is used mainly in informal contexts and reflects the country‚Äôs geographical layout.
The ‚ÄúBoot‚Äù concept adds an element of charm to discussing Italy and is often used to help depict the different regions of the country. For example, the ‚Äútoe‚Äù of the boot refers to Calabria, while the ‚Äúheel‚Äù pertains to Apulia. This geographical representation enables both Italians and visitors to understand the country‚Äôs diverse geographical and cultural landscape better.
Another popular nickname that resonates with many people is ‚ÄúLa Dolce Vita,‚Äù which translates to ‚ÄúThe Sweet Life.‚Äù This phrase became particularly famous after the release of Federico Fellini‚Äôs 1960 film of the same name. The essence of ‚ÄúLa Dolce Vita‚Äù captures the Italian spirit of enjoying life‚Äôs pleasures, from delicious food and wine to beautiful art and architecture.
Italy‚Äôs rich culinary tradition, full of regional specialties, delightful desserts, and world-famous wines, epitomizes this philosophy. Italians celebrate family gatherings, socializing over meals, and savoring life‚Äôs simple pleasures ‚Äî an approach to life that many associate with the Italian way of living.
While not a nickname in the traditional sense, it is essential to note that the very name ‚ÄúItalia‚Äù carries immense historical significance. The term ‚ÄúItalia‚Äù originally referred to a specific region in Southern Italy and has roots dating back to the ancient Greeks. Over the centuries, the name expanded to encompass the entire country after the unification of Italy in the 19th century.
The name is derived from the ancient Italic tribes that settled in the region. Today, ‚ÄúItalia‚Äù is a source of pride for Italians and an integral part of the country‚Äôs identity. It represents the nation‚Äôs long history, rich cultural heritage, and diverse regional influences.
Italy is also often referred to as ‚ÄúThe Land of the Popes‚Äù due to its historical and religious significance. With over 1,800 years of papal history, Rome is home to the Vatican City ‚Äî the smallest independent state in the world and the spiritual center of the Roman Catholic Church.
This nickname highlights Italy‚Äôs important role in the history of Christianity and its influence on global religious practices. Not only does it identify Italy with a significant aspect of its culture, but it also attracts millions of tourists annually who visit the Vatican to see treasures like St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica and the Sistine Chapel.
Italy is famously known as ‚ÄúThe Cradle of the Renaissance,‚Äù a nickname that captures its historical importance as the birthplace of one of the most significant cultural movements in European history. The Renaissance, which occurred from the 14th to the 17th century, marked a period of rejuvenation in art, science, and thought, leading to monumental changes in society.
Cities like Florence, Venice, and Rome were pivotal in showcasing revolutionary ideas and artistic achievements. Renowned artists such as Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, and Raphael emerged during this time, and their works continue to be celebrated worldwide. The nickname reminds us of Italy‚Äôs enduring legacy as a cultural powerhouse.
Italy is known by several nicknames, including ‚ÄúBel Paese‚Äù (Beautiful Country), ‚ÄúThe Boot,‚Äù ‚ÄúLa Dolce Vita‚Äù (The Sweet Life), ‚ÄúThe Land of the Popes,‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Cradle of the Renaissance.‚Äù
Italy is colloquially referred to as the ‚ÄúBoot‚Äù because of its distinctive geographical shape that resembles a high-heeled boot on the world map. This nickname is useful for identifying different regions of the country, like referring to the ‚Äútoe‚Äù or ‚Äúheel.‚Äù
‚ÄúLa Dolce Vita‚Äù translates to ‚ÄúThe Sweet Life,‚Äù reflecting the Italian ethos of savoring life‚Äôs pleasures, including food, art, and company. It symbolizes the relaxed and joyful approach to life that many associate with Italian culture.
Italy earned this nickname due to its significant role in the Renaissance, a period of cultural rebirth that began in the 14th century. Notable cities like Florence and artists such as Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo emerged during this transformative era, leading to lasting contributions in art, philosophy, and science.
The name ‚ÄúItalia‚Äù has historical roots, originating from ancient Italic tribes. It has since become a source of national pride and represents the country‚Äôs cultural heritage and diversity stemming from thousands of years of history.
Italy‚Äôs nicknames encapsulate the nation‚Äôs beauty, culture, and historical significance. From ‚ÄúBel Paese‚Äù to ‚ÄúLa Dolce Vita,‚Äù these monikers highlight the unique aspects of Italian life and the enduring impact that Italy has had on art, cuisine, and religion across the world. The richness of Italy‚Äôs nicknames is a testament to its profound influence over the centuries, drawing visitors from all around the globe to experience the magic of this remarkable country.

Title: My Letter to Italy
Content:

The alarm clock goes off at 7:00am. I immediately do my morning stretches before going for my habitual morning run, a few kilometers traversing the narrow, winding streets of Cinque Vie and around the Castello Sforzesco. After, either a bowl of whole-grain cereal mixed with bananas and strawberries and Turkish coffee. If I‚Äôm feeling extra Italian, a brioches al pistacchio topped off with a warm cup of cappuccino at the corner caf√©. Then I‚Äôm off to work at my office located in the historic 14th century Palazzo Borromeo. Lunches would consist of either a plate of pasta or a protein-based dish, to be had on the fashionable piazza just in front of my office with a view of a 16th century church. In the evening, a drink or two at my favorite lounge at the Darsena neighborhood. Had it been Fashion Week or Design Week, a quick pit-stop at an after party or at a gallery opening before heading home to get a peaceful night‚Äôs rest.
This was how some of my days looked like in Milan, the city I called home for nearly a decade. I had moved to this bustling metropolis at the tender age of seventeen to study at university. With dreams as vast as the endless cityscape before me, I embarked on a voyage of self-discovery, leaving behind the familiar comforts of my hometown of Jakarta.
The streets of Milan hummed with the promise of adventure, each corner whispering secrets waiting to be uncovered. Amidst the towering skyscrapers and labyrinthine cobblestone alleyways, I found myself at the cusp of adulthood, navigating the intricate tapestry of urban life with a blend of trepidation and exhilaration. With every step, I wove my own narrative into the fabric of the city, carving out a place for myself amidst the chaos and possibility. And so, the saga of my odyssey began, a tale of resilience, growth, and the boundless potential of a longing to succeed.
This journey had not been without its lows. Finding myself in the midst of an international crowd had made it difficult to learn the local language, especially during my initial years in Milan. It was only when I started to join the workforce that the melody of the language began to spark a note within me. What had initially been thinking twice and endlessly practicing under my breath before going into a caf√© to order an espresso eventually became second nature. Over the years, I had become a fixture at these caf√©s; the staff need not ask what I would like to order anymore, they simply bring me il solito, the usual. I am, after all, a creature of habit.
I owe much of my relative prowess in the language to my friends and colleagues, who patiently endured my stumbling attempts at conjugations. Their encouragement, coupled with countless laughs at my linguistic missteps, transformed my rudimentary grasp of Italian into something more coherent. Granted, they didn‚Äôt teach me to speak Italian; they taught me to speak Milanese, which is what some Italians regard as a refined blend of English and Italian generally spoken by overachieving business people and stylish fashion enthusiasts in the nation‚Äôs financial capital.
Covered in an abundance of arts and culture, my life in Milan had been rather colorful. I had the remarkable opportunity to come across people from diverse backgrounds, eat marvelous food, and travel relentlessly. However, it had not always been easy. When the pandemic hit at the onset of this decade, like many other young people starting off in their careers, I had struggled to cope with the stringent restrictions. I was fortunate enough to be living with two extraordinary people who respectively hailed from Spain and Sicily, who undoubtedly made my time in quarantine worthwhile. We would sit for hours over home-made Sicilian cuisine sharing stories about our lives prior to coming to Milan. As the sun-kissed Mediterranean flavors danced in our palates, we all felt extremely connected through the commonalities we had discovered in the stories we shared. Naturally, we all kept in touch after we went our separate ways, the Spaniard to Emilia Romagna and the Sicilian to her native island. She would sometimes send me the quintessential pacco da gi√π, a package usually sent by madres and nonnas of the South to their children and grandchildren in the North. She would fill these pacchi with paste di mandorla, my favorite Sicilian dessert after cannoli.
Among the bustling piazzas of the city, there lay a treasure trove of museums, each a sanctuary for treasured paintings and sculptures. These cultural havens became my beloved retreats, and further fueled my interest for the arts. I often find myself gazing at Francesco Hayez‚Äôs Il bacio, the masterpiece on display towards the end of the Pinacoteca di Brera, for prolonged periods of time. Michelangelo‚Äôs statue of David commands attention from its prominent position at the heart of the Galleria dell‚ÄôAccademia in Florence, about a two-hour train ride from Milan. I stood transfixed, drawn into the intricate details of this renowned sculpture. Florence offered more than its artistic treasures; as I wondered through its enchanting streets, I was greeted by breathtaking views of the Arno river and the red-tiled rooftops that stretched out before me. I indulged in copious amounts of Tuscan bread, each bite a revelation. Renowned for its lack of salt, it seemed to sing with the flavors of the region, a perfect complement to the rich olive oil and robust wines.
Having lived in one of the most prominent fashion capitals of the world, it would come to no surprise that I had made a great deal of friends that are somehow intertwined with the realm of haute couture. My interactions with them made me somewhat of an expert on the topic. Although I do struggle differentiating between cerulean and other shades of blue, I have learnt enough to know that my favorite fashion show is Alexander McQueen‚Äôs Ready-to-Wear Spring ‚Äô98; that Giorgio Armani and Gianni Versace had a heated rivalry throughout the late twentieth century; and that Tom Ford had initially worked at Gucci before starting his eponymous brand.
Although Milan was beautiful in its own right during the day, it was the nights where the lion awakens in its den. A cocktail da asporto in hand listening to L‚Äôappuntamento by the majestic Ornella Vanoni, whilst casually staring at the latest pieces of high fashion embossed in fluorescent light at Via Montenapoleone. Those were the days.
Nestled in the heart of Lombardy, Milan offered a gateway to mountains, lakes, and beaches. This geographical blessing meant that adventures were never far away. During the sun-soaked summers, my best friend and I would embark on journeys to the charming coastal towns of Liguria in his sky blue vintage sedan listening to Italian hits from the ‚Äô80s. The salty breeze mingled with the nostalgia of the music, creating a soundtrack to our youthful escapades. As the seasons shifted and snow dusted the peaks, our attention turned to the Italian Alps. Bundled up in our warmest gear, we‚Äôd venture into the snowy expanse, eager to carve fresh tracks on the slopes. The thrill of skiing down those majestic mountains was unmatched, each run a new adventure waiting to be discovered.
Milan, with its strategic location at the heart of three international airports, was more than just a city; it was a launchpad to adventures far beyond its borders. International travel became a routine part of life. Den Haag to attend my sister‚Äôs birthday dinner? Easy. Frankfurt for my best friend‚Äôs wedding? Just another weekend trip. Athens for a bachelor‚Äôs party? Been there, done that. London to visit my uncle? A frequent flyer. From the cobblestone streets of Den Haag to the vibrant markets of Athens, each destination held its own allure and charm. Yet, no matter how far I traveled, Milan remained my anchor, always welcoming me back with open arms. It wasn‚Äôt just a city; it was the starting point for countless journeys, each one leaving an indelible mark on my soul. And for that, Milan will always hold a special place in my heart.
Navigating the labyrinth of Italian bureaucracy was a trial by fire, one that tested my patience and resolve in ways I never imagined. The infamous Italian red tape was a beast of its own, one that many expats struggled to tame. I was lucky enough to emerge relatively unscathed, but I witnessed the battles of others who weren‚Äôt as fortunate. I quickly learned that trying to fight the system was like banging my head against a brick wall ‚Äî painful and ultimately futile. So, I did what any survivor in Italy does: I adapted. One of my greatest accomplishments was obtaining my driver‚Äôs license in Italy. Months of grappling with specific terminology and enduring compulsory driving lessons, all conducted in Italian, were no small feat. If there is one way to master the art of driving, it is by maneuvering through the narrow streets of Milan while receiving colorful scolding in Italian from your instructor as you deftly dodge a Fiat 500 driven by a formidable nonna.
As my time in Milan drew to a close, I couldn‚Äôt help but feel a pang of sadness at the thought of leaving behind spontaneous adventures. No more day trips to the serene beauty of Lago di Como or the romantic allure of Verona. But as I packed my bags, I knew that the memories of those carefree days exploring the wonders of Il Bel Paese would stay with me forever.
Italy became not just a destination but a journey of self-discovery, marking the beginning of my solo adventures in a foreign land. It was my first taste of independence, a chapter in my life where I learned to stand on my own two feet. I couldn‚Äôt claim to have made it solely on my own. Behind every step I took were the unwavering support and love of my family, friends, and colleagues. Their encouragement and guidance were the pillars that held me up during moments of doubt and uncertainty. Yet, Italy represented more than just a physical location. It was a decade-long odyssey, a tapestry woven with the threads of newfound friendships and unforgettable experiences.
Living away from my family and the friends I grew up with was a challenge, but it was also an opportunity to create a life enriched by the presence of beautiful souls who became like a second family to me. They shared in my triumphs and failures, my joys and sorrows, shaping the person I was becoming. As I reflect on my time in Italy, I realize that it wasn‚Äôt just about navigating a new country; it was about navigating the depths of my own soul. And in doing so, I discovered a strength and resilience I never knew I possessed. This country had taught me a great deal of things. But it is now time to say good-bye.
Arrivederci, Italia. Until we meet again.

Title: Personal Space in Italy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
There is none.
Ok that‚Äôs a lie ‚Äî there‚Äôs some. But honestly, coming from a US upbringing it really means none. The study of ‚Äúpersonal space‚Äù is called Proxemics, ever since 1963 when the cultural anthropologist Edward T. Hall, decided to name it extremely appropriately. Because of his wonderful work, more people have noticed this variation of how close people like to be to other people and studied it. So now we know that in North America, the average ‚Äúappropriate‚Äù distance to be away from another person is literally longer than arms-length away at four feet. Italians, the culture that likes to smoosh their faces together multiple times while greeting, are absolutely fine with two to three feet of distance. I will attest to the fact that city Italians have an even smaller circle that hardly extends past their actual being. If I go into the center, I will absolutely touch other people. This is a given now, and I have accepted it for the most part. Today at the playground in the park, however, I couldn‚Äôt get over how these kids throw themselves around and over each other without a care.
The study continued to agree that ‚ÄúIn Italy, it‚Äôs also common for people to establish extended physical contact when having an exchange. For instance, a person may reach for a friend‚Äôs forearm as a way to communicate openness and honesty or walk arm in arm with a coworker (of any gender) as they discuss something confidential.‚Äù Even when I was younger, I never minded a pat on the arm and thought it nice, so the casual physical interactions that happen here are endearing, and usually come from the older crowd. Older Italians are absolute suckers for babies and puppies and neither is safe from roaming cuddles and kisses. Maybe that‚Äôs why the kids Proxemics numbers are subzero numbers here. I‚Äôm pondering all this today as I watch three boys crawl over each other up the slide and then past Giulio as he was trying to go down it. It‚Äôs madness.
I grew up as one of maybe ten or so kids in our neighborhood that was surrounded by corn fields and woods. We didn‚Äôt have a swing set, but we had acres of land to ourselves. Of course, this mirrors throughout society and culture. In the US,I grew up with houses having backyards, grocery stores had parking lots as big as the piazzas here. Three grocery carts could pass in an aisle at the same time. I could do cartwheels in my bedroom. Here, if I did a cartwheel in any part of my house, I‚Äôd definitely be at the hospital. If I don‚Äôt have to wait for a traffic jam of carts to clear in the grocery store, it‚Äôs a good day. As described, the neighborhood fits about forty-eight (this is like a guess-the-jelly-beans-in-the-jar-number. I honestly have no idea. It‚Äôs a lot.) high-strung children from the ages of months to preteens in the size of a baseball diamond with four swings, and three slides. Of course youre going to get used to having less personal space ‚Äî because there isn‚Äôt much to go around.
You know the little dance you do when someone else is in front of the item you need in the store? That awkward back and forth waiting for them to move? Not here. If someone wants something, they‚Äôll get it. Maybe even move you out of the way a bit to do it. This, once accepted, is actually awesome when you can use it yourself.
Sometimes, it‚Äôs infuriating ‚Äî this closeness. Sometimes, it‚Äôs pretty endearing. It certainly does bring everyone together ‚Äî because we have to. Everyone is in everyone‚Äôs face always. So we learn to deal with each other ‚Äî just like Giulio having no issue with being bowled over as he runs to the slide ‚Äî with a special burst of confetti from the other kids on the way (it‚Äôs Carnevale here so paper confetti is a free-for-all and, again, everyone just accepts it). Of course, I still believe everyone needs a bit of personal space ‚Äî and that that‚Äôs the best way to be. That‚Äôs why we get away every once in a while and have our garden out back. But as I live here longer, my bubble of personal space has gotten smaller, and I think maybe overall it‚Äôs a good thing. It really gets you in touch with the people around you. Ha!
Originally published at lisaharveywriter.com on February 19, 2019.

Title: Between Two Kitchens & Two Homes: A Georgian Family‚Äôs Return From Italy With An Italian Restaurant in Tbilisi
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Samuel Hall Stories is the multimedia blog of Samuel Hall (www.samuelhall.org)

--
Listen
Share
By Natia as told to the Samuel Hall team. Photographs by Tornike Begiashvili
This story was developed as part of Samuel Hall‚Äôs work with the FAiR Consortium, focusing on research conducted in Georgia. The FAiR (Finding Agreement in Return) project aims to improve the governance of return migration in the EU, addressing the challenges of legitimacy in return migration policies and exploring viable alternatives. As a partner in the project, Samuel Hall has been working to identify key public discourses and counter-discourses surrounding immigration, emigration, and (enforced) return, and to understand how these narratives are shaped and embedded in broader public and private conversations within non-EU source and transit countries, as well as diaspora communities. This story has also been published on the FAiR website, where you can read more about the project.
Navigating the complexities of dual identities, I grew up in Italy while maintaining deep roots in Georgian soil. I was born in Georgia, but my family and I relocated to Italy when I was just 3-years-old.
The decision to move came in the aftermath of a deadly conflict. Following the Abkhazian War in 1992, my family fled to Georgia and was facing considerable hardships ‚Äî shuffling between the cities of Marneuli and Tbilisi.
Life was challenging; my father, a chef, earned a meagre salary. Fortunately, his culinary skills caught the attention of an Italian restaurant in Rimini, leading to an invitation to work there. Seizing the opportunity, he relocated our family to Italy in 1996.
We were warmly welcomed. Both of my parents worked at the restaurant, while my siblings and I attended Italian schools from kindergarten through graduation. We spent 21 years in Italy without facing any discrimination, immersed in a community that embraced us.
My parents believed that raising their children abroad would offer better opportunities. However, though our lives were primarily in Italy, my parents never let us forget about Georgia and always talked about, one day, moving back. As much as possible, we tried to maintain our culture ‚Äî my parents would speak to me in Georgian, and I would respond to them in Italian.
As political and security conditions in Georgia improved, we began to return for vacations, reconnecting with our homeland. It enriched my connection to Georgia. We were welcomed by the community whenever we returned because we were always in touch with them. Every time I spent the summer here, I felt so good that I never wanted to go back to Italy.
My parents had always planned on returning and had bought a house. Owning a home in Tbilisi, my father started giving Italian cooking classes for aspiring chefs. Since all restaurants were closed, my father decided to start teaching people of all ages in order to help them find jobs after the pandemic. Our classes attracted numerous students, some of whom are still working as cooks in Georgia, Italy, and the US.
As the pandemic subsided, my father decided to establish deeper roots in Georgia rather than return to Italy. He expressed that he did not want to work for anyone else anymore. Given his love for hosting people and leveraging their special pizza oven, they opened our own restaurant. The community quickly grew to love our establishment.
My father was the best chef of Italian cuisine in Georgia. In the 2000s, you would rarely see an Italian restaurant in Tbilisi. He was a pioneer spreading the love for Italian cuisine in Tbilisi.
Initially, we only expected students to come for takeout. But then, more and more customers started coming in, and expressed their desire to eat at the restaurant rather than taking it home. We had to open additional rooms to accommodate everyone. So we added another section to make the restaurant bigger. We then added another room and put tables outside. Now we can host 90 diners. My father cooks, my mother makes pizzas, and I work as a waitress. We have also hired 10 additional wait staff.
People ask why we do not open another branch. We tell them we want to keep what we have built here, the taste and the food; it‚Äôs so organic. But lately, we have started considering it.
Returning to Georgia was slightly difficult for me because the mentality and lifestyle were very different.
We have a saying in Georgia, ‚ÄúWhere you are going, you have to put on the same hat that they are wearing‚Äù ‚Äî this is what we did in Italy and what we do here in Georgia.
When I returned at 18, I had to start reading and learning the language again. You start as if you are a foreigner.
Our identities are deeply intertwined with the culinary traditions we cherish. My favourite dishes ‚Äî Khinkali from Georgia and pasta from Italy ‚Äî mirror my dual heritage. I could enjoy pasta every day, delighting in a variety of sauces. Typically, weekends were reserved for indulging in pasta, soups, and pizza with friends. Currently, my diet leans more towards European cuisine; I can relish Italian meals several times a day. Georgian food, with its robust flavours, is something I savour less frequently, often opting for a restaurant experience when the craving strikes.
While we still go back to Italy to visit my brother and old friends, as far as the near future is concerned, we plan to stay in Georgia and expand our business operations ‚Äî but Italy is still our second home, and my parents are grateful to Italy. When my father returned from Italy, there were few Italian restaurants in Georgia. He was the first to introduce authentic Italian cuisine here, bringing everything he had learned and observed in Italy to his ‚Äòhomeland‚Äô.
To continue the legacy, I will soon be opening a pizzeria with the help and knowledge of my parents. The pizzeria will be in Tblisi‚Äôs city centre and its name will be Rimini, the place in Italy where I grew up.

Title: Benvenuti, or welcome to sunny Italy!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
‚ÄúCiao, un caff√®, per favore.‚Äù That‚Äôs how every morning started during my last holiday in Italy. Typically, these mornings I spent in small caf√©s, filled with the buzz of loud voices and the clink of espresso cups. These caf√©s made you feel at home with warm sunlight streaming through the glass windows and the fine aroma of coffee delicately wrapping around you. Among tanned locals, you order a tiny espresso cup with a glass of water, just like a typical Italian. Hot, bitter coffee runs through your veins, you place the cup back on the bar counter, put on your sunglasses, and then disappear into the narrow streets‚Ä¶
How did I get there? After an amazing lunch with pizza, my friend and I decided to spend a couple of weeks in Italy, visiting the most iconic cities and eating authentic Italian pizza, something we had always dreamt of doing. After researching, we chose four destinations: Florence, Rome, the Cinque Terre National Park, and Genoa. We booked Airbnb flats, packed small suitcases, and embarked on our greatest adventure to the land of sun, pizza, coffee, and delicious gelato.
An unusually bright and hot sun greeted us when we arrived in Florence. Though we were exhausted from the journey, we decided to take a short walk to the city center. We were staying quite close, on the opposite bank of the Arno river. The weather was perfect for a summer evening: warm, but with a light breeze.
Our first stop was Florence‚Äôs famous cathedral, Santa Maria del Fiore. The construction of this magnificent Renaissance dome began at the end of the 13th century. The vast Gothic structure is striking, with its front decoration showcasing an incredible mix of pink, white, and green marble. Due to circumstances, we couldn‚Äôt go inside, so we peered into the marvelous interior through the open door.
Next, we visited the less famous but charming church, Santa Croce. I have a special connection with this place. As a child, I visited Florence with my mum. Once, in a funny and somewhat scary moment, we nearly got lost and missed our group. We had to rush across the Santa Croce Square to meet our guide. It was our first trip abroad, and we were a little scared of getting lost in a city we‚Äôd never been to before. Fourteen years later, as an adult, I stood in front of that beautiful church, smiling at my childhood memories. I was surprised at how different things looked after so many years. The square in front of the church wasn‚Äôt as huge as I remembered it being as a child.
Then we went to the Roman crossing, the Ponte Vecchio, or Old Bridge. Since the 13th century, there have been shops lining the road across the bridge. In the evening, it becomes full of street musicians and couples. Ponte Vecchio is a very romantic spot in Florence, with its great views over the river and of the bridge itself. We arrived just as the sun was setting, and its pink and brown shops started to gleam gold, reflecting in the calm water. On the other side of the river, there were tiny identical cottages with pollards. Followed by the deep red-purple sunset, we sat down on the dry, rough grass and cooled ourselves with tasty gelato. While enjoying the amazing flavors, two police officers came to warn us about insects in the grass that could bite us. They didn‚Äôt speak English well but heartily tried to convey their message. In the end, they smiled and waved to us before moving on to another group of people.
After two full days in Florence, having walked over 30 kilometers each day, my friend stayed to rest in the city while I decided to visit Siena. What seemed like a casual trip to a nearby city turned into a wonderful adventure. I didn‚Äôt expect anything special and was pleasantly surprised.
Siena is a small city in the heart of the Tuscany region. The first thing I encountered was the Medici Fortress on my way from the railway station to the city center. The massive yellow stone building caught my attention with its high fortress walls. I guessed there might be nice views from the top, and I was right. It was afternoon, and from the top, I saw a magical skyline, a clear blue sky with thin white clouds, and wide verdant hills in shades of green. Then, I entered the old city. Its narrow streets led me into a labyrinth of yellow and red stone buildings that protected me from the hot Tuscan sun. A welcome coolness covered my shoulders and made me shiver a bit. I didn‚Äôt have a map, so I followed the signs on buildings and asked people for directions. The signs led me to the stunning Piazza del Campo, with its massive Palazzo Comunale and Torre del Mangia in the center of the town. The square was full of people, cafes, noise, and street vendors. There wasn‚Äôt enough space for all the tourists. I walked a few steps up from the square and faced the magnificent Duomo, which dominates Siena‚Äôs city center. It wasn‚Äôt as big as Florence‚Äôs Duomo but still very impressive. That day, I returned to the hotel very tired. Going up and down the hills was more exhausting than usual walking.
Rome, where history intertwines with modernity, is a place of contrasts, both noisy and peaceful.
An ancient city with a vast historical heritage, Rome impresses you from the first steps. I‚Äôm not referring to the arrival by train, as the railway station, while not the ugliest or dirtiest I‚Äôve seen, is still somewhat unpleasant. After the relative calm of Florence, Rome overwhelms you with its noise and crowds. Initially, I thought the city itself would be less crowded than the railway station, but I was mistaken. Wherever you go, Rome is packed with people in June.
The district where we found an Airbnb flat was far from the city center and didn‚Äôt seem particularly safe at first glance, with many migrants and poorly dressed individuals. However, it didn‚Äôt feel like a rough part of town, and we didn‚Äôt encounter any problems. So, we left our bags and ran to explore the city.
As I mentioned before, I visited Italy fourteen years ago, including Florence, Rome, and a few small cities. I had dreamt of returning as an adult to not only see and remember everything but to truly experience it. Italy is all about the gesticulating Italians, the smell of pizza and coffee from every corner, enjoying your dinner with pasta and wine in small caf√©s with lovely views, and soaking in the special atmosphere that is unique to this country.
We planned to see the most famous sights like the Colosseum, Trevi Fountain, Spanish Steps, and the Vatican. We marked these spots on the map and decided to walk through the beautiful old streets rather than use public transport. We also didn‚Äôt plan where to eat, leaving it to chance, which added a spontaneous and adventurous spirit to our journey.
Compared to other Italian cities, Rome feels very big and noisy. I suppose it was peak tourist season, so we were a bit unlucky in that regard. Near all the major attractions, you constantly hear street vendors calling out ‚ÄúCold water ‚Äî 1 euro‚Äù or ‚ÄúHat, buy a hat.‚Äù You simply want to enjoy the view and take photos, but it‚Äôs almost impossible due to the crowds and the persistent sellers.
We did a quick loop around the Colosseum, hurried by a strong, sandstorm-like wind. We delved into the labyrinth of streets and found another Roman gem ‚Äî the Trevi Fountain, the largest Baroque fountain in the city and the most famous in the world. Unfortunately, the situation was the same there. The small square was overcrowded with tourists, making it difficult to get close to the fountain. We decided to return early the next morning, hoping it would be less crowded.
The next day, we woke up very early and by 6 a.m., we were already at the Trevi Fountain. The atmosphere was completely different from the previous day. The fresh morning air was much more pleasant than the scorching day heat. There were only a few tourists around, allowing us to enjoy the view. This was the perfect time to walk around the city and appreciate its ancient masterpieces. We had enough time to admire the gorgeous statues and throw a coin for luck into the blue water while the statue of God Oceanus watched us attentively. Bathed in the soft light of sunrise, we moved on to the Spanish Steps.
The Spanish Steps connect the Piazza di Spagna at the base with Piazza Trinit√† dei Monti, dominated by the Trinit√† dei Monti church at the top. The marble steps, polished by thousands of feet, shone in the bright sun. Lazy, yawning tourists began to appear, and we even saw several weddings having photo sessions on the steps.
We continued our walk and arrived at the Quattro Fontane square, an ensemble of four Late Renaissance fountains installed in the 16th century at the intersection of Via delle Quattro Fontane and Via del Quirinale. The morning sun was starting to bring its summer warmth, and we chose the shady side of the road as we headed toward the Vatican.
The Vatican hardly needs an introduction. There‚Äôs plenty of information available in any guidebook, but I advise you to plan your visit carefully. Be aware of Catholic holidays and check the opening hours of St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica.
Standing in front of one of the largest churches in the world, I remembered an episode from my childhood. When I first visited with my mom, it was nearly dark. Yellow lamps cast a warm glow over the square. Our driver, who didn‚Äôt speak English well, tried to tell me something in Italian. Finally, he pointed to the Apostolic Palace and said, ‚ÄúPapa. Roma. Window.‚Äù It was the most memorable moment of that trip. Though I enjoyed the old buildings and their significant history, I couldn‚Äôt fully appreciate them as a child. However, that summer night, standing near the native who proudly showed me the Pope‚Äôs window, I felt something incredible. As an ordinary girl, I was standing just meters from the head of the Catholic Church and the Vatican, whom I‚Äôd only seen on television. It felt almost magical. As an adult, I felt the same childlike wonder when we returned. I showed my friend that window with a warm smile, remembering the Italian driver.
After a busy day of walking, we moved to the most beautiful and colorful area of Rome ‚Äî Trastevere, which feels like a different city. After ancient forums, ruins, and historical sites, there isn‚Äôt as much to see, but the atmosphere is entirely different.
The busy city blurs in the dim sunlight as we step into the Trastevere area. Its narrow cobblestone streets are picturesque, lined with ochre-colored buildings entwined with bushy green plants, arched passageways, and old doorways with antique door knockers. Don‚Äôt miss this atmospheric place. My friend from Rome recommended a caf√© known for its famous pasta ‚Äî tonnarelli. Although there was a long queue for a table, it was worth the wait. The outdoor tables, warm yellow lights, loud emotional Italians, and delicious food created a recipe for small happiness.
We finished our pasta late in the evening and took a walk around the city. It had completely transformed. The day‚Äôs heat had given way to a fresh breeze. Tourists had disappeared from the streets. Bright day colors had faded, replaced by ochre and dark brown hues under the cozy yellow street lamps. Magic was in the air, filling us with complete happiness.
The next day, we left Rome. It will always hold a special place in my heart. Rome is where treasures can be found around every corner, and even the most unassuming streets hold incredible history. You just need to ease your mind and enjoy the city, where history intertwines with reality in a quaint way.
--
--
Marketing manager in reality. Passionate writer and traveler in my soul.

Content:

Sign in

--

by: Isa Arocha
After the problems with my passport finally subsided (not so funny story: it was expired and I had to leave the country to renew it, but couldn‚Äôt leave the country with an expired passport), my family decided it was time to venture out further than our usual trips from northern to southern California and organize our first visit to Europe. The planning process was strenuous as each of us tried to melt our ideas of the perfect adventure together, but looking back I could not be happier with how it played out. One of the most memorable experiences, in fact, was our two-day deviation from the mainstream: Quercianella.
Rather than hitting every crowded tourist destination in Italy, we rented a car in Florence and drove down the Tuscany coast, stopping first at Sienna, and then ending at a miniature beach town by the name of Quercianella.
A town where you could count the number of restaurants on your hands, and every resident was likely on a first-name basis, this was the epitome of an escape. The air smelled of salt and the temperature was perfectly warm. Every one there seemed care-free ‚Äî families walked freely on the sides of the road, shop owners sipped coffee outside, and you could see locals laying on the stretches of rock and beach basking in the sun and purely enjoying the company of friends or a good book.
After driving down the town‚Äôs narrow roads for a while, we found our ‚ÄúVilla Margherita‚Äù and unpacked starved, ready to uncover the local wonders. Being a Yelp-connoisseur, I offered to scour the food scene, but soon realized that Yelp did not carry much weight in this little town. So, we slipped on our sandals and just began to walk. After following the main road for a few minutes, we turned onto a street with a gelateria on the corner, and quickly found a pizzeria nearby.
We sat outside on a string-lit patio and soon began speaking with the waiter, who also happened to be the owner‚Äôs son. In contrast to the people working the service desk at the hotel, with whom we had to communicate through vague hand gestures, he spoke a great amount of English. It was a comforting revelation, since the town probably did not get many tourists coming from the US. So, taking advantage, my dad asked for dish recommendations. He told us to get a pizza each, as they were personal-sized and he could easily finish one or two. We probably should have known that his idea of personal would differ than ours, however, and when he brought them to the table, all my sister said was ‚Äúit‚Äôs almost bigger than me!‚Äù I wasn‚Äôt complaining though; we ended up taking the leftovers for a late-night snack.
At the end of our delicious meal, we were greeted by another unexpected surprise. We began talking to the owner and his son about where we were from (Palo Alto, California), and the son‚Äôs face suddenly lit up. It turned out he had lived a couple miles away from us for ten years while working his past job, after which he decided to take some time to move back home and work with his father. Our meal then turned into a night of laughs and good conversation as we exchanged stories of California and got to know the family of the pizzeria.
Even in a seemingly random beach town, we found a connection to our home thousands of miles away. The unexpected link was a reminder that we live in a minuscule world where the owner of a pizza place you happen to stumble on in Tuscany could very well have once been your neighbor.
About the Writer: Isa Arocha is a freshman from Palo Alto, California still currently deciding what on her major in Arts & Sciences. She loves learning about different cultures and trying new foods (as long as they‚Äôre vegetarian). One of her favorite cities is Barcelona as it combines her love for all these things and also has a beach.
About Guac: Guac is an award-winning travel publication run by an interdisciplinary group of students at Cornell University. We aim to inspire our readers to celebrate cultural diversity and view the world with an open mind through delivering unique stories from people around the world.

Back in Autumn 2023, during a month in Puglia, I suddenly felt I‚Äôd spent enough time eating focaccia in Bari, and decided to visit the coast of Salento, specifically a charming beachside town called Gallipoli. Next to it on my tray table, I had a tiny baguette, given to me free at La Pani√®re, just outside the March√©. Thankfully, the bistro on board offered wooden cutlery so that I could cut the rind.
I was even more grateful that the bistro sold a crisp Pays d‚ÄôOc chardonnay to accompany my 11 am snack.

Title: Drop everything, go to Italy, sing‚Ä¶
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
GOSPEL songs ‚Äî earworms! ‚Äî play in my head constantly now after two intense weeks of learning them with a choir touring Tuscany. We weren‚Äôt a choir before we boarded our respective flights, but we are a choir now.
And right now I can ‚Äòhear‚Äô a very beautiful Italian prayer-song, Signore Delle Cime ‚Äî Lord of the [mountain] Peaks ‚Äî in my mind and I, a non-believer, am nevertheless deeply moved. Who wouldn‚Äôt be?
Signore Delle Cime asks the Lord to take ‚Äòour friend‚Äô, a fallen mountaineer, up to heaven covered ‚Äòwith a soft white blanket‚Äô. It soars.
Then there was Bella Ciao, the rousing hymn of the partisans who would die for la liberta. It seems all Italians know that one.
The 30 singers in our choir are mostly Australian and we also have a sassy soprano from Canada who lives in New Zealand, three terrific tenors (Scotland, Canada and New Zealand), and an Irish lass, our scintillating soloist and queen of the altos, who lives in Melbourne.
We learned songs, mostly gospel in nature, in Italian, French, Samoan, Zulu (yes!) and English. And we performed a selection of them in two churches, one in the gentle medieval town of Mercatello sul Metauro in the Marche region that borders Tuscany, and another in Firenze. (The angelic altos are pictured above.)
Our maestros were exceptional talents ‚Äî Guerrino Parri in Mercatello, Edoardo Materassi who taught us in the first week of our tour in Montestigliano, near Siena, and in Firenze, and Tony Backhouse, who taught us for the entire two weeks. Many readers will know Tony from his acclaimed Sydney-based choir, the Caf√© at the Gates of Salvation Gospel Choir, as well as his Heavenly Light Quartet. That‚Äôs him, below, with Guerrino in the background getting ready to begin.
Each of these three conductors was a joy to watch at work. So knowledgeable ‚Äî so animated! ‚Äî and able to sing each part (bass, tenor, soprano, alto), they lifted us up with their energetic love of the music and of teaching it. What a joy.
Members of Guerrino‚Äôs choir in Mercatello joined us for our concert there, and in Firenze we were treated to exceptional performances by Edoardo‚Äôs choir, Animae Voces, who also joined us for some tunes.
Now I am in Anghiari, ‚Äòmy‚Äô beloved medieval village near Arezzo, very happy to be here again so unexpectedly soon, thanks to one person dropping out of the singing tour before it began. [I spent last November and December here.] ‚ÄòMaking Music in Italy‚Äô, organised by a Byron Bay-based outfit, The Create Escape, had been fully booked when I inquired about it months before. When I tossed my cap in, I assumed it unlikely that a spot would become available ‚Äî but it did! So, with just four weeks to get myself prepared ‚Äî flights, insurance, what to do after the tour, and so on ‚Äî I said yes. Life is short, yes?
I have always eschewed the idea of group tours, but now I am very glad I took what felt like a leap of faith and dived in. The accommodation in Montestigliano, Mercatello and then Firenze was excellent and interesting in different ways; we ate sumptuous meals, had some lovely parties and stimulating side trips as well as the pleasure of learning. (You can see a snippet of one of those parties here.)
One of the side trips was to the hilltop restaurant Il Girone dei Golosi just out of Mercatello; another was to the beautiful organic winery Pomaio near the town of Arezzo where we went for lunch on the way to Firenze (see pics below).
I‚Äôm sure we all made some lovely new friends. (And here I must make special mention of Susie and David from the Northern Rivers who had the brilliant idea of making this tour the first leg of their honeymoon! It was a treat for all of us to have them along.)
Now I‚Äôve seen more of Tuscany than I had before. It is my fifth time visiting Anghiari and I‚Äôve opted to spend a month here to catch up with acquaintances I have come to know and love. After all, the airfare is just the same for six weeks as for two, isn‚Äôt it?
A presto. Mimi :)
PS: If you would like to see the choir in action, some parts of our concerts can be found on YouTube. Go to ‚ÄòMaking Music in Italy, 2024‚Äô. You‚Äôre welcome. xx
