Title: Drop everything, go to Italy, sing‚Ä¶
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
GOSPEL songs ‚Äî earworms! ‚Äî play in my head constantly now after two intense weeks of learning them with a choir touring Tuscany. We weren‚Äôt a choir before we boarded our respective flights, but we are a choir now.
And right now I can ‚Äòhear‚Äô a very beautiful Italian prayer-song, Signore Delle Cime ‚Äî Lord of the [mountain] Peaks ‚Äî in my mind and I, a non-believer, am nevertheless deeply moved. Who wouldn‚Äôt be?
Signore Delle Cime asks the Lord to take ‚Äòour friend‚Äô, a fallen mountaineer, up to heaven covered ‚Äòwith a soft white blanket‚Äô. It soars.
Then there was Bella Ciao, the rousing hymn of the partisans who would die for la liberta. It seems all Italians know that one.
The 30 singers in our choir are mostly Australian and we also have a sassy soprano from Canada who lives in New Zealand, three terrific tenors (Scotland, Canada and New Zealand), and an Irish lass, our scintillating soloist and queen of the altos, who lives in Melbourne.
We learned songs, mostly gospel in nature, in Italian, French, Samoan, Zulu (yes!) and English. And we performed a selection of them in two churches, one in the gentle medieval town of Mercatello sul Metauro in the Marche region that borders Tuscany, and another in Firenze. (The angelic altos are pictured above.)
Our maestros were exceptional talents ‚Äî Guerrino Parri in Mercatello, Edoardo Materassi who taught us in the first week of our tour in Montestigliano, near Siena, and in Firenze, and Tony Backhouse, who taught us for the entire two weeks. Many readers will know Tony from his acclaimed Sydney-based choir, the Caf√© at the Gates of Salvation Gospel Choir, as well as his Heavenly Light Quartet. That‚Äôs him, below, with Guerrino in the background getting ready to begin.
Each of these three conductors was a joy to watch at work. So knowledgeable ‚Äî so animated! ‚Äî and able to sing each part (bass, tenor, soprano, alto), they lifted us up with their energetic love of the music and of teaching it. What a joy.
Members of Guerrino‚Äôs choir in Mercatello joined us for our concert there, and in Firenze we were treated to exceptional performances by Edoardo‚Äôs choir, Animae Voces, who also joined us for some tunes.
Now I am in Anghiari, ‚Äòmy‚Äô beloved medieval village near Arezzo, very happy to be here again so unexpectedly soon, thanks to one person dropping out of the singing tour before it began. [I spent last November and December here.] ‚ÄòMaking Music in Italy‚Äô, organised by a Byron Bay-based outfit, The Create Escape, had been fully booked when I inquired about it months before. When I tossed my cap in, I assumed it unlikely that a spot would become available ‚Äî but it did! So, with just four weeks to get myself prepared ‚Äî flights, insurance, what to do after the tour, and so on ‚Äî I said yes. Life is short, yes?
I have always eschewed the idea of group tours, but now I am very glad I took what felt like a leap of faith and dived in. The accommodation in Montestigliano, Mercatello and then Firenze was excellent and interesting in different ways; we ate sumptuous meals, had some lovely parties and stimulating side trips as well as the pleasure of learning. (You can see a snippet of one of those parties here.)
One of the side trips was to the hilltop restaurant Il Girone dei Golosi just out of Mercatello; another was to the beautiful organic winery Pomaio near the town of Arezzo where we went for lunch on the way to Firenze (see pics below).
I‚Äôm sure we all made some lovely new friends. (And here I must make special mention of Susie and David from the Northern Rivers who had the brilliant idea of making this tour the first leg of their honeymoon! It was a treat for all of us to have them along.)
Now I‚Äôve seen more of Tuscany than I had before. It is my fifth time visiting Anghiari and I‚Äôve opted to spend a month here to catch up with acquaintances I have come to know and love. After all, the airfare is just the same for six weeks as for two, isn‚Äôt it?
A presto. Mimi :)
PS: If you would like to see the choir in action, some parts of our concerts can be found on YouTube. Go to ‚ÄòMaking Music in Italy, 2024‚Äô. You‚Äôre welcome. xx

Title: I spontaneously moved to Italy to build a family home √†nd a business sanctuary
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
It was June 2023 when I drove to Italy for 3 weeks to find a second house or a renovation project in Italy. I had sold my house in the Netherlands as I felt it was time to move forward without any mortgage. Freedom.
Initially I was focussed on moving to Spain. My boyfriend‚Äôs native language is Spanish, and learning Spanish is already a challenge. Putting another language in the mix like Italian, didn‚Äôt feel very useful. Long story short, I couldn‚Äôt get a homy feeling in Spain, and I always loved and felt connected with Italy. Italy it was.
Like many house searchers, Idealista is a great way to start. With a long list of 50+ houses I drove to my preferred area around Lucca and further up the coast in Liguria. Obviously many houses weren‚Äôt at all what they seemed online, but more, I couldn‚Äôt see myself living in those areas. Secondly, I was all over the place with what I was looking for: a nice holiday home or a golden gem like a big mansion to renovate.
Having one week left, I went back to the heart of Piemonte where I had spent the first 2 nights. I ended up in a B&B owned and run by Francesca. We clicked and I loved the area: the rolling soft hills with its vineyards, the laid back little villages with one bar in the center as the communal place to meet each other for coffee or an aperitivo.
I visited some more houses in the area but nothing came even close to making my heart jump a tiny bit with excitement. This is not the right way, I felt. Let‚Äôs reverse the process: stop hunting, trust that life will show me what or where to look next. As a side note, I always bought the houses I lived in very intuitively, which has never let me down. In fact, it has given me a lot of financial expansion over the years.
I just posted my ‚ÄòI trust the universe‚Äô post on facebook when the cousin of Francesca stepped into the garden. 10 minutes later, he offered to show me his house down the road that he bought a year ago. Would I be interested to buy his house as his plans had changed?
Is this a sign? Curious as I am, I said that I would be open to explore. It wasn‚Äôt love at first sight. It wasn‚Äôt the Liberty House from early 20th century with heigh painted ceilings I was hoping to find, but it was huge! And that ignited my interior design excitement. I love a good renovation challenge! I have had my design business for 13 years, and although I never see myself in that role again, I love to be my own client!
3 Months later I signed the contract, and became resident in one day. The house, with a potential of 600m2 living space and 14000 m2 land, was mine. Definitely a design challenge as 40% of the house, the barn with its hay attic, needs a complete transformation. For Italian standards the whole process went very smoothly, mainly due to great help I received from the seller!
Why did I say yes? It just felt like the one thing to do. Not just buying it, but to move out of the Netherlands immediately and start something new. It all felt right: the potential of the house with 7‚Äì8 bedrooms and the potential for an equal number of bathrooms, living spaces to share and some to keep private, enough space for my children to come and stay, alone or with their friends and the idea of creating a business sanctuary, whatever that will be‚Ä¶I felt a new phase opened up. How exciting!
Back to the summer of 2023. My partner wasn‚Äôt as thrilled as I was when I showed him the house the first time. Understandable! His favourite spot to visit, the Netherlands, was suddenly swapped for a rural area with a bunch of farmers. Having a long distance relationship for 6 years now, travelling between Lima-Peru and The Netherlands very frequently, has worked well for us, but will it be the same with my drastic move?
While I didn‚Äôt really involve my partner in the decision, I did involve my 3 (young adult) children! Perhaps not realising the complete impact of this move, they were supportive of my choice. I feel blessed with their ability to give me this space although it certainly hasn‚Äôt always been easy for them for different reasons.
So here I am, 14 months later. A year of learning and rooting. Slowly learning the language. Connecting with the ground I live on. Making the house with simple means a home for now until the renovation is done. Enjoying the simplicity of life in the country. Meeting so many beautiful new people, of which a few are becoming good friends.
And of course, not everything goes easy and smoothly. My renovation started with a classic mistake, trusting the wrong person and ignoring my inner doubt as I was too eager to get started. It has cost me quite a sum of money with which I had come to terms with for myself. I felt so angry and frustrated but also a bit ashamed with my mistake. Shouldn‚Äôt I know better as an experienced renovator and intuitive person?
I stopped working with the first contractor, continued with his collaborating partner (as he was a victim of the whole situation as well) to finish the terraces and new swimming pool. Normally one starts with the house and the outer areas are last on the list. For sure it will turn out quite unpractical to have a new terrace while the whole house needs to be taken care of, but I am so happy I enjoyed a first summer with a lovely space outside and my beautiful new swimming pool. At least the pool can‚Äôt fall of the budget anymore! A lovely first summer, sharing it all with friends, family, and of course my children.
While I moved on my own to a country where I didn‚Äôt know anyone, I can‚Äôt say I ever felt alone or lonely. In fact, in between all the visits, and my own travelling to the Netherlands, Peru and some other places, I am happy to have some weeks on my own. I love the different seasons: fresh sunny spring, warm rain free summer, foggy autumn mornings and cold winters with the snowy mountains of the Alps as a postcard view from my terrace.
And the house? For a while I didn‚Äôt want to renovate it at all. I live so comfortably already, and I have enough rooms for guests to stay. My youngest spontaneously brought 7 friends for a week around New Years Eve. My son enjoyed a week in the summer with 6 of his friends! And you know, sharing 2 bathrooms and 4 bedrooms worked fine for everyone.
But after a few months, I felt the excitement bubbling up for the next phase of the renovation. I refreshed my skills so I could use my design software again. It had been a while but I really loved solving this big puzzle. How to make the best out of the house. This part had always been my favourite element of my interior business: creating the most optimal living spaces, a natural flow, all within the limits of the building and a budget. To me it is the definition of simplicity: creating such a design that solves all complexity (integrate all wishes affordably, elegantly, beautifully and within the limited space) while the results looks very natural like the house has always meant to be like that. In other words, I don‚Äôt like over designed houses for the sake of creating something new and expensive.
The house had grown on me, which made me change some of my initial ideas. I finalised the complete design in September. Now what? How to find the right contractor(s) this time? One that is flexible to find affordable and beautiful solutions: my budget is limited and my standard is high! But more importantly, finding one who is willing to work differently from the very bureaucratic way that is known in Italy and very costly in my view.
I did hire a geometra. A geometra works within the triangle of the municipality, the contractor and the house owner. A geometra can easily take 15‚Äì20% of the budget as an add on! That is excluding the costs for an architect, an interior designer and an engineer (for constructive calculations). I decided to hire my geometra only for the permit, the (ridiculous but mandatory) safety and security rules and some engineering guidance. I followed the same process as I did in the Netherlands for many years to receive budget proposals from 4 contractors. Well, that already made a pre-selection. Two of them resigned as they didn‚Äôt like my way. They would only give a quote based on the standard procedure here where the geometra prepares the whole costing format. Basically this means, they only have to fill in the price per item and you get a very clear overview per contractor what his offering is. Sounds great and good for comparing budgets, but quite costly for me and way less flexible.
Now I am left with 2 parties who both feel like good companies to work with. One of them is very eager to grow his business and the other has an established contracting business. I haven‚Äôt finalised the deals yet, but it feels like the project will be divided amongst these 2 parties.
I am excited to get started, to work with the workers wherever I can, find solutions and the right materials. I am best when I can design the little details in the moment.
Please follow along in this blog to read about my weekly updates, surprises, joys, fun facts and challenges as I navigate this BIG project!

We had promised our son that we would take him to Italy, especially since we named him after our memorable trip to the country over a decade ago. (You can also read this article on my travel blog ‚Äî GracefulTrips.com)
Upon arriving in Rome, we took the train to Florence, using it as our base for exploring nearby cities such as Siena, San Gimignano, and Pisa. We also took some time to explore Florence, known as the capital of artists. Afterward, we took the train back to Rome and visited all the famous historical sites before flying back home.
This article will list the cities we visited, not necessarily in chronological order.
We signed up for a walking tour, the best way to learn about this area. The guide showed us what all the buildings used to be and the stories behind them.

Title: ‚ÄòNavola‚Äô: A Powerful Dragon‚Äôs Eye in Renaissance Italy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The (Counter)Cultural One-Stop for Nonfiction on Medium‚Ä¶ incorporating categories for: ‚ÄòArt‚Äô, ‚ÄòCulture‚Äô, ‚ÄòEquality‚Äô, ‚ÄòPhotography‚Äô, ‚ÄòFilm‚Äô, ‚ÄòMental Health‚Äô, ‚ÄòMusic‚Äô and ‚ÄòLiterature‚Äô.

--
Listen
Share
Out my window in New York I can see a tall white slice of a building where the Russian diplomatic corps lives. In that contained compound, there‚Äôs also a long, low building with a big round window, a school for their children. What are the mindsets of people there ‚Äî especially when they see protesters waving the Ukraine flag across the street? What kind of history lessons do they teach those kids?
I mention this curious, closed-off world because it‚Äôs the kind of environment that can send fiction writers down long trails of exploration. And if all their research and imaginings lead to a vivid, unusual tale, readers may scratch their heads and wonder how the heck the writer came up with it.
When I read a new novel by Paolo Bacigalupi, Navola, I did some of that proverbial head scratching. It‚Äôs set in an alternative version of Renaissance Italy, filled with deception, vast wealth, and cut-throat power plays. So many questions surfaced in my mind, which led to some unexpected discoveries.
Before getting into that, here‚Äôs a little bit about Bacigalupi and the novel. If you‚Äôre a sci-fi fan, you might have gone head-over-heels for his first published novel, The Windup Girl, which picked up two of the most prized awards in the genre, a Hugo and a Nebula, along with other honors. Maybe you read some of his work that came after that ‚Äî until he disappeared from the literary scene. Then last year, he rose up once again with Navola.
This marks the first time that Bacigalupi has dived into the fantasy genre. He sidestepped many of the usual suspects ‚Äî magic spells, knights, princesses, witches, elves. But he did dust off the old dragon trope and gave it a strange quality. We first learn about it in the book‚Äôs opening paragraph, which begins:
‚ÄúMy father kept a dragon eye upon his desk. An orb larger than a man‚Äôs skull, gone milky and crystalline but still burning with inner fire as if it retained life.‚Äù
MISFIT IN A POWERFUL FAMILY
The narrator is a boy, and later a young man, born into a banking family. The young scion, Davico, may be extraordinarily wealthy, but he can‚Äôt meet the huge expectations of the father he so reveres. Davico is educated in warfare and how to perceive the dark secrets that are rife in Navola, the city-state where he lives. He pushes himself to become a master negotiator and to achieve far-reaching knowledge about all the bank‚Äôs clients. But he seems to always fall short. His passions and natural gifts lie elsewhere.
One of his gifts has to do with that dragon‚Äôs eye. The relic isn‚Äôt mentioned very frequently and seems inert to everyone but Davico, who senses its pent-up power. It seems like it‚Äôs going to do something. But what? I read much later into the night than I should have, wondering about that.
Another reason for my sleep deprivation had to do with a character named Celia. She arrives just after Davico‚Äôs father wreaks revenge against her family, which had plotted to overthrow his power. The father decides to adopt Celia, giving Davico an unexpected sister. It makes for an awkward introduction.
Over the course of the novel, Celia transforms from a subdued, quiet girl into a vivacious wit who is able to navigate through the treacherous, opulent world much more easily than Davico.
A third reason why I couldn‚Äôt stop reading relates to Bacigalupi‚Äôs master skills of foreshadowing, teasing the reader about what‚Äôs to come without giving much away. Consider the confessional tone of Davico in this passage, which is addressed to his readers:
‚ÄúI have lost interest in hiding who I was or what I have become. I am tired of the lies and excuses, and wish only to lay myself bare before you, so that you at least will understand, even if you do not forgive.‚Äù
In addition to all my curiosity about where the book was headed, I also started to wonder about Bacigalupi‚Äôs inspirations and how the book had come about. It was so different than what I‚Äôd read of his other work.
It wasn‚Äôt hard to discern that novel‚Äôs world was some ancient version of Italy. Bacigalupi also invented certain words, gestures and body markings that seemed to borrow from Italian culture. But where was that all coming from? With a name like Paolo Bacigalupi, I assumed that he had an Italian family history. I was wrong.
My research uncovered an unexpected set of circumstances. Navola‚Äôs storyline came to him at a time when he was no longer interested in exploring the sci-fi topics he‚Äôd become known for, like changes in the world due to extreme weather and bioengineering.
‚ÄòNERVOUS BREAKDOWN,‚Äô NEW AVENUE
He explained his mindset in a Write-Minded podcast interview: ‚ÄúA lot of the [future] trends that my brain locks onto are the frightening ones. And so you end up spending time being sort of anxious in your daily life. And then you go into this creative space where you actually expand on those anxieties and go deeper and deeper into them. And it builds this sort of, I don‚Äôt know, synergistic toxicity. And eventually I just broke down, fundamentally. I kind of had a nervous breakdown.‚Äù
A new way forward gained momentum during a trip to Italy with a friend, who wanted to learn Italian by living in Bologna. Bacigalupi had gone along for the ride. But it turned into so much more than that. Italian architecture and history proved fertile ground for his imagination, and that‚Äôs so evident in Navola‚Äôs landscape.
‚ÄúOne of the things about Bologna was all these rival families in the city would build these towers, and they were defensive towers for their families, but they were also statements of wealth and importance,‚Äù he told Locus magazine in a December 2024 article.
‚ÄúThe landscape is telling you something about politics, saying, ‚ÄòOh, this city is not a cohesive political unit, even though you‚Äôve got a wall that goes around the whole city ‚Äî inside it, there are armed factions who war with each other, and retreat into their towers when they‚Äôre unsafe, then come out and attack each other. They‚Äôd imprison one another in their towers, all sorts of stuff. You can see this layer of anarchy clearly established in the architecture, and that‚Äôs not something that I would have organically thought of, but it‚Äôs something that I could observe and then steal and bring into my own world.‚Äù
There was at least one unexplored story thread in Navola that I kept waiting to play out as the pages turned. And while it never did, I suspect it was a little hint about what‚Äôs to come. At the time he was interviewed by Locus, Bacigalupi had written 60,000 to 80,000 words of a sequel book. As with Navola, it will be published by Knopf.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to let the story be as long as it wants to be. If I need to go back to Knopf and offer another book, I‚Äôll do that. If I can wrap it up elegantly in two, I‚Äôll do that,‚Äù he said at that time. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying to be as loose as I can with it and allow the thing to take on the shape that it wants.‚Äù
With or without that dragon‚Äôs eye, I‚Äôll be waiting.

Title: ‚ÄúThere will never be a place in Italy that you won‚Äôt find beauty.‚Äù
Content:

That‚Äôs what a friend told me before I went to my next travel destination, and she was right. It was summer in England, but it did not feel like it (knowing English weather ‚ò∫), so a quick summer getaway to Lake Como seemed like a good idea. And mind you, Italy never disappoints.
For my first photo blog, I would like to share my experience of my recent trip to Lake Como. Lake Como, or Lago di Como in Italian, is located in the Lombardy region in the northern part of Italy. It is surrounded by different towns, and visually, it looks like an inverted Y when you look at it on the map. Popular for its beautiful waters, majestic grand villas and gorgeous Italian towns, it has always been a favourite summer destination for locals and tourists around the world.
There are several towns surrounding the lake, and the most popular ones are Varenna, Bellagio, Menaggio and Como. For this trip I decided to stay in Varenna for its strategic location and more peaceful scenery compared to other major towns. I stayed in Lake Como for 4 days. I know it might not be long enough because there are still lots to see and explore.
How I got there:
I travelled from London Heathrow to Milan Malpensa airport since the nearest and most convenient airport to reach Lake Como. After landing in Milan, it took fifty minutes to an hour via train from Milan Centrale to reach Varenna. You can buy your train tickets from the airport or by using the Trenitalia app on your mobile phone. My advice is to book your tickets via the app in advance because train tickets might be difficult to book, especially during peak seasons. Trains usually depart every hour, and a one-way ticket costs me 11 euros for a first-class seat. To be honest, I‚Äôm not sure if it was too hot in Italy at that time, that the temperature in the train was too warm as well. Nonetheless, it was a pleasant journey overall.
Where I stayed:
I decided to stay in the town of Varenna in the eastern part of the Lake. My stay in the town was pleasant and calm, probably because of the smaller crowd since there were fewer restaurants and establishments in the area. There were different accommodations to choose from, ranging from high-cost hotels to cheaper, but still comfy ones. Just a quick warning, though, there were several areas in Italy where air conditioning in hotel buildings was regulated at specific times of the year. Be sure to do your research before choosing your accommodation. My hotel was a 5-minute walk from Varenna Train Station, which was also a big plus for me.
What I did:
There were several exciting activities that you can do in Lake Como. It ranges from walking tours, visiting Italian architectures on each town, visiting beautiful villas via boat tours, dipping into the lake and many more.
First Stop
After checking in the hotel, I went straight to a pre-booked tour of two of the most beautiful Villas in Varenna, Villa Monastero and Hotel Villa Cipressi. Roaming around Villa Monastero, you can see the attractive garden and the majestic view of Lake Como. The view of the lake was so stunning, and I‚Äôm sure you will be amazed too. It‚Äôs one reason why many movies were filmed here, like Oceans Twelve, Casino Royale and Star Wars Episode II: Attack of the Clones.
I went straight to Hotel Villa Cipressi and enjoyed the view of the garden and the lake while sipping Aperol Spritz and eating Italian panini! Truly Dolce Vita! The Villa is part of a hotel that has a restaurant and bar open to both guests and non-guests. There were so many Instagrammable spots in both villas, and I recommend that you visit them.
After visiting the villas, I explored Varenna on foot to see what this town has to offer. I went to the town centre and there were couple of restaurants along the lake shore. The place was a bit crowded since it was summertime but still manage to roam around and find amazing spots, fancy restaurants and local stores.
The lake view was so serene especially during golden hours. It was so pristine and calming for the senses and worth capturing on your camera lenses.
As I walked back to my hotel, I saw group of people enjoying the sun and having a dip in the lake. I should have brought my swimming trunks and sunscreen with me ha-ha.
I ended up the day having authentic Italian pizza and a glass, uhm okay glasses of red wine ha-ha.
There will be more stories to come in the second part of my Lake Como journey. Hope you enjoyed this short blog and can‚Äôt wait to share the rest in the next part! Thanks for reading!

‚ÄúLet them eat chocolate,‚Äù was the kind proclamation of Madama Reale.
The year was 1678. Madama Reale was thirty years old, widowed, with a boy to raise, and had become the ruler of the Piedmont region in northern Italy. She took her job seriously and carried on major beautiful changes to the city during her reign , continuing in the tradition her husband had began, remodeling the Palazzo Madama into pretty French style.
In Madama Reale‚Äôs day chocolate was a precious novelty served only to royalty and priests. It had come to Italy through the Spanish explorer Cortez, who found it in South America.
When a Turin baker asked Madame Reale‚Äôs permission to make chocolate for regular folk, I imagine she figured, ‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù She probably needed the seritonin fix to deal with the hassles of being a female ruler and wanted to pass on the high to keep her popularity ratings up.

Content:

Or how a Balinese priest told me who I would marry
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a wonderful old Italian joke about a poor man who goes to church every day and prays before the statue of a great saint, begging, ‚ÄòDear saint ‚Äî please, please, please‚Ä¶ give me the grace to win the lottery.‚Äô This lament goes on for months. Finally the exasperated statue comes to life, looks down at the begging man and says in weary disgust, ‚ÄòMy son ‚Äî please, please, please‚Ä¶ buy a ticket.‚Äù
That profound realisation is from the blockbuster book Eat Pray Love. In the iconic movie scene, Julia Roberts says these words while overlooking ancient Rome. I have seen this film time and again, but I didn‚Äôt realise it until last year ‚Äî did I just relive Eat Pray Love itself?
Dear saint, I did buy three tickets years apart‚Ä¶ to Italy, India and Bali‚Ä¶ and my lottery is a prophecy.
Italia‚Ä¶ amore a prima vista! I was a teenager on my birthday when I first set foot in Italy. The fact that I don‚Äôt recollect the exact year is evidence that I speak of time long passed. It was a high school trip and my highlight was Casa di Giulietta (or Juliet‚Äôs house) in Verona. I revive the memory of a line of people flocking to this medieval tiny courtyard with one wish in mind ‚Äî to find true love. Standing before the statue of Juliet, supposedly where Romeo wooed her, I was observing how everybody was writing their names on a wall, followed by symbols and dates important for them, as well as the name of their crush, husband or partner.
And then there was me. I found myself in front of the wall with a pen in my hand. I wrote ‚Äò‚ÄôMila‚Äô‚Äô followed by a tiny doodle of a heart. And then I looked up to the sky and set out the following intention ‚Äò‚ÄôI left the space next to my name empty. Let whoever is meant to be with me, write their name next to mine. And let the universe do its magic and introduce me to that person in divine timing.‚Äô‚Äô Something inside of me as a young girl told me that I was probably the only one who did that.
But the woman in me today knows who wrote their name next to mine.
Namaste, India! It was my 21st birthday. The land of contrast. The thing about India is that you either love it or you never want to go back. I fall in the first category. I call to mind entering a Hindu temple for the first time in my life. ‚Äò‚ÄôNo phones allowed‚Äô‚Äô ‚Äî it said on a very high fence. As a 21-year-old just entering the era of Instagram this is the last thing you want to hear. ‚Äò‚ÄôWell, I don‚Äôt have a choice‚Äô‚Äô ‚Äî I said to myself while proceeding to entering the temple. If you have been to India, you know that New Delhi is chaotic. Yet, somehow this Hindu temple was the trailer to how tranquillity feels like in the hustle and bustle of the big city.
The only time before that I was in awe of a building was in Barcelona when I entered La Sagrada Fam√≠lia. But Akshardham Temple in Delhi was something magical. This was the exact moment when I fell in love with India, Hinduism and Asia. I stood in front of the central sanctum and in a trice I couldn‚Äôt see anyone else. It was just me and this massive gold statue before me. The entire world went still. It was a fleeting moment, but it was something that I couldn‚Äôt explain to myself. What I know for sure, though, is that if I had my phone with me I wouldn‚Äôt have had this memory.
Om Swastiastu, Bali! I had to go back to Asia. The older you grow, the more life pushes you to search for peace, meaning and answers. ‚Äò‚ÄôOm Swastiastu, Miss Mila, my name is Ketut, nice to meet you.‚Äô‚Äô No way. Did he say Ketut? I just rewatched the movie Eat Pray Love (which is by the way based on a true story) on my flight to Bali and if you have seen it, you know who Ketut is in the story. To make the picture even more unbelievable, Ketut that stood before me is a local priest in Ubud.
One morning, before inviting me to a Balinese family celebration that happens only once every 30 years, we had a talk about life. I shared that I wanted to visit a local palm reader. Sometimes when you‚Äôre desperate, you look for answers from places you never thought you would run to. ‚Äò‚ÄôI do‚Äô‚Äô ‚Äî he said, ‚Äò‚Äôbut you don‚Äôt have time for this today‚Ä¶ have you visited The Pyramids of Chi? I think you should go‚Äô‚Äô ‚Äî said Ketut, accompanied by a witty smile, as if he almost knew what would happen there.
Like I wrote in another article, the gods always travel incognito. Ketut was convincing in an almost demanding way, leaving me with no choice but to go to those pyramids. I went to the reception and asked for a ticket for the first session available. I had no idea what I was getting myself into. I was in a pyramid built on top of a rice field, about to meditate to the sound of a gong. And let me tell you ‚Äî I was the type of person that could never do yoga or meditate.
I still find it hard to put into words what happened to me that morning. I started having visions, one of which was a very specific necklace with a lotus flower. Once the session was over and it almost felt like I just woke up for the first time in my life, my legs took me to the giftshop. And guess what ‚Äî that exact necklace I saw in my meditation was sold at their shop! I got goosebumps. A receptionist approached me and said to me ‚Äò‚ÄôMiss, this is the last necklace.‚Äô‚Äô Nothing is a coincidence and signs do exist.
A year later, fate took me to Bali again, despite planning to go to Thailand instead. I had to go back to those pyramids again. I needed more answers. It was not an easy task to revisit a place without the burden of the expectations from the first time. However, I told myself that if those visions are a reality and not just my mind playing tricks on me, I must see the number 17 immediately when I leave the pyramid.
The sound healing was done. I ran to grab a piece of my favourite peanut butter chocolate cake and drink a comforting cup of ceremonial cacao. The woman at the counter handed me a note with a number and told me to put it on the table so they know where to bring my order. I grabbed it without looking and started playing with a frangipani flower that fell next to me. I sat down, a waiter brought my cake and to my astonishment I looked up ‚Äî the table number I was given was‚Ä¶ 17. And next to the cake the word ‚Äò‚Äôlove‚Äô‚Äô was written with strawberry jam.
Then I went back to my homestay and Ketut asked me the mandatory question of how my day was. How do I tell this man that he sent me to a place that changed my life? I was looking for a palm reader, but I ended up being my own palm reader. What really made my jaw dropped was what Ketut asked me. ‚Äò‚ÄôMila, do you have a partner?‚Äô‚Äô and before I could even respond he continued ‚Äî ‚Äò‚ÄôYou have already met him, I saw him‚Äô‚Äô and then with that same smile he gave me last year, he walked away and wished me good night. He saw him? What did he mean?
I don‚Äôt really have an ending for this story. An ending would imply that a cycle is completed. Yet, why does it feel like this cliffhanger by a Balinese priest is just the beginning? Or maybe I myself started this prophecy by writing my name on a wall in Italy over 14 years ago? And‚Ä¶ what if maybe he also told me who I will marry?
Let‚Äôs connect!

The Alps are the highest and the most extensive mountain group in Europe, extending across 8 countries: France, Switzerland, Monaco, Italy, Liechtenstein, Austria, Germany, and Slovenia.
In this chapter, I focus on the road trip I did last year on the first nine days of May, driving from Southeast Switzerland to northern Italy, Tyrol Austria and Liechtenstein. If you prefer only to visit the Swiss Alps click here.
The last stop in Switzerland before crossing the border to Italy.
Lake Como
Driving along the lake‚Äôs road through the towns of Domaso, Menaggio, Lenno, Laglio‚Ä¶and at the southern tip Como, where we stayed a night.
Picturesque and romantic city
Lake Endine
A smaller lake also in Lombardy and the perfect stop to stretch our legs and have a lunch break before reaching Lake Iseo.
Lake Iseo
Views to Mont Isola at the island of Lake Iseo were breathtaking so we decided to stay here for the night.
Hiking trails connecting very small ancient villages, old churches, and olive fields with sheep and donkeys.
Lake Garda
Lazise
Bardolino and Malcesine
Riva del Garda
Famous for its beaches, swimming, sailing, windsurfing, hiking and cycling holidays. Here you can paraglide too.
The Dolomites ‚Äî South Tyrol
Trento, Bolzano and Merano landscapes
Gardens of Trauttmansdorff Castle in Merano
In these gardens so carefully taken care of, you will find flora from different parts of the world, a labyrinth, educational games, experimental landscaping, a restaurant with tasty soup by the lake and views to Tyrol as a background knowing that Austria is right on the other side.
Sterzing ‚Äî Vipiteno
Hiking in the morning and local market and shops in Vipiteno¬¥s center in the afternoon before crossing the border to Austria.
‚ÄúTyrol is a western Austrian state in the Alps that‚Äôs known for its ski resorts, historic sites, and folk traditions.‚Äù Innsbruck is its capital.
Innsbruck
Ischgl
A famous ski resort, the season had ended a week before we visited it.

Title: WHY IS ITALY UNIQUE?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Italy is an extraordinary country that blends history, art, culture, cuisine, and natural beauty in an unparalleled manner. From its ancient ruins to its vibrant cities and picturesque landscapes, Italy has captivated the hearts of millions. In this article, we will explore the various aspects that make Italy unique, from its rich history to its diverse regional offerings.
Italy is often called the birthplace of Western civilization. The ruins of ancient Rome, providing remnants of its powerful empire, speak to its historical significance. The Colosseum, the Roman Forum, and the Pantheon are not just tourist attractions; they are testaments to a bygone era that shaped architecture, governance, and law in many parts of the world.
The Renaissance period flourished in Italy, primarily in cities like Florence, Venice, and Milan. This cultural movement saw the emergence of remarkable artists such as Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, and Raphael, whose works have left an indelible mark on art and culture globally. The legacy of the Renaissance continues to influence modern design, art, and literature.
Italy boasts an astronomical number of art treasures. The Vatican Museums, showcasing works by Raphael and Michelangelo, are one of the most visited destinations in the world. Additionally, the Uffizi Gallery in Florence houses masterpieces from the likes of Botticelli and Titian. The sheer volume of artistic genius within Italy‚Äôs borders is unmatched.
Italy‚Äôs architecture is as diverse as its regions. The iconic Leaning Tower of Pisa, the intricate Gothic facades of Milan Cathedral, and the romantic canals of Venice star in the country‚Äôs architectural repertoire. Furthermore, the charm of small medieval towns, with their cobbled streets and historic buildings, add to Italy‚Äôs architectural allure.
Italian cuisine is celebrated worldwide, but what makes it distinctively unique is its regional diversity. From the rich risottos of Northern Italy to the fresh seafood of the Amalfi Coast, each region offers unique flavors and traditions. Dishes like pizza, pasta, and gelato have their roots in specific locales, showcasing the country‚Äôs culinary heritage.
Italian culinary excellence is tied to its commitment to high-quality, local ingredients. Olive oil, fresh vegetables, cheeses, and meats play a crucial role in traditional dishes. The Mediterranean lifestyle, which is intrinsic to Italian culture, emphasizes a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and healthy fats, promoting wellness and enjoyment of food.
Italy‚Äôs landscapes are incredibly varied. From the rolling hills of Tuscany, adorned with vineyards and olive groves, to the stunning cliffs of the Amalfi Coast, the country‚Äôs natural beauty is breathtaking. The Dolomites in the North attract outdoor enthusiasts with their rugged peaks, while the serene beaches in Sardinia offer a slice of paradise.
Italy is home to the most UNESCO World Heritage Sites in the world, with over 58 sites. This includes the picturesque landscapes of the Cinque Terre, the historical and architectural wonders of Venice, and the cultural landscapes of the Val d‚ÄôOrcia. Each site tells a story of the intertwined relationship between nature and human creativity.
Italy‚Äôs cultural calendar is sprinkled with festivals that showcase the nation‚Äôs heritage and local traditions. Events such as Carnevale in Venice and the Palio di Siena draw crowds with lively parades, colorful costumes, and thrilling horse races. These festivals provide insight into the local way of life, uniting communities in shared joy and celebration.
Italian culture places a strong emphasis on family and community. Meals are often shared events, where multiple generations gather to enjoy traditional dishes. This communal spirit fosters a sense of belonging and reinforces the importance of relationships in everyday life.
Italian is often considered one of the most beautiful languages in the world. Its melodic tones and expressive vocabulary contribute to its uniqueness. The language is also a significant part of Italy‚Äôs identity, with numerous dialects reflecting the rich diversity of various regions.
Italy has a rich literary tradition, with significant contributions from authors such as Dante Alighieri, Petrarch, and Umberto Eco. The literary works originating from Italy often explore themes of love, philosophy, and human experience, reflecting the nation‚Äôs diverse cultural heritage.
Italy is synonymous with high fashion. Cities like Milan are considered global fashion capitals, housing revered designers such as Valentino, Prada, and Gucci. The Milan Fashion Week is a pivotal event in the fashion industry, showcasing cutting-edge designs and trends.
Beyond fashion, Italian design is celebrated in industries such as automotive (Ferrari, Maserati), furniture, and architecture. Italian designers prioritize functionality while maintaining a strong emphasis on aesthetics, leading to innovative and timeless creations.
Some of the top tourist destinations include Rome, Florence, Venice, Milan, and the Amalfi Coast. Each of these locations offers unique attractions, historical landmarks, and cultural experiences.
The best time to visit is typically during the spring (April to June) and fall (September to October) when the weather is pleasant, and the crowds are smaller compared to the peak summer months.
It is advisable to dress smartly in Italy, especially when dining out or attending religious sites. Comfortable walking shoes are also essential for exploring cities and towns.
Must-try dishes include pizza Napoletana, pasta carbonara, risotto alla Milanese, and gelato. Each region has its specialties, so be sure to explore local cuisines.
Overall, Italy is considered a safe country for tourists. However, it‚Äôs wise to stay vigilant and take standard precautions against pickpockets, especially in crowded areas.
Italy‚Äôs unique blend of history, culture, cuisine, and stunning landscapes continues to inspire travelers from all over the world. The country‚Äôs rich tapestry makes it not only a destination but also a profoundly dynamic experience that lingers in the hearts and minds of those who visit.

Title: The Ultimate Guide for Digital Nomads in Italy: How to Live Well While Exploring the Hidden Gems
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
Italy is a beautiful country, full of history, culture, and delicious food. But what if I told you that you can explore and enjoy this country to the fullest without compromising on your lifestyle as a digital nomad? As someone who has stayed in over 2000 hotels across Italy, I specialize in finding mid-range accommodations with a budget of ‚Ç¨60‚Äì110 per night, focusing on 3 or 4-star hotels. My experience has taught me to strike a balance between comfort and cost, making the most out of each stay without going to extremes.
In this article, I‚Äôll share with you some of the best tips and tricks I‚Äôve learned along the way. But this is just the beginning! Throughout this series, we‚Äôll go beyond the basics of ‚Äúwhere to stay‚Äù and ‚Äúwhat to eat,‚Äù diving into the practicalities of living well on the road: how to maximize your experience, find hidden gems, and maintain a high quality of life that goes beyond mere survival.
Who Am I?
I‚Äôm a digital nomad with a unique perspective. I work as a technical consultant for a multinational company, splitting my time between freelance projects and a steady job that takes me all over Italy ‚Äî and sometimes beyond. Because of my work, I‚Äôm always on the move, and I‚Äôve made it my mission to find the best places to live, eat, and work remotely, no matter where I am.
But unlike some digital nomads, I‚Äôm not willing to live like a ‚Äúpoor man‚Äù nomad, squeezing myself into the cheapest hostels and cutting corners just to get by. I also refuse to become a ‚Äúdigital hermit,‚Äù living in isolation away from the pulse of the cities. Instead, I aim to thrive ‚Äî finding a balance between comfort, productivity, and enjoyment. And that‚Äôs what I want to share with you in this series.
What Does It Cost to Travel Well in Italy?
Let‚Äôs start with the basics: What does it cost to travel well in Italy? I‚Äôm not talking about scraping by on a tight budget. I‚Äôm talking about a lifestyle that includes good food, nice hotels, and experiences that leave you feeling fulfilled.
How to Travel Around Italy Efficiently
Italy‚Äôs public transportation system is good, but knowing how to navigate it can save you a lot of time and stress. However, unlike many digital nomads, I don‚Äôt often find myself traveling between big cities like Rome and Milan, where trains are ideal, or from Rome to Catania, where a plane would be the obvious choice.
Why and when Traveling by Car is Essential in Italy
Unlike in many other countries, my job rarely takes me to the major hubs like Rome or Milan, where trains and planes would be the most practical options. Instead, I travel to small towns and villages off the beaten path ‚Äî places that are hard to reach by public transportation. If you‚Äôre in a similar line of work, it‚Äôs crucial to understand that the car becomes your lifeline.
Driving in Italy is not only a practical necessity but also a way to fully experience the country. Italy is densely populated and full of charming towns and villages that are worth exploring. Driving to get your groceries or grabbing a beer in a small village becomes an unparalleled experience!
Given the layout and structure of Italian towns, unless you want to be a ‚Äúcaravan nomad‚Äù moving with public transportation, a car is essential. And if you enjoy driving as much as I do, it‚Äôs an experience to cherish rather than a burden. Italy is not like Spain, where cities are spread out and public transport is a more viable option. Here, the car is strategic. I‚Äôll share with you some tips on how to make the most of it and save money while you‚Äôre at it.
Tips for Enjoying Your Hotel Stays
One of the perks of my job is staying in a wide variety of hotels. Whether it‚Äôs a 5-star luxury resort or a small boutique hotel in a hidden village, I‚Äôve learned a few tricks to make every stay more enjoyable:
The Joy of Exploring Small Towns in Italy
One of the true joys of traveling around Italy is exploring its many small towns and villages. Every region has its own charm, and the people are often warm and welcoming. The best part? Even in the most remote locations, you‚Äôll rarely feel isolated. Unlike in some other countries, where you can feel like a stranger in the countryside, in Italy you‚Äôre more likely to be invited to a local event or to share a meal.
This is why you‚Äôll never feel like a ‚Äúdigital hermit‚Äù in Italy ‚Äî unless you choose to be. The density of the towns and the hospitality of the people make it easy to connect, network, and create meaningful experiences, no matter where you are.
Wrapping It Up
Italy has so much to offer, and it‚Äôs possible to experience it all without compromising on quality. This is just the beginning of a series of articles where I‚Äôll explore various Italian and European destinations, sharing what it truly means to live well as a digital nomad.
Stay tuned for more articles where I‚Äôll dive deeper into specific cities and regions, sharing hidden gems, recommended hotels, and, of course, the best places to eat. Because living like a digital nomad shouldn‚Äôt be about ‚Äúmaking do‚Äù ‚Äî it should be about living well.

Title: Is Life in Italy beautiful?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
This article was originally published in Spanish and you are invited to read it as well in my beautiful language here
I am not a psychologist. I could read a bunch of books to find answers to questions like why we enjoy dreaming, and why we love idealizing places, people, and situations‚Ä¶ but I‚Äôm too lazy to do that.
All I know is that if you idealize your life, it‚Äôs probably because you like living in a self-generated Matrix avoiding some problem, denying it, or worse, you‚Äôve always lived that way.
Nowadays, however, we have a huge choice of online resources, and it‚Äôs possible to get a real sense of what a place might be like: ideal for living or vacationing, boring or lively, safe or dangerous. You have the chance to even interact with its inhabitants long distance or, simply ask travelers about their experiences.
A few months ago a video of a girl went viral because she was complaining about how to get to Amalfi. She said she had to fly to Naples, take a train to Sorrento, a ferry to Amalfi, and finally climb lots of stairs to reach her hotel ‚Äî all this in the height of summer, with that heat! Can you believe it?
She said influencers should be jailed for saying things that aren‚Äôt true‚Ä¶ (deep breath‚Ä¶)
Here‚Äôs the thing: living is easy with eyes closed, but today you don‚Äôt have excuses. You have to be in the here and now. Whether it‚Äôs Instagram, YouTube, a book, or an article, you must remember that someone‚Äôs version of a place or an experience is subjective and probably idealized. You need to be aware that what you‚Äôre being sold on social media is either driven by economic convenience or because the person in question is feeding their delusion, trying to rope others into their fantasy.
You can‚Äôt plan your vacations, your life, or your career based on the ideas others give you. You have to go out into the world, connect with people, try, smell, ask, think critically, question, and then decide what to think, how to act, what to do, and where to go.
Mistakes are always lurking around the corner ‚Äî you should always keep that in mind ‚Äî but I can assure you that you‚Äôll feel less frustrated knowing that you did everything yourself and consciously made the effort for your project to succeed.
Having said all this, I imagine you now understand why I said ‚ÄúNo‚Äù in response to the title of this article.
But maybe I‚Äôm not so good at explaining my thesis, so here it is:
No, it‚Äôs not beautiful in Italy or anywhere else if you‚Äôve decided to see life through filters, through the eyes of others ‚Äî call them dream sellers, rich kids who study or live abroad, or immigrants who haven‚Äôt adapted to a new lifestyle or who‚Äôve endured years of bitterness before achieving a decent standard of living and showing it off to you.
Life is beautiful only when you look at it with your own eyes and your ideas. It‚Äôs beautiful with both the good and the bad ‚Äî not just when you see it through the Deep Summer filter.
Wake up!

Title: When in Rome‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäMy Experience in Italy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I took a three-day trip to Italy on New Years. It was always my dream to visit the great Ancient Rome, so you can imagine how excited I was for this trip. Throughout my visit, I experienced some wonderful places, great food, and met new people. I want to share with you the rookie mistakes that I made, the things I did right, and ultimately what I learned from this experience. Here are some tips for navigating your way through the beautiful city of Rome.
Pack well (and right!!): Extra clothes, check, portable charger, check, type C, F, and L power outlet plugs, not check. Seriously, I spent the first half of my day there looking for electronic stores with the correct power outlet adapters. I made a rookie mistake, and hopefully, you will not have to.
Don‚Äôt pay extra. If anyone tries to convince you that you have to pay to get into the Vatican, I will assure you that you don‚Äôt. As soon as I arrived at the Vatican, I was unpleasantly approached by a man who apparently had only two tickets left to sell for the Vatican. Most might think that they ‚Äúgot lucky‚Äù and that they had just made it there in time before tickets were sold out, but that isn‚Äôt the case at all. Just keep your head up and walk right into the Vatican. It‚Äôs free. Thankfully, binge-watching travel videos on youtube helped me with that one.
Take lots of pictures. If you are traveling along, you can even ask tourists to take photos of you! As a solo traveler, I had plenty of time to soak in all the views and take my time appreciating all the sights and wonders. It is nice to take some pictures so you can reminisce later (who knows when you‚Äôll be back). If you want to take some pictures of yourself, ask tourists if they‚Äôd be willing to take it for you, you‚Äôd be surprised how much photography talent there is in the crowd. If you see someone who could use a hand, offer to help them take their picture, they might offer to take yours back. Well, hey, it worked for me.
Plan well! I packed my day with wonderful sightseeing adventures and activities. It is crucial to check openings of the different places, especially on holidays. Unfortunately, I missed out on the great opportunity of seeing the Sistine Chapel because it was closed on the new year.
Throw a coin (or two) into the Trevi Garden. Legend has it that if you throw a coin over your head into the Trevi Fountain, chances are, you will return to Rome. If you throw two, you will return to Rome and fall in love, and three, you will return to Rome, fall in love, and get married there. I don‚Äôt know if this has been proven correct, but it can‚Äôt hurt to take your chances either way. Unluckily, I didn‚Äôt get to throw coins into the fountain, but have no doubt; I shall return.
Check out what Italy is known for, then make sure not to miss out. I enjoyed some delicious Italian Ice Cream, Pizza, and House Wine. The wine is incredibly affordable in Italy. While in the restaurant, don‚Äôt rush to receive the bill. It is customary in Italy to stick around and have a conversation after a nice meal.
Fly Ryanair! This one is a little bit controversial. If you asked me then if I would fly Ryanair again, I would have said that I would absolutely not. Looking back though, I realize how convenient it was to have a cheap flight from London to Rome. Just make sure you read exactly what you need to do when buying the ticket so they won‚Äôt charge you extra for late check-in or carry-on bags. If you don‚Äôt want to experience flight delays though, don‚Äôt fly with Ryanair. They might have cheaper flights, but that doesn‚Äôt mean they come without a cost.
I hope asome of these travelling tips helped you out! I know that I need to take some of my own advice on my next trip to Rome.
Edit: This blog is a repost from 3 years ago when I first visited Rome. Hope you enjoy!

Title: Italy Trip Chronicles: History, Heaven and Heartache
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Italy is a journey through history, a celebration of art, cuisine, and natural beauty. This summer, my family and I embarked on a two-week Italian adventure. From the ancient ruins of Rome to the enchanting canals of Venice, we were ready to uncover Italy‚Äôs timeless wonders. But, like any true adventure, it brought a few unexpected twists, a bittersweet farewell, and memories we‚Äôll carry for a lifetime. Here‚Äôs a chronicle of our journey through history, heaven, and a touch of heartache.
Our trip took place in August, making it perfect for a family getaway. We dedicated two weeks to truly experience Italy from end to end. For planning, AI proved invaluable, offering detailed itineraries and personalized tips at every stage. With its help, we crafted an itinerary covering the major cities: Rome, the Amalfi Coast, Florence, and Venice.
Here is my prompt to AI. You could expect multiple follow up prompts that will help you with better plan (example: plan by hour), new choices and alternate options. Here is the final plan I used for my trip.
Here is my trip plan to Italy. Suggest major attractions in the below cities I will be visiting. Provide transport options for travel between cities. Recommend Italian local restaurants at each location: 1. Rome ‚Äî 1.5 days 2. Amalfi Coast ‚Äî 1.5 days 3. Florence ‚Äî 2.5 days 4. Venice ‚Äî 1.5 days
Rome is where history stands tall. Walking through the Colosseum, Roman Forum, Palatine Hill, and Pantheon, you‚Äôre not just visiting landmarks ‚Äî you‚Äôre breathing history. These sites evoke goosebumps as you imagine the lives of kings, soldiers, and citizens who once walked these grounds. If you‚Äôre planning to visit, consider skipping the line at the Colosseum (it‚Äôs worth it). A guide is optional but can really enhance the experience, bridging past and present.
Leave the history at Rome. What awaits you are Mountains on Amalfi Coast, cool Winds of Florence, Cinque Terre ‚Äî Story of 5 Villages and Gondolas of Venice.
Mountains on Amalfi Coast
As you travel through Italy, you will see mountains everywhere; Mountains on land and Mountains on coast line. The Amalfi Coast felt like a slice of paradise, where mountains meet the Mediterranean. The scenery here is surreal: vibrant villages perched high on steep cliffs, overlooking turquoise waters. Our Airbnb, nestled high on one of these cliffs, offered a stunning panoramic view of the coastline. A boat and snorkeling tour along the coast was a highlight ‚Äî an immersive journey into hidden caves, secluded beaches, and warm Mediterranean waters.
Winds of Florence
Florence has a charm all its own, with a magical cool breeze that welcomes you. Known for its art, culture, and incredible cuisine, it quickly became a family favorite. Florence is also an ideal base for day trips to Tuscany‚Äôs famed wine regions and charming medieval villages. The restaurants here are a treat, offering some of the best Italian cuisine we‚Äôve ever had, which our kids loved too.
Cinque Terre ‚Äî Story of 5 Villages
We chose to visit Cinque Terre, 5 villages along the beautiful coastal region. These villages stand on steep hills (it‚Äôs common across Italy) along the sea with houses colored with various colors. Villages are connected by sea, trains and trails. You can trek mountains to reach across villages. At Cinque Terre, you experience natural beauty, rich history, and Italian culture. You will see how Italians relax and enjoy life.
Gondolas of Venice
No trip to Italy is complete without visiting Venice, the ‚ÄúCity of Love.‚Äù Surrounded by water and navigated by gondolas, Venice feels romantic in every sense. Its narrow, winding streets, centuries-old art, and serene canals create a timeless beauty that makes you feel like you‚Äôve stepped into another era.
As the trip drew to a close, emotions ran high. Physically exhausted, we encountered an unfortunate incident when one of our bags was lost at the Rome railway station. Not a great feeling when you lose what is yours. Cops were of no help. We were grateful to have all our travel documents intact. Pickpockets are real, take warning seriously, keep an eye on your belongings!
We‚Äôd have taken more day trips from Florence and been more vigilant about pickpockets.

Content:

My family rented two Polestar 2 cars for a week long jaunt from Rome to Florence and around the Tuscan countryside, where we stayed at a beautiful villa for five nights, for a total around 1000 km. The catch was that the villa was sited for gorgeous views at the peak of a local hill on a farm that was accessed by 4‚Äì5 km of gravel road, depending on direction of approach. We obtained fast DC charging on the highway away from and back to Rome (more later), but there was no convenient fast charging near the villa.
The Polestars came with an EU wall outlet charging cable, so we were intent upon charging from outlets just inside the front and rear doors. Fortunately, the proprietors left out two grounding plug adaptors that mated with the Polestars‚Äô cable, and we were off. Both outlets were on a single breaker, so only one car could be charged at a time, but at 2.3 kW, wall charging is faster than in the USA, and we were able to share the juice and obtain enough for extensive day trips in Tuscany. The catch was that the owners were unhappy with our solution on grounds that it violates their solar array agreement, which specifies ‚Äúagricultural uses‚Äù. They did accept a nominal payment in compensation, however. We of course argued that they would benefit from offering this as a feature in their AirBnB listing.
On the highway, we charged at an Enel X charger at a shopping center, which offered only one 50 kW DC fast charging spigot with 5 slower Level 2 spigots. This was typical of most charging stations across Italy. So we had to time-share the two cars between a fast and a slow spigot, which seemed absurd coming from our experience with Tesla superchargers featuring at least 4‚Äì8 100‚Äì200 kW spigots per installation. A second session at a Evviva charging station benefitted from four fast spigots, but the initial 140 kW soon dropped to 70 kW when the second car was added.
Thankfully, the Evviva station recognized our Enel X app, but this was not at all apparent without some coaching from another EV driver who was incredibly helpful. The onboarding for Enel X charging had been quite painful, requiring download of an app, entry of quite a bit of personal information, and manual entry of credit card information. My attempt to register for an account was unsuccessful on three successive tries, but I was able to pay as guest, and the app put me in good shape for later charging on the Evviva chargers. But here‚Äôs the question:
Why is it possible to purchase fuel at most any gas station using only a credit card reader, but not at an EV charger? Who is blocking the adoption of a modern process for entering only the most rudimentary validating information (e.g. zip code), or more recently, simply tapping a card or a phone, without the frustrations of downloading apps or entering extensive personal information to set up ‚Äúaccounts‚Äù that are totally unnecessary?
For heaven‚Äôs sake, give me a charge and TAKE MY MONEY, already! We don‚Äôt owe you a database.
--
--

Title: WHY ITALY IS VERY FAMOUS?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Italy, a country located in Southern Europe, is globally renowned for its rich history, stunning landscapes, delicious cuisine, and vibrant culture. From its iconic historical landmarks to its contributions to art, fashion, and automotive design, Italy continues to capture the hearts and minds of people around the world. In this article, we will explore the various facets that contribute to Italy‚Äôs fame and allure.
Italy is often referred to as the cradle of civilization, thanks to its pivotal role in ancient history. The Roman Empire, one of the most influential empires in history, originated here and left behind a remarkable legacy of architecture, law, and governance. Landmarks like the Colosseum, the Roman Forum, and the Pantheon stand as enduring symbols of this glorious past.
The Renaissance, a period that marked the rebirth of art, literature, and science, also originated in Italy. Cities like Florence, Venice, and Rome became the epicenters of intellectual and artistic achievements. Great minds such as Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, and Raphael produced masterpieces that are celebrated worldwide today. The Uffizi Gallery in Florence and the Vatican Museums in Rome house some of the most important works of art in existence, drawing millions of tourists every year.
Italian cuisine is another significant reason for Italy‚Äôs fame. It is internationally adored and has heavily influenced culinary traditions worldwide. Dishes such as pasta, pizza, risotto, and gelato are not just staples of Italian food but have become favorites in many countries.
Italy‚Äôs culinary scene is incredibly diverse, with each region offering unique flavors and specialties. For example, the rich and hearty dishes of Northern Italy contrast sharply with the fresh and vibrant flavors found in the South. The Sicilian cannoli and Neapolitan pizza are just two examples of Italy‚Äôs gastronomic treasures. Food festivals held throughout the country celebrate local produce, further showcasing Italy‚Äôs commitment to quality and tradition in cooking.
Italy has long been a leader in the fashion and design industry. Cities like Milan are known as fashion capitals, hosting prestigious events such as Milan Fashion Week. Renowned designers like Gucci, Prada, Versace, and Valentino have transformed the global fashion landscape with their innovative designs and luxurious collections.
In addition to fashion, Italy is home to several iconic automotive brands, including Ferrari, Lamborghini, and Maserati. The country‚Äôs passion for automotive engineering and design is evident in its sleek sports cars that symbolize speed and elegance. The annual Mille Miglia race and the Auto e Moto d‚ÄôEpoca exhibition in Padua further highlight Italy‚Äôs deep-rooted love for automobiles.
Italy is blessed with diverse landscapes, from the picturesque villages of the Amalfi Coast to the rolling hills of Tuscany. The stunning scenery is a significant draw for tourists, who flock to experience the natural beauty and charm of Italian regions.
Italy has the highest number of UNESCO World Heritage Sites in the world, with 58 sites that showcase its cultural and natural heritage. From the ruins of Pompeii to the stunning frescoes in the Sistine Chapel, these sites attract millions of visitors every year, eager to immerse themselves in Italy‚Äôs storied past.
Italian art has left an indelible mark on the world, influencing countless artists and art movements. Baroque, Renaissance, and Neoclassicism are just a few of the notable art styles that have roots in Italy. The beautiful architecture found in cities like Venice and Rome also demonstrates the profound artistic vision of both past and contemporary architects.
Italy is known for its colorful festivals and lively celebrations that reflect its rich culture and traditions. Events such as Carnevale di Venezia and the Palio di Siena draw both locals and tourists alike, showcasing traditional costumes, music, and dance. These events not only honor Italy‚Äôs deep-rooted traditions but also offer a glimpse into the Italian way of life.
The Italian culture is characterized by warmth, hospitality, and a strong sense of community. The Italian way of life emphasizes family values, hearty meals, and leisurely activities. This welcoming nature is often what draws tourists back to Italy time and again, as visitors leave with not just memories of scenic landscapes and historic sites but also of heartfelt connections with the locals.
Some must-visit locations include Rome (the Colosseum, Vatican City), Florence (Uffizi Gallery, Duomo), Venice (St. Mark‚Äôs Basilica, Grand Canal), and Milan (Duomo di Milano, Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II).
Italian cuisine is popular for its fresh ingredients, simplicity, and variety. Dishes can be easily customized and offer a balance of flavors that appeal to a wide range of palates.
The best time to visit Italy is during the spring (April to June) and fall (September to October) when the weather is mild, and the tourist crowds are relatively smaller.
Yes, Italians value family, social interactions, and meals enjoyed together. It is common to greet friends with a kiss on both cheeks and to enjoy long meals that include multiple courses.
Italy has significantly influenced art, architecture, music, and cuisine. The country is credited with introducing opera, contributing to Renaissance art, and establishing fashion trends that continue to resonate today.
In conclusion, Italy‚Äôs fame can be attributed to its rich historical legacy, extraordinary culinary delights, vibrant fashion scene, breathtaking landscapes, and warm culture. Each facet adds to the allure that keeps people around the world enamored with this beautiful country.

Title: The Magic of Northern Italy: My Journey From Milan to Florence
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Last year I went on a month-long journey through the North of Italy. In this article, I want to share some of the highlights that I made on the tour. Additionally, I thought I‚Äôd complement my own thoughts with impressions of German writer and poet Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, who visited Italy from 1786 to 1788.
My journey began in Milan, which is the second largest city in Italy after Rome. My first impression of the city was a bit disappointing as I perceived it as quite dirty and ran down. Maybe this was due to the fact that my hostel was located next to the main station, which is not the best area in town.
The hostel itself, however, was very nice. I would do a lot of exploring around the center of the city. Two of the main sites are the Milan Cathedral and the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II. The former was built in 1386, and I highly recommend taking a tour through the Cathedral, including the rooftop.
The Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is Italy‚Äôs oldest active shopping gallery. It stands out due to its high ceilings, the glass dome in the center, and its luxurious shops and restaurants within the gallery. I found the architecture very fascinating, although it is obviously overrun by tourists.
After a short stay in Bergamo, I headed out to Verona, the city of Romeo and Juliett. Verona has a nice Mediterranean vibe and is home to the Verona Arena, one of the best-preserved Roman amphitheaters.
It was built in 30 AD and is still in use today. Goethe wrote about the amphitheater:
‚ÄúThe simplicity of the oval is palpable to every eye in the most pleasant way, and every head serves as a measure of how enormous the whole is. Now, when you see it empty, you have no measure; you do not know whether it is big or small.‚Äù
Although the amphitheater is one of the city‚Äôs main attractions, what stood out to me was the general architecture you can find throughout the city. There is a beautiful hill, home to the Castel San Pietro, from which you are able to overlook the city.
Lake Garda, which is easily reachable from Verona, was my next stop. What stood out to me was the panoramic view, with the majestical mountains of the Alps in the background. Goethe was also enraptured by this view:
‚ÄúHow much do I wish that my friends were with me for a moment to enjoy the prospect, which now lies before my eyes. I might have been in Verona this evening, but a magnificent natural phenomenon was in my vicinity ‚Äî Lake Garda, a splendid spectacle, which I did not want to miss, and now I am nobly rewarded for taking this circuitous route.‚Äù
I stayed in a small town called Desenzano del Garda, which is a great hub for exploring the surrounding areas. Even in late October, you are able to enjoy some hours at the lake‚Äôs beaches.
My next stop on the list was Venice ‚Äî a town I have seen so many times in various movies but never in person. So as soon as I left the train station and saw the canal in the beautiful sunshine, I had a big smile on my face. I stayed in a hostel called the Generator, which is located on one of the smaller side islands but offers a great view of the city.
Now, Venice really is a place of its own. You do not need to visit museums or galleries because the city itself is a piece of art. It gained wealth and power between the 9th and 12th centuries and had another very influential phase during the Renaissance. The boats, the houses, the canals. Everything in Venice feels magical, and you could easily believe that the city is a well-constructed theme park.
Note, however, that many tourists are moving through the narrow alleys of which Goethe wrote:
‚ÄúAfter dinner, I hurried to first get an impression of the whole, and threw myself (‚Ä¶) into the labyrinth of the city, which, although intersected by canals and small channels, is connected again by bridges and small bridges. One cannot imagine the narrowness and crowdedness of the whole without having seen it.‚Äù
After I left Venice and spent one night in Bologna, I headed further south to Florence. Now, if you‚Äôre a fan of DaVinci, Michelangelo, or art in general, this city is a must-see! Although I was already a bit tired of the hustling and bustling of all the cities I‚Äôd seen, I managed to visit the Uffizi, which hosts one of the most important collections of the Renaissance era.
What I enjoyed even more in Florence was the community kitchen of my hostel ‚Äî the Yellow Square. Every night a committed group of travelers would gather in the kitchen and share meals and stories of their day. Furthermore, the hostel has a nice rooftop terrace from where you can overlook the city.
Finally, it was time for me to head out into nature. I went to a place called LaVerna ‚Äî an old, mystical monastery that is located on the top of a mountain. From there, I would start on a week-long pilgrimage along the way of St. Francis, which ultimately led me to the town of his birth, Assisi.
Thank you for reading this article. If you enjoy my writing, please follow my profile on medium. See you soon!

Think you know Italy? Think again.
Though I knew a fair amount about Italian culture before moving to Calabria last year, I‚Äôve learned a few things that have surprised me now that I‚Äôm here.
In the U.S., we are used to being spoiled by friends and family for our birthdays, aren‚Äôt we?
Here, it‚Äôs the opposite. You, the birthday girl, are supposed to take out your loved ones to celebrate you. I think it‚Äôs to offset the cost of the gifts that they give you.
This year, I avoided breaking the bank by having a party at my house instead. But I almost made a faux pas by offering to split a meal the day after my birthday with my ‚ÄúItalian mamma‚Äù until I remembered this strange cultural norm and quickly went to pay for our lunch.
I have never been big on blowdrying my hair, but in Italy, I get raised eyebrows.
It turns out, Italians believe in what they call a colpo d‚Äôaria, literally a hit of air. It causes, or so they believe, headaches, colds, and a litany of maladies. And having wet hair invites it.
