Title: Cows, Cheese And Italy‚Äôs Land Without Animals
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Why Saying ‚ÄòArrivederci‚Äô to ‚ÄòCareless‚Äô Meat and Cheese is Key to Restoring Italy‚Äôs Relationship with Food
I‚Äôll never forget my summer road trip through the land of gastronomy. I spent several days touring Italy‚Äôs most fertile agricultural valley. I marveled at the pretty villages with picturesque churches and hilly backdrops. The endless pastures and crop fields. The balmy days of blue skies and t-shirt temperatures. Friendly people at every turn. And the smell of the most delicious food.
No wonder Italy is so widely cited as the world‚Äôs number one for cuisine. Whether pizzas, pastas or gnocchi served with a myriad of flavours, Italy seems to have it all.
Italian food engenders an exhilaration like no other; what world-renowned Italian chef, Giorgio Locatelli describes as the ‚Äúthe relationship between food, sex, wine and the excitement of life‚Äù.
Except, there was something missing. In my days traversing the fields, valleys and plains of the rich Italian countryside, I never once saw a farm animal outside. It was an irony that has stayed with me ever since.
Where were the cows producing milk for world-famous Parmesan or Grana Padano? Or the pigs renowned for Parma ham? Or the chickens producing eggs for Carbonara?
Quality not quantity
What I discovered is that farmers in Italy‚Äôs richest agricultural region had forgotten how to keep animals outside. They simply had a blind spot. They couldn‚Äôt see why it wasn‚Äôt right to keep them cooped up indoors all day, every day. They couldn‚Äôt see the irony of grass being grown then mowed and packed into bales to feed incarcerated cows.
They had lost sight of the fact that cows, pigs, and chickens like to feel fresh air and sunshine as much as we do.
It put me in mind of something else Locatelli once said: ‚ÄúIt is better to have fantastic meat once a week than fill ourselves up every day with cheap, carelessly reared meat. We all have to get used to quality, not quantity.‚Äù
Famous cheeses
The most surprising discovery on my travels through the Italian countryside was the way dairy cows were kept, not least for those world-renowned iconic cheeses of Parmesan and Grana Padano.
I remember checking the production details for Parmesan and Grana Padano and finding they both mentioned the cows being raised on fresh grass and hay.
But cows wandering the fields, gently tugging at grassy stalks or chewing the cud under the shade of trees, were conspicuous by their absence; the only cows I could find were crammed into darkened sheds.
I remember seeing a hundred cows peering out of a single square shed. They were trapped inside but had a perfect view of the lush pasture they were prevented from grazing on.
I watched incredulously as heavy goods vehicles delivered grass to a processing plant. A yellow tractor scooped grass into a giant machine, while yet more trucks took compacted blocks of grass and drove them away.
Instead of letting the animals graze in a time-honoured fashion, mechanically pressed bales were being produced to feed confined cattle.
What happened to cow paradise?
In what should have been a cow‚Äôs paradise, nature‚Äôs way had been abandoned.
According to the Grana Padano consortium, 80 per cent of their cows are denied pasture access with approximately 40 per cent confined indoors, not even having outdoor ‚Äòpaddocks‚Äô.
It reinforced my impression that we now have a generation of cattle farmers in Italy that simply don‚Äôt know how to keep animals as nature intended ‚Äî on pasture.
I wondered whether things were now different for those cows milked for Parmesan ‚Äî or Parmigiano Reggiano to give its full name. Surely, this ‚Äòking of cheeses‚Äô would be made from the milk of cows that are kept on grass?
Like Grana Padano and many other regional foods, strict rules govern the manufacture of Parmesan. Given its protected status, only cheesemakers from Parma, Reggio Emilia, parts of Bologna, Modena and Mantua can qualify.
My enquiries to the Consorzio del Formaggio Parmigiano Reggiano, the consortium that governs the manufacture of Parmesan in 2016 resulted in them sharing that the proportion of cows grazing freely in fields for them during the summer months was ‚Äúvery low‚Äù.
I was told that there were few exceptions, perhaps as few as one per cent of their farms had cows out grazing. In 2023, I asked them for an update and received no reply.
Known as ‚Äòzero-grazing‚Äô ‚Äî keeping cows indoors permanently ‚Äî I subsequently found that it was common practice all over Italy.
As Kees de Roest wrote in The Production of Parmigiano-Reggiano Cheese: The Force of an Artisanal System in an Industrialised World, ‚Äòalmost all Italian dairy farms apply the zero-grazing system‚Äô.
Whilst cows are confined indoors, Italy‚Äôs crop fields are often dedicated to growing feed for them rather than food for people.
Unsustainable
About half of Italy‚Äôs cereal crop is used to feed intensively reared animals. In addition, the country is a big importer of soya, importing about 3 million tonnes a year, much of which is used to feed industrially reared animals.
Farmed animals are now spookily conspicuous by their absence from the fields and valleys of Italy‚Äôs Po Valley.
Which reminded me of those prophetic words by Italian chef, Giorgio Locatelli who warned against eating cheap, carelessly reared meat, saying, ‚ÄúWe all have to get used to quality, not quantity.‚Äù
Putting quality back on our plate seems the right ingredient for ensuring that Italian cuisine once again reflects that fabled relationship between food, sex, wine and the excitement of life.
Saying ‚Äòarrivederci‚Äô to keeping cows permanently indoors should be a big part of a recipe for nature-friendly food for the future.
Note: This is a version of an article that was first published in The Scotsman on Monday 24th April, 2023

Every day, I learn something more about my new home in Calabria, Italy. I now laugh at how much I DIDN‚ÄôT know before I moved to Italy. Hopefully, this post will help you gain a few more nuggets of wisdom if you‚Äôre planning to relocate to Italy!
I‚Äôll be in the middle of a deep conversation with a friend or my boyfriend and then the phone rings. 98% of the time, they‚Äôll answer.
While many Americans also keep their ringers on and answer or respond to texts, by far, the Italians have them beat. They will respond no matter what they‚Äôre doing. (Do not ask me to elaborate. You can use your imagination here!)
And if they‚Äôre the ones calling and if they get no answer, they‚Äôll call again. And again. And again. Italian phone numbers don‚Äôt have voicemail, so you can let the phone ring until tomorrow if you want.
This is one frustration I haven‚Äôt gotten over. I feel like when you‚Äôre with people in person, they should be your focus, not whoever‚Äôs calling to shoot the shit.

Title: Italy brings out the Italian in all of us
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Italy is my happy place. There are so much to love I don‚Äôt know that I can fully articulate them all. I fell in love with this magical country over a decade ago on my first trip to Florence and Rome. For me, there was something that happened when I took that first sip of Italian wine while sitting at a quintessential Italian bistro. For me, it was a sort of spiritual awakening. I didn‚Äôt feel like a tourist at all. I felt like I was finally coming home. So much so that when I took my 23 and me test a few years back I was convinced it would come back confirming what I felt in my soul. Turns out I‚Äôm only 7% Italian, but one can dream.
Fourteen years and four trips later I am more in love with Italy than I‚Äôve ever been. Every time I leave to come home, I‚Äôm already obsessing over when I can go back. Time doesn‚Äôt stand still and we can‚Äôt ever duplicate an experience though. I‚Äôve learned to embrace this over the years. Because of this, each of my trips to Italy have been dramatically different. So much so that my perspective and appreciation of Italy changes a little each time. I have learned a few simple things during this time that I want to share to make your journey everything it should be.
One of the most spectacular things about Italy is the landscape. You don‚Äôt want to miss a minute of it. To miss out on this part of the journey is like missing out on seeing the ocean if you visit the Oregon coast. For this reason, if you‚Äôre visiting multiple cities on your trip the only way to do this is by train. Do not; I repeat; do not waste your precious time on a bus. It is by far slower, stinkier, and you miss out on much of the countryside( I know this unfortunately by experience). The train system in Europe is very convenient. I recommend using the app Omio. You can search and purchase tickets from city to city, find the quickest and most inexpensive routes, and then store your tickets right to your I-phone or smart phone. Book a window seat so you can be sure to take in all of the amazing views. Pro tip: Pack lightly and make sure your bags are easily accessible when you disembark the train. This process can get a little bit chaotic, but still so worth it.
Everyone enjoys a summer vacation. School tours, large groups, and just about everyone in between will be in Italy in the summer. For this reason, if you can manage the timing heed my advice when I tell to you go during a non-peak season. Not only will you avoid the stifling heat, you will pay less for pretty much everything, you will get to have some leisure that doesn‚Äôt happen when you are battling the summertime crowds. You can enjoy your time in front of the David without waiting in line and then having to fight your way to front just to get a photo. Imagine standing in the middle of St. Mark‚Äôs Square in Venice, with only a handful of other tourists ( I have very fortunately experienced this). Or picture yourself standing in the Sistine Chapel without wall to wall people. This is an experience that precious few can say they‚Äôve encountered while traveling in Italy.
While you‚Äôre taking time to get in touch with your inner Italian make sure you allow your eyes to move from the map you‚Äôre using. Close the navigation on your phone and please get lost. One of the beautiful things about being in a foreign country is allowing yourself to wander. We live in an age of maps and GPS everywhere so I realize this can be challenging. But by putting the directions away you will find that you start to see what‚Äôs right in front of you instead of planning how to get to the destination on your mental to-do list. Roaming through the streets of a walled city in Tuscany is something you won‚Äôt regret or ever forget. Allow yourself to stumble upon the unique local shops and chat with the friendly Italians. While I agree that some planning is necessary on your journey the real adventure comes when you let yourself drift and soak up the treasures just waiting for you.
Italy is truly a remarkable place. There‚Äôs an omnipresent feeling that you‚Äôre surrounded genius works of art and culture. I challenge you to visit and enjoy, but always save a little bit to explore on your next trip. I do hope that your journey allows you get in touch with a little bit of your Italian and keeps you coming back for more. You won‚Äôt regret the views from the train. You‚Äôll not want to miss any of the Italian wine while you eat the best pasta of your life. And don‚Äôt forget to find yourself on a street that you hadn‚Äôt planned on visiting, soaking up a view that you didn‚Äôt realize was waiting for you.
--
--
Lover of music, travel, books, and art. Give me a minute and I can talk your ear off about all of them. Let me write and I will sing you a song.

Title: Why I didn‚Äôt love Italy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Italy has to be on everyone‚Äôs travel shortlist ‚Äî and, for a long time, it was on mine as well. It‚Äôs a destination like Paris or London or Tokyo that fills people with wonder and has an iconic feeling thanks to Hollywood and everyone‚Äôs brag-worthy Insta shots.
I can‚Äôt say why we hadn‚Äôt made it to Italy yet. We‚Äôve been working our way through Europe country-by-country, mainly as add-ons to my work trips. There are other places I‚Äôve gravitated towards first because they have been a bit higher on my list. We also took a massive three-week trip in 2013, and while we went to Portugal and Spain, Italy didn‚Äôt make the cut.
But I happened to have a work trip to Zurich for The Company in December, and since we did Denmark and Sweden the following year in November and froze to death, we decided to go south this trip and finally check Italy off of the list.
Italy was disappointing.
That‚Äôs not a popular sentiment. I‚Äôm dear friends with many Italophiles, and I love them and trust their opinions, but I‚Äôve since learned that I don‚Äôt have to love all destinations equally. And Italy just isn‚Äôt my jam.
I tried to break this down into broader categories, and I realized that there are a few things that I look for when I travel:
Order: If we think about a continuum from order to chaos, I‚Äôm a lover of order. I find that chaotic places can be somewhat anxiety-triggering, but beyond that I find a smoother travel experience when it‚Äôs easy to get from A to B and when people know how to queue in lines in an orderly fashion. Even if it‚Äôs not the structure that I know, I‚Äôm happy to stand back and observe the rules and adapt to them.
Politeness: A close cousin to order is the politeness of the people in individual interactions. Are people open and kind? Do they hold doors, try to stay quieter at night, or stand up to give seats on transit for expectant mothers? When you treat someone with respect, do they respond in kind?
Warmth: How welcome do you feel, even if you are different? Do people welcome you into their lives and their families? One country that feels incredibly warm to me is Mexico ‚Äî just pull up a chair and join the family! You are welcome no matter who you are and feel that people genuinely care about you.
History/Culture/Stuff to Do: This is actually the easiest requirement of all because I find so many things interesting! I can find something interesting in almost any place.
[Note: One huge exception here is camping. I don‚Äôt camp. I hate it and I refuse to spend my vacation doing something I can‚Äôt stand. So if camping is the attraction, or the accommodation, I‚Äôm out.]
So when I step back and think about my favorite trips I‚Äôve ever taken, it‚Äôs not surprising that they would score highly across the board. If I were to rate my favorites, the top three thus far are Australia, Austria, and Hawai‚Äôi. Each of these is quite different, with different things that attract me, and each has their own detractions (scary creatures, weather, humidity, excess sand, etc.), but they are places that have a good orderliness, polite and warm people, and interesting cultural sites and activities.
The big attraction to Italy was the culture and the history. It‚Äôs the freakin‚Äô Roman empire ‚Äî how amazing to visit a society that was such a powerhouse for a thousand years! So when I think about the highlights of our visit to Rome and Florence, these cultural attractions made the biggest impression on us.
But Italy did not score so well in the categories of order, politeness, and warmth. Whenever I mention this to an Italophile they express one of two things. First, they might express regret that I didn‚Äôt experience the Italy that they love (one dear friend said, ‚ÄúWell, by the fifth or sixth time Italy is amazing!‚Äù which made me laugh that I‚Äôd have to do four more trips like this to discover the charm of the place). And I can see that this could be true because there were pockets of warmth. There was the amazing B&B host in Florence who gave us a mini walking tour around the B&B and kept adding recommendations to our map (to the point that I kept feeling bad that he was taking up so much time). We had some very kind servers at some of the restaurants in Rome, especially those we visited in the Jewish quarter.
But this was not a country filled with politeness or order. It felt a lot like Portugal ‚Äî a city that was once great but that was, quite literally, in decay. I found the Italians en masse to be loud, pushy (literally) and rude. Sometimes their aggression is well-served ‚Äî say, in the way that they drive ‚Äî but in other cases it just seemed misplaced.
I have some empathy for what Romans must experience, living in a city that every idiot tourist in the world wants to visit. They tromp off of their air-conditioned coaches in khaki shorts and big white tennis shoes, stopping in the center of the sidewalk to unfurl their maps or position their selfie sticks. I get it. These are the same idiots that show up in Seattle in June, July, and August.
What frustrates the crap out of me is that we work very, very hard to not be that kind of tourist. I‚Äôve found that learning some of the local language can be incredibly helpful. I‚Äôll never forget my first trip to France with some friends. One of them refused to say ‚ÄúBonjour‚Äù when we entered shops, instead saying ‚ÄúHI!‚Äù in a super-American accent. Greetings are one of the simplest ways to show respect of other cultures ‚Äî it doesn‚Äôt take more than 30 minutes to learn five basic phrases in a language, and now that we have the Internet, there‚Äôs no excuse!
When it came to Italian, I spent two months learning a bit more than the basics on DuoLingo. Yes, it did help a little, but in most cases it helps grease the skids for moments of connection. Not in Italy. Not at all.
Two other simple adjustments we make when we travel is in the way that we dress and the way that we behave in public. If you‚Äôve ever been on a train in Germany or a flight in Sweden you‚Äôll notice how quietly people converse, mindful of the shared spaces that they are in. These are places where one doesn‚Äôt need to draw attention to oneself through behavior or dress. Dressing for the road is actually rather simple ‚Äî we wear clothing that is classic and plain, or in muted patterns (like stripes, small checks, or small florals). We ditch the clothes with words and jokes and logos to go for the pan-European look. Because of how we look physically people are often unsure where we‚Äôre from (no one ever guesses Mexico for Sergio!), and because of this we can ‚Äúpass‚Äù for different nationalities. The best compliment to me when traveling in Europe is for someone to think I am Swiss or German (but I‚Äôll take Canadian!), and I take a lot of joy when I say that I am American ‚Äî just one who is considerate in other countries!
All of this amounted to nothing in Italy. No amount of blending behavior worked at all. Maybe that‚Äôs because we weren‚Äôt blending with the culture? But even if you can‚Äôt blend, I had hoped there would be some appreciation that we weren‚Äôt obnoxious.
In the end, I think my experience of traveling in Italy was very much like my travels to New York City. It‚Äôs not popular to say this, but I‚Äôm not a fan of NYC. Sure ‚Äî there are lots of things to do and see. I love the museums and the shows and the food. But it entirely lacks in charm and warmth, not to mention trees (I‚Äôll give Rome this ‚Äî they do have some trees here and there).
One last note, and that‚Äôs food. Food might be the fifth category, if there is one. My opinion on food has changed since I‚Äôve modified my diet (no dairy plus I follow a modified version of the FODMAP diet) ‚Äî I‚Äôm interested in the local cuisine, but in some countries the choice foods aren‚Äôt something I can eat. Italy is a great example ‚Äî most pizza and pasta is covered in cheese, a big no-no for me.
I admit that we sinned big one night and had lasagna, which was delicious and worth the stomachache. Italian food was good, but since it‚Äôs widely available, there wasn‚Äôt much about it that felt so special that I could only get it there. This is different than some other cuisines where it is very difficult to get authentic cuisine outside of the place. Have you ever had amazing barramundi in the US? What about perfect shave ice outside of Hawai‚Äôi? Or fl√∏deboller outside of Scandinavia? Or perfect spaetzle and strudel outside of Bavaria?
So that‚Äôs that. Italy turned out to be a bit of a bomb for me. We don‚Äôt have any upcoming work trips planned to Europe, but we do have a big trip planned in the spring! For something completely different, we‚Äôre going to Norway, Estonia, and Finland! To say that I‚Äôm excited is an understatement. A fair bit of my heritage is Norwegian (with a bit of Swedish and Finnish thrown in for luck), so I‚Äôm excited to visit Norway in particular. We‚Äôve also visited both Denmark and Sweden, and while the Scandinavians aren‚Äôt the warmest people when you first meet them, those countries score off-the-charts on order, politeness, and history! I‚Äôm going to start learning basic Norwegian phrases next month!
Ciao for now, Sarah

Title: Tidbits about my wanderings through Italy, one region at a time‚Äî Piedmont
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
After 15 years of transcontinental trips, I finally accomplished my goal of visiting all 20 regions of Italy (magically, just before the pandemic hit). I will continue to return over and over, as there is so much more to see and do and learn, but in this blog series I look back, through the rear-view mirror, and share some of the highlights I discovered along the way ‚Äî One region at a time.
Piedmont sits in northwest Italy, bordered by France and Switzerland, as well as by the Italian regions of Aosta, Lombardy, and Liguria. As its name suggests, Piedmont lies at the foot (pie) of the mountains (monte). Italy‚Äôs second largest region, it is surrounded by mountains on three sides and is home to many of the highest peaks and largest glaciers in Italy. The landscape is incredibly diverse, from rugged peaks to rolling hills covered with vineyards, to rice fields and plains.
Turin is the regional capital, was the first capital city of Italy, and for centuries before that was the heart of the Kingdom of Savoy. Not surprising, the city is rich in history and culture. A mix of elegant Baroque, Neo-classical and Art Nouveau architecture (more reminiscent of Paris and Vienna than Rome and Naples), combined with broad, portico-lined streets, sets its historic centre apart. Many of Italy‚Äôs more traditional medieval centres that I have visited (e.g., Florence, Siena, Bologna) tend to have narrow, haphazard streets, and stocky Romanesque architecture. The differences are striking
My experiences in Piedmont (Piemonte) centred around Turin, where I spent 2 weeks during the World Masters Games (2013) and Monferrato, where I spent 3 weeks working at a winery and agriturismo (2019). I also felt compelled to return to both place in 2021, to reconnect with friends from my earlier visits. My eyes were opened wider with each visit.
La Casaccia Agriturismo and Winery sits about an hour east of Turin. For some background, I was at La Casaccia as a volunteer, working in exchange for room and board (part of an exchange program called WWOOF (World Wide Opportunities on Organic Farms that I highly recommend for anyone who wants an authentic Italian experience). For me it was a way to extend my stays in Italy without breaking the bank, to practise my Italian and, as much as possible, to live like a local. Mission accomplished!
I chose La Casaccia for several reasons. A major draw was its location in Piedmont, a region I wanted to spend more time exploring. The fact that La Casaccia was a B&B /agriturismo as well as a winery was also appealing, as I was sure to learn more as I helped out in the variety of activities. It turned out to be an amazing experience with a wonderful host family. I did everything from preparing breakfast for B&B guests to working in the garden and kitchen (where I learned some local recipes), to working in the cellars and vineyards (helping prepare for and participate in the vendemmia, or wine harvest, as well as in the production process for the various organic wines they made). I loved every minute of it, and my return visit 2 years later felt like a family reunion.
While at La Casaccia, I also had the luxury of exploring the area on electric bikes the family owned. Something I highly recommend if you get the chance, particularly since the area is quite hilly. The vineyard landscapes of Langhe Roere and Monferrato that I biked through are a designated a UNESCO World Heritage site.
Piedmont is a spectacular region of Italy. My visits offered just a glimpse of what it has to offer. Click here for more information about Piedmont and here for information on the Monferrato wine region and its wines.
I look forward to hearing from you about your highlights from Piedmont, whether you are a travel enthusiast, lover of Italy, reader, writer (or all of the above!) and especially about your experiences getting off the trodden path and seeing Italy from all its amazing angles. For more about my experiences through other regions of Italy please check back for new posts. You can also check out my website Susan J Bocock Author

--
Writing is my therapy. Italy is my addiction. Follow my wanderings through Italy‚Äôs 20 regions and all they have to offer. www.susanjbocockauthor.com

Title: One Week in Italy: The Millennial‚Äôs Guide
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Oh, Italy. Your vast landscapes, rich history and culture, gorgeous architecture and inexpensive cappuccinos, how I love thee. Before taking a week long roadtrip through Italy, I had expected nothing but bliss. While there was definitely bliss, there were quite a few roadblocks (like, literally.) Now that I know the quirks of traveling in Italy, my next trip there will probably look completely different, and I want to make sure that you‚Äôre set up for success for your own trip! From start to finish, here‚Äôs everything you need to know about traveling in Italy from Milan to the Amalfi Coast.
Where to Stay
When asking what most millennial‚Äôs would want from a travel guide, most of my Instagram followers said, ‚Äúbudgeting tips!‚Äù Obviously, where to stay takes up a significant portion of your traveling budget. That being said, I definitely suggest booking Airbnb‚Äôs on your trip in Italy if you are looking for a cost-effective experience. Here are some ways to make the most out of your #AirbnbExperience.
Not all Airbnb‚Äôs are created equal: Something I didn‚Äôt know is the difficulty of finding and entering Italian Airbnb‚Äôs. I‚Äôm sure there are areas in Italy where newer apartments/homes are available, however, NOT SO with where we stayed. Keep in mind that the buildings in Italy are, well, ancient. It is rare to find an elevator in apartment/condo buildings, and even if you do, it might be the kind that you have to manually open and close the doors of and still hike up a floor (yes, this happened.)
Prepare to sweat: If running AC is a dealbreaker for you in the summer (like it is for most people), make sure to select ‚ÄúAir conditioning‚Äù in Airbnb‚Äôs search options. If you don‚Äôt, you might end up trying to decide whether it‚Äôs a good idea to sleep naked with all the windows wide open all night. In the winter, this wouldn‚Äôt pose as much of an issue, since it is quite nice in the evening, but if you opt for a non-AC equipped unit in the summer just to save a few bucks, don‚Äôt say I didn‚Äôt warn you.
Your host WILL meet with you and it MIGHT be awkward: A funny detail about Italy is that most Airbnb‚Äôs are run like hotels. Families own entire floors of old apartments and rent them out. That being said, check-in won‚Äôt be done solo. Unlike America, where your host will typically hide the key, wish you goodluck and not speak to you until they leave you a *fingers-crossed* kind review, Italians greet you at the street corner, will carry your bags, walk with you to the apartment, then sit with you in the living room giving you local tips. At first, this made me uncomfortable. After realizing how absolutely crucial it is to travel with a local‚Äôs tips, I looked forward to each check-in process. Don‚Äôt hurry them out, listen to every last word like it‚Äôs your religion.
Travel tax is often not included in the cost: Prepare to pay between ‚Ç¨1‚Äì2 per person per night* at each place you stay. It‚Äôs often not included in the Airbnb cost so have euros readily available at every location. Also, prepare for your host to snap a photo of your ID or Passport. This alarmed me at first, but it is actually Italian law to report your guests to the government with their valid ID. Who knew?
*This cost maxes out after three days in one location. If you hop around Italy every few days staying in different locations, it will renew and you‚Äôll need to pay the tax at each location.
Transportation
My favorite flight tracking site is SkyScanner, second favorite is the app Hopper. Watch flight costs and book when it‚Äôs low, then plan to travel in Italy one of two ways: public transportation or rent a car.
Car rental: If you‚Äôre absorbing the cost of more than one person (like, if you‚Äôre married, OR have the option to split travel costs with friends) it‚Äôs cheaper overall to rent a car. Tolls were around ‚Ç¨200, the rental itself was ‚Ç¨700, and we chose a diesel car so that every tank of gas would take us farther. We were crossing a country border, so it‚Äôd cost around that just to get to one location in Italy for both of us. However! I do not suggest driving in Italy. You might save overall, but the time wasted trying to find parking, (and in some places, paying for parking) is not easy. If you rent a car in Italy, each driver will require an Italian driver‚Äôs permit. You can acquire one at your local AAA office in the US for $20. (To my knowledge, you can not acquire one once you are overseas.)
Trains, trams, and busses: Get to Italy by plane and there will be a train station either underneath or within walking distance of any airport. Get a pass that covers the duration of your stay and you‚Äôre set. Trams and busses are optional depending on location, so I wouldn‚Äôt plan ahead for these. Depending on how many locations you visit, this is probably the best option for you. I can‚Äôt guarantee what your overall cost would be, but if you‚Äôre a solo traveler it‚Äôs most definitely the way to go.
How to Pack Light
The easiest way to pack light is by following the capsule wardrobe rules. My favorite capsule wardrobe concept is the 10x10 wardrobe created by Lee Vosberg of the Style Bee Blog. Here are the rules: pick any 10 items (not including accessories or jewelry) from your current closet and style those items into 10 different looks. Easy! The basic formula is choosing 4 tops, 2 bottoms, 1 dress, 2 shoes, 1 top layer. Pay attention to the local weather (duh) when packing, and look for inspiration by searching the #10x10Friends hashtag on Instagram!
After the fun things are packed, don‚Äôt forget the boring yet completely necessary things. If your luggage is full, purchase a space saver bag to secure your clothing in‚Äîit really will save you tons of space inside your luggage!
Budgeting
Budgeting for travel begins way before you book the flight or get on the plane.
My overall rule for budgeting is based on the rules of minimalism. I spend on experiences, not things. I don‚Äôt buy what I don‚Äôt need, and I think about purchases long and hard before taking the plunge. If traveling is a desire or a goal for you, sacrifice has to come from somewhere. Think of the person you see online constantly traveling. Unless they‚Äôre a total baller or just racking up credit card debt, the money being spent has been saved for that moment. They‚Äôre sacrificing in one area so that they can experience life more fully in another. So, stash your cash monthly toward a traveling fund rather than letting it slowly drain from your bank account simply because it‚Äôs there and available.
Additionally, don‚Äôt overspend on your zero-transaction fee credit cards (I‚Äôm really pushing for these) while you‚Äôre abroad. Stay in line with your routine budget**. It‚Äôs easy to get carried away, but painful once all those swipes reveal themselves on your monthly statement.
Overall, I can‚Äôt tell you what to or not to buy. That‚Äôs ultimately up to you. But I can advise you to evaluate your ‚Äúmust have/see/do‚Äôs‚Äù and ditch the things that don‚Äôt actually interest you. If it‚Äôs not your thing, don‚Äôt go to a museum because everyone tells you to, don‚Äôt rent a beach chair because I tell you to, don‚Äôt wait in line or take a tour of a monument that everyone posts on Instagram but you could care less about. See the places you want to see with your own eyes, not the eyes of your friends, family, coworkers, etc. Clearly define your traveling desires before lift-off and your life on-the-road will be easier.
**If you don‚Äôt have a routine budget, I highly suggest starting here!
Now, to the fun part! Find Airbnb, restaurant, and budgeting suggestions below for each location we visited in Italy!
MONTEROSSO AL MARE (Cinque Terre)
Where to Stay: I highly suggest staying in this Airbnb. This is one of the locations that is run like an actual bed and breakfast and is literally steps from the ocean and ‚Äúnew town‚Äù center.
Where to Eat: You won‚Äôt need to search very far for delicious eats. Down the main street of old and new town, you‚Äôll pass at least thirty shops offering two cappuccinos and croissants for no more than ‚Ç¨6. Eat at these spots during the day and save the ones below for your evening dining!
‚Ç¨: Fornaio Di Monterosso
‚Ç¨‚Ç¨: Bar Davi
‚Ç¨‚Ç¨‚Ç¨: Torre Aurora, L‚ÄôAncora della Tortuga
What to Wear: After one hour in the sun you will shed all your clothing and end up in the ocean. Wear your swimsuit, throw on shorts and a tank and call it a day. In the evening, wear something light and comfortable for dinner. You‚Äôll see people dressed up for dinner, so if you plan to bring an outfit that makes you feel fancy when sipping on your cocktail of choice.
Local Tips: This is truly a hang out at the beach all day, shop at the mini-markets and eat your weight in seafood kind of place. The way to really enjoy it is by getting up early and snagging an umbrella by the shore while you can. The cheapest spot is right outside the Beach Bar Stella Marina. (It costs ‚Ç¨30 for two chairs and an umbrella for the entire day.) You can purchase the spot and it‚Äôs yours until after the sun sets! Leave your towels and wander around when it‚Äôs too hot to tan, grab a bite to eat, grab some souvenirs, then come back and take a nap in the shade. If you plan to be there for a few days, get a train ticket (the train stops literally right smack by the ocean in the center of ‚Äúnew town‚Äù) for the duration of your stay so that you can hop around to the other four towns in the Cinque Terre, because Monterosso is only one of five!
Budgeting: The nice thing about Monerosso al Mare is that you can count on spending around ‚Ç¨50 per day, umbrella included (if you‚Äôre not counting the Airbnb cost.) Street food is delicious and ridiculously inexpensive. Get your fill on ‚Ç¨1 cappuccinos, croisants and gelato, then treat yoself at dinner. Budget a little extra for shopping and alcohol and you‚Äôre good to go. Side note: You can get a bottle of wine at dinner for only $18, soooo, yeah, you‚Äôre gonna wanna get that.
ROME
Where to Stay: This Airbnb was gorgeous but difficult to enter and the AC wasn‚Äôt fantastic. But it was right smack in between Vatican City and the Colosseum, so we didn‚Äôt have to spend money on transportation. If you‚Äôre able-bodied (keep in mind that you must climb a flight of stairs after taking a manual elevator) and don‚Äôt mind waiting for the air to cool down, book this Airbnb for its charm and location. If not, find one with AC and easy entry in the surrounding area.
Where to Eat: We were only in Rome for one day, but each of these spots were to die for. These are a MUST when in Rome.
‚Ç¨: Da Simo Pane e Vino, Pergamino Caff√®, and best gelato in Rome, Della Palma!
‚Ç¨‚Ç¨: II Corallo
What to Wear: Rome is hot in the summer. Like, real hot. The locals are extremely fashionable, but they‚Äôre also adjusted to the heat, so, not sure where I land on this one. Use your own discretion. I do suggest comfortable sneakers, though, since you‚Äôll be on foot all day.
Local Tips: Assuming you‚Äôre visiting Rome to see Vatican City, The Colosseum, etc. prepare to spend a half day or more at each location. Drink lots of water and prepare to pay to use any public restroom! Have euros on hand, always!
Budgeting: This location is hard to indicate a set budget for because everyone‚Äôs preferences are different. But things you can keep in mind: most everything to see has a fee, coffee and pastries are cheap as they are everywhere in Italy, a fine lunch/dinner can cost anywhere from ‚Ç¨8‚Äì30 per person, and bottles of wine at dinner are CHEAP.
AMALFI COAST
Where to Stay: Our Airbnb was an absolute dream. We were a short bus ride away from central Amalfi and just down the road from a cafe, beach, and a few restaurants. This specific location is on the side of a cliff. Dreamy, but takes a quick downward hike to get to since there aren‚Äôt elevators on the sides of mountains.
Where to Eat: Surprisingly, we only ate two meals in Amalfi. One dinner, and one ‚Äúbreakfast‚Äù, which was actually just a croissant and a cappuccino (the only way to do breakfast in Italy!) The restaurant is, shockingly, not on maps and I can‚Äôt even remember the name. However, if you walk around in the city-center long enough, you‚Äôll find a spot. This is the type of place to leisurely walk around and land upon a spot that captures your attention!
What to Wear: I was genuinely surprised to realize that this is not as much of a ‚Äúbeach town‚Äù as I‚Äôd expected. This is more of a luxurious, million-dollar-making, yacht-owning, white-elitist‚Äôs playground than a beach bum‚Äôs paradise. If you want to keep up, dress up. If not, don‚Äôt. I personally walked around in a swimsuit and shorts all day with my hair in a bun and my face red hot from the sun. But that‚Äôs just me.
Budgeting: Ironically, this specific city isn‚Äôt overwhelmingly expensive unless you‚Äôre staying in one of the high-end resorts. The food is cheap, the beach is free, you can get a few inexpensive bus tickets to take you to local cities like Praiano, Positano and Naples. However, if you‚Äôre not hopping from town to town and you‚Äôre not the stay-in-our-Airbnb-all-day type, you might run out of things to do. The city-center is beautiful to walk through, but isn‚Äôt very large, so keep that in mind when choosing to visit this city or not.
CAPRI
Where to Stay: We stayed in Amalfi‚Äîwe took the ferry to Capri early one morning and returned later that afternoon.
Where to Eat: We only ate one meal in Capri, and it wasn‚Äôt great, so I won‚Äôt mention its location. However, try to find a restaurant off the beaten path because it will be less touristy, better priced and much more delicious. One that was suggested to us by our boat tour skipper was La Canzone Del Mare!
What to Wear: Pretty much everyone is in their swimsuits with a cover-up since the only things to do here are go swimming, boating, tan, drink, and eat. P.S. the sun is HOT so make sure to pack an eco-friendly, organic sunscreen.
Budgeting: Ferries to and from Capri will cost you ‚Ç¨40 per person, a tour to the Blue Grotto varies between ‚Ç¨15‚Äì35, a private boat tour will cost you around ‚Ç¨180, and the food is between ‚Ç¨12‚Äì30 per plate. You‚Äôre looking at a wild day of spending but a mind-blowing array of beauty, so, soak it up!
FLORENCE
Where to Stay: I am not joking when I say that the Duomo is in full sight from this Airbnb. It is steps from the city-center and is equal distance from all the areas you will want to visit.
Where to Eat:
Breakfast/Brunch: Le Vespe Cafe is a zero-waste cafe located in Florence! This place really made my whole day. Their cappuccinos are amazing, too!
Dinner: Osteria dei Centopoveri is a Tuscan restaurant and pizzeria, so any budget will work here! Their pizza and calzones are huge and delicious, so you‚Äôll definitely want to visit more than once! Make sure to order a bottle of local wine‚Äîyou can score an entire bottle of Tuscan wine for only ‚Ç¨15 and they‚Äôll cork it for you to take home if you don‚Äôt finish it!
Gelato: If you don‚Äôt get gelato from Grom, were you even in Florence? It‚Äôs literally rated the best gelato in Florence, so, don‚Äôt miss out. (The best two-scoop mix is chocolate and grom flavor!)
Cocktails: Jazz Club Firenze is one of the top rated spots for drinks and vibes in Florence. Unfortunately, they were closed for holiday when we visited, but if you are in Florence when they are open, you‚Äôve gotta stop by and tell us how it is!
What to Wear: Florence in the summer is quite warm! This is becoming an Italian trend, eh? If you‚Äôre exposing skin (which I recommend, because seriously, it‚Äôs HOT) lather up in sun-screen. From there, you can pretty much wear anything. Florence is a stylish city but what‚Äôs important is being comfortable, since you‚Äôll be on foot all day.
Budgeting: Everything historic has a fee, including the Medici gardens. Unless you‚Äôre ready for a hot hike around the garden, skip it and climb to the top of the Duomo, see the Medici Villas, and visit the museums, instead. You‚Äôre looking at spending between ‚Ç¨50-‚Ç¨100 per person for a day or two of historic venturing. Other inexpensive restuarants are around every corner, you just have to look for them!
MILAN
We were only in Milan for lunch since we passed through it on the way back to Switzerland, but our one suggestion is a good one.
Where to Eat: Do not leave Milan without visiting L√πbar! This is closer to the ‚Ç¨‚Ç¨‚Ç¨ scale, since the plates are small, made to share, and they recommend ordering four or more per person. But, wow, the food and drinks are jaw-dropping good.
Okay, guys. That‚Äôs it! Did I miss anything? Is there anything you have questions about that you‚Äôd like more info on? Let‚Äôs chat! Shoot me a DM on Instagram at any time and let‚Äôs plan your next adventure!

Title: Italian Culture Series: Travelling to Italy?Do as Romans Do
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
So what happens when you land up in the capital of a country, which would have welcomed you with open arms had you not uttered those deadly words right at the onset: ‚ÄúSorry, I don‚Äôt speak Italian!‚ÄùWell, you will definitely be frowned at, ignored, unanswered or just be left on your own - which I am sure nobody would prefer in a vibrant space such as Italy.You can make sure to begin your conversation with at least ‚ÄúScusi‚Äù (Excuse Me‚Äî formal) or with a minimal salutation like ‚ÄúBuongiorno‚Äù or ‚ÄúBuonasera‚Äù. Then, perhaps, you could proceed to tone down your actual question in English by using cue words in Italian, like ‚Äútoilette‚Äù (Italians prefer the french word to their own ‚Äúbagno‚Äù in reference to the washroom) ‚Äúpiazza‚Äù or ‚Äúpizzeria‚Äù ‚Äúristorante‚Äù, so that the local Italian understands quickly what you are referring to.Don‚Äôt be afraid to use Italinglish: ‚Äúscusi, where is ‚Äúristorante‚Äù?‚Äù or something even shorter: ‚ÄúScusi, toilette?‚Äù which will be taken more into consideration than your English version.
Italians like being elaborate when they give directions, as for everything else in life. Be patient and say ‚ÄúScusi, non parlo italiano!‚Äù (Sorry, but i don‚Äôt speak Italian!) which is a table turner. This will immediately make an average Italian rush to your help even if their English is not so good. You must not, however, ever point out to an Italian that their English is not up to the mark! Praise them if you must, criticize them never. And you never know, this might be a great start to a cross-border friendship.You see, Italians take an instant liking to you if you express any sort of interest in their culture and language; they are extremely protective, just like any culture where multiple languages and dialects are spoken, about their native tongue. You‚Äôd be surprised to know that some of their dialects are full fledged languages in themselves, and equally diverse are their traditions which vary greatly from north to south.
Having learnt and then having taught the language to Indians ‚Äì I have had the possibility of meeting many Italians. And I have always felt they might have, a soft spot for India and Indians in general ‚Äì because in a way they are as multi-hued as us and they relate to our cultural diversity. So for them an Indian with even a basic knowledge of their language comes across as someone very ‚Äúfigo‚Äù (an informal slang for ‚Äúcool‚Äù)!
But that is true for anyone who lands in Italy with a basic knowledge of Italian ‚Äì you‚Äôll be befriended at the bar, at the ristorante, in the tassi, in the underground metropolitana, the autobus faster than you can imagine. Don‚Äôt be overwhelmed, and don‚Äôt shy away from engaging with each one as you go. The more you chat, the more you will enjoy this land of wonders.
One last advice: If you really want to enjoy your first, and many more trips to this architecturally and scenically beautiful space ‚Äì you better have your hellos, thank yous and wows in order (‚ÄúCiao‚Äù ‚ÄúGrazie‚Äù and ‚ÄúChe Bello!‚Äù)!So with the first cultural contact established, hope you have a Buon Viaggio in Italia!
--
--
Always looking forward, never back. Multilingual. Poetry aficionado. Content writer. Canadian by choice, Indian at heart.

A few weeks back we asked our followers on Twitter what they think are some of the most loved destinations in Italy. The response was quite incredible.
‚ÄúThis will probably be the easiest question I get to answer all day,‚Äù writes one of our followers after telling us that his favorite destination is Capri, in the Campania region.
Others mentioned their heritage and origins: ‚ÄúCosta Smeralda, Sardegna,‚Äù writes Jonathan, mentioning that his mother is from Santa Teresa di Gallura.
And others admitted ‚Äúit‚Äôs too hard to choose,‚Äù as writes Darlene, whose favorite destinations are Pienza in Tuscany, and Capri and Positano in Campania. ‚ÄúSo tough to choose,‚Äù says Ishita, mentioning Montestigliano in Tuscany.
Kevin didn‚Äôt write anything, but responded with a beautiful photo of Florence.
Here are some additional destinations that our Twitter followers highlighted, from small towns to large areas who every year attract tourists from the US and around the world: Amalfi Coast, Budelli Island, Crotone, Guardia Snaframondi (Benevento), Lucca, Monte Argentario, Napoli, Porto Santo Stefano, Salento, Sicily, Taormina.
In March, the World Travel & Tourism Council (WTTC) said that overall, the total contribution of the travel and tourism industries to the Italian economy was ‚Ç¨223.2 billion in 2017, once all the direct, indirect and induced benefits were taken into account. The report mentioned that, not only Italy is the 6th largest travel economy in the world, but the industry supported 3.4 million jobs in 2017 with an estimate of 4 million jobs by 2028.
So, what is your favorite destination in Italy?

Title: What I‚Äôve Learned Living in Italy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
4
Listen
Share
When I embarked on my Italian wine journey nearly three years ago, I could have never imagined having to face a worldwide health crisis here in Italy, or anywhere, for that matter.
Rather than recount grave tales of the current quarantine situation, I wanted to share what I‚Äôve only now realized my fellow Italian citizens have taught me.
It‚Äôs been said a million times before, but now, more than ever, we need to remember that we cannot predict or control every aspect of our lives. As an American, this is something I‚Äôve found very hard to accept. Living amongst a population of people who contrastingly seem to embrace unpredictability, has shed a spotlight on my inability to do so.
From my first days working on a beautiful vineyard in central Italy, I wanted to know exactly what I‚Äôd be doing when. I‚Äôd inquire about lunchtime, dinner time, and my future tasks for the upcoming week, often met by quizzical and unspecific replies. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll pause for lunch when we‚Äôre done with these rows‚Äù, pointing to an undefined plot of vines, or ‚Äúwhen we pick enough Trebbiano for today,‚Äù the winemaker would tell me.
Gone were the days of living confined to my office calendar, handcuffed to the rigid meetings, scheduled a month or more in advance. Countless more examples in the Italian countryside, as well as in my current city of Bologna, reinforce that Italians innately embrace the present, instead of wasting time obsessing about the future.
This take-things-as-they-come mindset has proven very beneficial in combating hysteria and fear during these now uncertain times of Coronavirus. Italy and the majority of its people are not overly panicking about tomorrow or being frightened by media reports from abroad.
Despite exaggerated accounts, Italians are not hoarding groceries and fighting in stores, as I‚Äôve witnessed with every prediction of 6 inches of snow in the U.S. They focus their energy on dealing with the day at hand, taking time to prepare for the next, but never forgetting to find a few minutes to laugh and be grateful to be alive.
Unless of course, we‚Äôre talking about a football (soccer) match, Italians have shown me that life is much more than a series of back-to-back competitions. In America, we are groomed for competition from birth ‚Äî just look at the insanity surrounding pre-school admissions. Parents in many parts of the US are forced to apply for pre-school the moment their child is born, in fear of being left out in the cold once their child approaches school-age ‚Äî 3 years later.
From elementary school through high school, the competition only increases with each passing year. Immense pressure is put on students to outperform one another, gain entry to the highest classes, most prestigious clubs, teams, and of course colleges. Pre-SATs, SATs, state proficiency exams, and class-rankings pit every student against each other, creating tremendous anxiety and comparisons amongst impressionable teenagers.
In the US, very rarely are students encouraged, or afforded the time, to help one another succeed. Instead, they are told to focus on grades, activities, transcripts and overall peer-group standing. Fierce competition for the few coveted spots at elite and popular universities drives an inordinate amount of stress and do-whatever-it-takes approach. Parents and students resort to insane, sometimes illegal, measures to gain advantages and excel above the next student. Only now, are people finally being held accountable for admissions cheating scandals.
This cut-throat competition and dog-eat-dog mentality does not permeate society in Italy or most parts of Western Europe. Many factors contribute to this of course, but one major reason is that most European universities are public and accessible to all citizens, for free, or very little money. It‚Äôs been truly eye-opening to see how much this one difference can affect a nation‚Äôs culture and mindset of its society.
In Italy, children and teenagers can grow up without the looming fear of college admissions hanging above their heads. I‚Äôd argue, this results in Italians being less individualistic and hostile towards one another, from an early age. Family values are emphasized instead of GPAs, and more time is spent cultivating relationships and passing on priceless traditions. Additionally, students generally dedicate more time to their passions, communities, and appreciation of the arts.
Consequently, many Italian adults have numerous ‚Äújob titles‚Äù, such as a lawyer by day, cheesemaker by night. It‚Äôs also common for people to work across various industries, instead of being pigeonholed into one. The freedom that comes with guaranteed higher education creates more opportunities to become successful in a field of your choosing, rather than a field that can most-efficiently pay off $100k+ student debt ‚Äî as is often the case in America.
While competition is, of course, healthy, especially in business, I think we Americans often forget that life itself is not a competition. We must strive for meaningful lives ‚Äî not only aim for high test scores, job-titles, and bank accounts, simply to out-shine the next person.
Italy‚Äôs economy is far from perfect, however, living in this country during good times, and recent times of difficulty has proven to me that quality of life defines a country much more than its GDP. Italians have come together to face this crisis as a unified and optimistic society, something I‚Äôm very proud to be a part of, now, more than ever.
#Andr√†tuttobene ‚Äî Everything will be alright.

Title: Hub and Spoke in Italy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
We‚Äôve learned to enjoy the ‚Äúhub and spoke‚Äù approach to travel. We pick a hub town to stay several days and then plan day trips out from there. That way, we immerse ourselves in one location and aren‚Äôt moving every other day. This style of travel provides a more comfortable, relaxed pace.
A good hub is an interesting town located in the center of an area with sights around it. You‚Äôre looking for a spot that allows you easy day trips to other locations. We picked general areas and then zoomed in to look for interesting Airbnb possibilities.
We‚Äôll land in Venice at Marco Polo Airport and take a shuttle to the rental car place. I used Kayak to find quotes and make a reservation. We didn‚Äôt need a big car (and good luck driving one on tiny European roads anyway). Plus, gas is expensive. I‚Äôve read Italian drivers are intense but at least we‚Äôll be on the familiar side of the road. If we can drive in Ireland, we can drive anywhere.
We‚Äôll do a counter-clockwise circuit through northern and central Italy beginning in the hill town of Feltre. That will provide us a base to explore the Dolomites in the Italian Alps. Then we‚Äôll head west to Torno on Lake Como and south to the Cinque Terre on the Mediterranean. We‚Äôll then go southeast into Tuscany to a village near Siena before finishing for a week back in Venice.
We‚Äôve used Airbnb to stay in unique homes across Germany, Ireland and the US. Often, the prices are much lower than hotels, especially as you add more people. Plus, you get a whole place to yourself, lots of privacy, more bathrooms and a kitchen for cooking. Most importantly, you‚Äôre more integrated into the everyday life of the place you‚Äôre visiting.
We use search filters to specify we‚Äôre looking to rent an entire place plus request key amenities like Wifi, washing machine and the number of beds/baths we need. The calendar for each place shows availability.
You can rate and review places you‚Äôve stayed. You‚Äôre also rated by the renters as a guest. It‚Äôs a self-monitoring system similar to eBay. You converse with the owner directly and can negotiate the price, especially if you stay multiple days (another reason to hub and spoke your trip).
The village of Feltre in the Veneto is our first hub. It‚Äôs located about an hour-and-a-half drive north of Venice with the Dolomites serving as a dramatic backdrop. The plan is to explore the mountains and nearby towns like Bassano Del Grappa and Trento.
After three nights in Feltre, we‚Äôll meander west along the mountains to the lake district. We‚Äôll stay for a week in an old villa along Lake Como in the village of Torno. Along with the lakeside towns of Bellagio and Como, we‚Äôll plan on making day trips to Milan, Mantua and Bergamo.
Here‚Äôs an example of how we used Airbnb to find our place in Torno. We wanted to stay around the lake and used the map feature. Once you zoom in on specific homes/apartments, you can view photos and research the area.
Yes, that looks pretty good! After a week around the lake, we‚Äôll then head south toward the Ligurian coast on the Mediterranean for three days.
Cinque Terre is a string of five centuries-old villages featuring colorful houses and vineyards clinging to the rugged coastline. We‚Äôre looking forward to riding the slow train that connects each of the towns and then exploring from the sea by taking the boat service.
After our stay along the sea, we‚Äôll head inland to the heart of Tuscany. We found a villa in the middle of vineyards roughly 30 minutes west of Siena. This will provide us a base to explore large sights like Florence, Pisa and Lucca as well as smaller Tuscan hill towns like Monteriggioni, Pistoia and Civita.
Here‚Äôs how I used Google Maps to tag interesting ‚Äúspoke‚Äù sights around our five hubs locations. We‚Äôre not planning on visiting this many places but it gives me a good list from which to choose once we‚Äôre in Italy. I color-coded sights by hub. With my Google Map on the cloud, I can pull this up while on the road and we can explore. This is where pre-trip research is key.
For example, we‚Äôre planning on visiting Arezzo to the east of Siena to take in a big market held on the first weekend in October. I tagged the location and we should be able to find it with minimal trouble.
We‚Äôll wrap up our Italian tour with a week in Venice. We found an Airbnb in a quieter, less-touristed sestiere (neighborhood). I‚Äôm looking forward to having time to just explore. Early mornings and late evenings this time of year should be much less crowded. I‚Äôm not sure you can ever soak in enough Venice.
My next post should be from Italy on Thursday if the Wifi situation cooperates. Until then, arrivederci!
‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.
Thanks again for following along. If you have questions or suggestions, tweet @JasonRMatheson. Missed an entry? Click here.

I hope this update finds you well.
I‚Äôve been back from Italy for about six weeks and am still in the process of digesting all my learning from my trip. It was a fantastic experience, and I‚Äôm glad to have had my first international experience.
I will continue to update this article with photos from different days of the trip as time goes on. Nevertheless, I wanted to publish this partially completed version so as to ensure it doesn‚Äôt end up in my drafts, never to be shared with the world.
Enjoy this post,
Josh
**********
THE TRAVEL PLANS
The plan was to visit Italy for just over three weeks, with a few days at Rome prior to joining a Tour of Italy for two weeks, with a return to Rome for an extra six or so days at the end of the tour.
We completed the Italy‚Äôs best tour with Cosmos. The tour in our trip saw us complete the following:
(Source: http://www.globaljourneys.com.au/images/maps/cosmos/europe/italy/2016/6390.jpg)
Places visited:
**********
TAKING A TRAVEL JOURNAL
I decided to take a travel journal to reflect both on my learning, and also to collect receipts, business cards, postcards, holy cards and other trinkets as I toured the country. All in all, I ended up with so much stuff I had to pack all the material collected separately, but there was a lot of value in journalling.
The travel journal I used was made by Typo and can be purchased here:
http://cottonon.com/US/p/typo/the-wanderer-travel-journal/2013463501982.html#start=1
Whilst I didn‚Äôt use all of the sections on this tour, I did make use of the following sections:
What follows is my notes from the notes, daily adventures, things I learnt along the way, and second notes sections. I have interspersed photos, post-travel commentary and other relevant pieces of information to make these more useful for future reference.
**********

29/06/16
We‚Äôre leaving tomorrow morning. I‚Äôm starting to pack and get things ready now, following my usual, last minute routine.
I‚Äôm looking forward to heading off, and am glad to finally be on holidays from work.
Requests to complete for people while I‚Äôm away:
Post-travel note: I made a video for each of these requests on my iPhone and sent them to the people concerned before I returned home.

My first ever view of an international country (Hong Kong) from a plane.
We‚Äôve survived our trip from Australia to Hong Kong. Shortly we will be boarding our second flight, which will take us to Rome.
I‚Äôve followed Courtney‚Äôs advice and kept awake thus far. If I can push myself a few hours more and then sleep on the plane I should be close to achieving Rome‚Äôs time with my body clock.
I purchased a 500 ml Coke whilst here, which cost 28 Hong Kong dollars. There was a girl here who unrolled her yoga mat and proceeded to do a lot of poses‚Ä¶ I was amazed by her flexibility. I have contacted Vanessa.
Whilst on the plane I watched:
I had chicken and rice and nearly choked on an asparagus-like vegetable. I also had pork noodles, which were nice.
Praise God for this wonderful opportunity.

I‚Äôm on the plane and we are a few hours from landing in Rome. Sleep has been nearly impossible on this plane, so I‚Äôm going to be suffering from jet lag when we arrive.
So far the food on this flight hasn‚Äôt been as good as the prior one. Nevertheless, things are more exciting now.
I watched the movie for ‚Äòthe Entourage‚Äô on this flight, read some more of ‚ÄòThe Imitation of Christ‚Äô, completed this journal entry and tried to sleep, albeit unsuccessfully.
At Rome:
We went to our accommodation and checked in our bags, as we can‚Äôt access our room until 2:00pm. From there, we checked out the Pantheon, the St. Ignatius Church (photos of the roof below), some other churches and Trevi Fountain.
We had lunch @ Vacanza Romana. First impression of Italian Pizzas is that D.O.C. in Australia is very authentic.
Also, my rosary broke but I seem to have been able to fix it.
We went for a walk again later in the day. Whilst doing this, we stumbled upon a Mass, where I went up for a blessing from the priest. Prior to that, we had Galati from a place at Trevi Fountain, which was amazing.
We also checked out some Roman ruins at the end of our hotel‚Äôs street earlier in the day.

After hearing a sermon on 1 Timothy 2:4 (God desires all men to be saved and to come to a knowledge of the truth), I knew I could not accept an understanding that requires two wills in God or the verse to be interpreted to mean, ‚Äòall elect men‚Äô, not ‚Äòall men‚Äô.
