Keenan‚Äôs Adventures, travels, and wordly outtings

--
Listen
Share
Departing Zermatt was unfortunate but necessary. We had seen the Matterhorn so there wasn‚Äôt anything else we could do with Yuki‚Äôs parents like hiking, biking or parasailing. We got up extra early to take the Train from Zermatt to Brig, anticipating that the 7 minute change at Brig would not be enough time. It ended up being more than enough time and after arriving an hour early, there was also a train to Domodossola, Italy, that we were able to take. There wasn‚Äôt, however, a train from Domodossola to Milano so we had to wait an hour in Domodossola instead of Brig. This wasn‚Äôt too bad because we ate another lunch of hard boiled eggs on rice and walked around the street market just outside the station.
Our initial impression of Italy was that it seemed to be a lot like Paris, only rougher with stone sidewalks and cobblestone streets. It was busy like Paris and there was clearly a wide disparity in wealth from beggars upwards unlike Switzerland which felt empty, organized, clean, and safe.
The train to Milano was very scenic. I drafted up some blog posts but also admired the beautiful scenery. Not far from Domodossola are some turquoise blue lakes and romanesque architecture with clay tile roofs that look like they could be easily centuries old. This got me exited for the next two weeks of seeing old architecture. The view became steadily less interesting as we approached more urban areas and soon we were in Milano.
Milano station was where be found out that the Italians are poor at scheduling. The train stations have large digital display boards with the departure and arrival of all the trains but they look exactly like the old school letter flipping boards. The departure platform for a train might not be displayed until 15‚Äì20 minutes before departure and that creates a mad scramble of people who were all waiting around the display board craning their necks up like weird penguins. The people swarm towards the platform, not unlike an unbalanced crowed of birds because they are all pulling along baggage. This occurs ever 5‚Äì10 minutes. When one train of people leaves, another arrives to refill the crowd around the departure board.
The train to Venice wasn‚Äôt all that interesting because it was mostly through urban areas that are noticeably modern but still in the same romanesque style of plaster brick walls and red tiled roofs. It‚Äôs actually a little like Asia; you can tell that the buildings are modern but they‚Äôre rundown and stained. To pass the time, I played the one Ipad game I‚Äôd bought for the trip, Dragonfall.
We arrived in Venice around 5pm and had a 30 minute, 2km walk to the hotel. Yuki had google mapped the route the night before and taken screen shots so that we could get there. I‚Äôm sure that it took us much longer to get to the hotel as every time we cross a canal we had to lift our suitcases over little pedestrian bridges. Between canals, we scooted down narrow alley ways that widened and narrowed like a child‚Äôs drawing who couldn‚Äôt draw straight.
Eventually we got to the hotel, tired and hungry. Checking in was straight forward and we were taken to our room around the corner that was a king bed and a folding bunk bed. Yuki and I were dejected to find out that we had booked another common room for the four of us. On our last trip to South Korea with her parents we‚Äôd been careful to book our own separate room whenever possible. For some reason, while planning this trip we forgot about that and ended up booking everything but Paris as a single room with four beds to save costs. We regretted this decision and were suddenly filled with low morale. Note to self: always book a separate room no matter the cost, It‚Äôs worth the brain cells and reduced stress.
This hotel in Venice only had wifi in the lobby and even there it was pretty crappy. I tried finding a highly rated restaurant on google maps but google doesn‚Äôt have most of the restaurants in Venice and what I found didn‚Äôt exist so we ate at the hotel‚Äôs restaurant.
The food was okay but not to our liking. We all had seafood dishes but there was very little seafood in each dish, it was mostly lobster or shrimp shell. The good part of the meal was that we got 35% off for being a guest at the hotel so the meal was pretty cheap.
Where the hotel lacked in dinner food it more than made up for at breakfast. We had an excellent self-serve buffet breakfast at the hotel that had cereal, breads, and fresh fruit. It was my favourite breakfast thus far and I finished early to take a quick walk around the end of the island we were staying at. The light had looked good for photographs but I was a little late and didn‚Äôt see anything worth photographing. On the way back to the hotel I did pass an American model and a film crew that I think they were doing a commercial.
We planned for one day in Venice to walk around as Yuki had been informed, there‚Äôs enough to do spend one day in Venice but two days would be excessive. This is because there are so many alleys, plazas, and bridges that they all blend together.
Our first stop was to get to the Plaza S. Marco. This is the most famous and the largest in Venice. We took lots of pictures and then went into the Basilica S. Marco. At the door Yuki was asked to wear a scarf because her skirt was above her knees. Other tourists were given thin blankets to cover up but beyond the lady at the door checking people none of the tourists seemed to actually bothered keeping themselves ‚Äúdecent‚Äù. Yuki thought it was going to be free but it was 5 Euro/person. It was worthwhile though, because at the top we got a view of the plaza from the roof. When 11 o‚Äôclock rolled around we got to watch the clock animate and brass figurines hit the bells to ring them.
As it was Sunday, there was a service in the main hall. There was a choir and a lot of singing that sounded wonderful in the cavernous space. This Basilica was more interesting than Norte Dame because it also had a museum where we could get up close to some of the artwork. The entire interior of the cathedral is covered in little tiles, most of which is backgrounded in gold. Though the museum signs have english, it didn‚Äôt make a lot of sense so after a while we stopped reading them and instead stood in the main hall to listen to the music of the mass.
Around the corner from the Plaza S. Marco we found a small gelato store and got two scoops on a cone. The Gelato here was incredible and significantly tastier, smoother and better than Canada. This shouldn‚Äôt have be a surprise, given that gelato originated in Italy, but it wasn‚Äôt something that I had expected before taking my first lick.
Wandering on, we crossed the famous Rialto bridge and then had lunch at an outdoor cafe beside the canal. The food was pretty good. Yuki had lasagna and I had a spinach salad with dried fruits, bacon, and a really interesting cheese. We also ordered Spritz Apoele, a popular drink in Italy that everyone seemed to be drinking. It wasn‚Äôt my favourite but it wasn‚Äôt bad either.
After lunch we headed towards the train station to get tickets for the next day‚Äôs train, stopping for more gelato on the way. We were very grateful to have the help of a young woman with the ticket machine and decided to also get most of our other tickets for the trip because we had her to guide us through the process. This girl was really helpful and turned what could have been a very frustrating and difficult situation into an understandable time.
For future reference, its best to book train tickets at least two days in advance. The prices are cheaper by a significant amount and the train isn‚Äôt full yet. The day before or the day of, tickets are more expensive and seating is difficult to find.
From the train station we walked back to the hotel and had a brief rest. When we were hungry, we went out and walked the streets again in search of a good restaurant. The cafe restaurant we choose had a good proportion of food and lost of seafood in the dish but the ambience wasn‚Äôt as nice. Still, I enjoyed the meal and the 1/2 bottle of white wine I ordered. Yuki had to help me finish it.
We had another great breakfast at the hotel and then left early for the train station to ensure that our slowness did not make us late. Leaving Venice was a lot easier than arriving. On the way back to the hotel the day before I‚Äôd found a route that had ramps over the bridges so we were able to return to the train station with half of the bridges turned into ramps and fewer canals to carry our bags over than before.
We arrived 40 minutes early and waited for the train platform. Annoyingly, the car numbers on the side of the train were different from the TV screens on the platform so we and several others got on the wrong car. We were able to get off and onto the right car with a little stress and hassle and were happy to be settle into our seats for the journey back to Milano.
The train was 30 minutes late because of some police incident so we only had around 15 minutes to change trains in Milano. When we got on the train, Yuki‚Äôs bag was open, an unsuccessful attempt at a pickpocket, and somehow papers from Yuki‚Äôs Dad‚Äôs inside breast pocket ended up on the table. I think there were two girls that opened Yuki‚Äôs bag while we were getting on the train and when we got to our seats, instead of sitting down to get out of everyone‚Äôs way Yuki‚Äôs Dad stepped right in the middle of the crowd and those two girls took the papers out but then left them on the table because they weren‚Äôt valuable.
We double checked our valuables a nothing was gone so that was good. The rest of the train ride to Levanto was mostly uneventful. We chatted with an Australian couple and anguished over not having any food so we were quite hungry when we arrived in Levanto around 5pm. We talked with the tourist office and got a map to walk to the hotel. It turns out that the hotel is run by a travel agency that also manages a B&B and a few apartments. For unknown reasons they upgraded us from a studio hotel to a one bedroom apartment with the ocean view. This was a huge boost to our morale and made us very happy.
The apartment was on the third floor and had a balcony with a view of the beach and the ocean. It was particularly nice to sit out and watch the sunset. The apartment also gave Yuki and I a private room and there was a much needed laundry machine that we used daily during our stay.
Internet was interesting, they gave us a portable modem with a little battery. I suspect that it ran on data and could, conceivably, be taken out to the beach or where ever but we left it plugged in beside the bed.
I‚Äôd asked the lady from the travel agency for a good restaurant and she recommended the one across the street so we went there for dinner. It was without a doubt the best meal so far. I had 5 grilled shrimp, Yuki had seafood ravioli and Yuki‚Äôs dad had the best mixed seafood calamari ever. To top it off, I had a great 1/2 bottle of white wine and Yuki got a very sweet white wine that her dad finished in two swings. We should have gotten more of that wine because we weren‚Äôt able to find it again.

Touching down in Italy for the first time was simply magical. The warm Mediterranean breeze greeted me as I stepped off the plane, carrying with it tantalizing hints of freshly baked pizza and rich espresso. My senses were immediately awakened by the vibrant hues of the landscape and the animated chatter in melodic Italian. Rome‚Äôs bustling street life unfurled before me with scooter-filled alleyways, ancient ruins peeking around burgeoning modernity, and lively piazzas brimming with locals and tourists alike. It was here, while savoring a creamy gelato beside the majestic Colosseum, that I first fell in love with Italy‚Äôs intoxicating blend of history and contemporary charm.
Wandering through Italy‚Äôs cities revealed a tapestry of experiences that surpassed all my expectations. From the romantic canals of Venice to the artistic fervor of Florence, and the fashion-forward streets of Milan, each city possessed its own unique character and allure. The locals‚Äô warm hospitality made me feel like I was welcomed into a large, extended family, eager to share their rich cultural heritage. I was captivated by the seamless way ancient monuments coexisted with modern conveniences, creating urban landscapes that felt both timeless and vibrant. What truly surprised me was how every corner of Italy offered something different; a culinary delight, a hidden historical gem, or a breathtaking view that left me in awe.
Italy‚Äôs cities are like a playground for the curious traveler, each offering a distinct set of adventures waiting to be discovered. Join me as we delve into the top 10 must-visit cities across this enchanting country. Buckle up for a journey through Italy‚Äôs urban gems, where history whispers through cobblestone streets and modernity pulses through lively markets and trendy cafes.
Although the post describes 10 experiences in , Italy, you can explore 2947 experiences in , as well as thousands of other cities across the globe on Travel Ninja. Watch the video below for more information, and download the app at Travel Ninja.
Stepping off the plane in Rome felt like diving into a living, breathing history lesson drenched in vibrant modernity. The first thing that struck me was the timeless grandeur of the architecture ‚Äî ancient ruins stood majestically beside chic boutiques and lively cafes. As I strolled through the bustling streets, I encountered a fascinating blend of people: tourists eagerly snapping photos at the Colosseum, locals animatedly chatting in small piazzas, and street performers adding an artistic flair to the atmosphere. The hum of scooters zipping by and the welcoming aroma of freshly baked pizza were a sensory delight. I managed my expenses well, finding accommodations in a charming mid-range B&B for around ‚Ç¨80 a night and enjoying delicious meals for approximately ‚Ç¨10-‚Ç¨20 per meal.
During an early morning exploration, the usually crowded Trevi Fountain was serene and almost ethereal in the soft dawn light. It was then that I met a couple from Argentina, and we shared our travel stories over espresso, marveling at the fusion of Rome‚Äôs ancient roots with its contemporary vibe. The energy shifted noticeably during the off-hours; the city seemed to breathe a sigh of relief, offering a more intimate glimpse into its heart. This visit made me appreciate how Rome thrives on its contrasts ‚Äî tradition and modernity, hustle and tranquility ‚Äî all of which are seamlessly woven together in its cultural tapestry. This immersion deepened my admiration for the city and gave me a richer understanding of its unique social fabric.
Exploring Venice felt like stepping into a living painting. The narrow, winding streets blend seamlessly with majestic canals, buzzing with vaporettos and gondolas. At every corner, there‚Äôs a mix of excited tourists and locals casually sipping espressos or chatting in lilting Italian. With a budget of ‚Ç¨50 a day, I savored delicious cicchetti at vibrant bacari, sipping Spritz Aperol and marveling over Saint Mark‚Äôs Basilica‚Äôs intricate mosaics. The blend of ancient architecture and contemporary life is stunning. Venice is both a historical marvel and a hub of modern energy.
Dawn strolls across the Rialto Bridge, practically deserted, offered me quiet moments to soak in the serene beauty. One delightful incident involved a cheerful American couple who, upon sharing their map, eagerly guided me to the lesser-known Fondaco dei Tedeschi terrace. We debated the best gelato flavors while marveling at the panoramic view. Interactions like these made me realize how Venice serves as a meeting point of cultures, fostering camaraderie among strangers. The trip deepened my appreciation for how Venetians preserve their rich heritage while embracing the cosmopolitan vibe ‚Äî it‚Äôs a city where tradition beautifully dances with modernity. Can‚Äôt wait for your stories!
Upon arriving in Florence, the city greeted me with an intoxicating mix of history and vibrant modern life. The cobblestone streets whispered tales of the Renaissance as Vespa scooters buzzed by, creating a lively, eclectic atmosphere. Walking towards the heart of the city, I marveled at the grandeur of the Duomo, its pink and green marble facade glistening in the sunlight. The bustling Piazza della Signoria was a feast for the senses ‚Äî gelato shops with their rainbow assortments, the grandeur of Palazzo Vecchio, and street musicians playing classical melodies. With my stepping counter enthusiastically tallying more than 15,000 steps, I felt every euro spent was worth it ‚Äî entrance fees to museums (‚Ç¨15‚Äì20 each) and delicious meals at cozy trattorias (‚Ç¨10‚Äì15 per meal).
As evening fell, the city transformed into a romantically lit wonderland. Less crowded now, I wandered along the banks of the Arno River, the Ponte Vecchio glowing under the streetlights. I struck up a conversation with a couple from Brazil at a quaint wine bar, and we swapped travel stories over a glass of Chianti (‚Ç¨5). The blend of tradition met modernity beautifully here, from historic architecture to chic boutiques. This juxtaposition deepened my appreciation for the city‚Äôs dynamic character. Florence isn‚Äôt just a relic of the past; it‚Äôs a living, breathing city, full of creativity and life. My experience was an eye-opener to the cultural depth of Florence, where each encounter, be it with locals or fellow travelers, is a brushstroke in a rich, colorful canvas.
Walking through Milan feels like stepping into a living blend of history and modernity. My visit began at the awe-inspiring Duomo di Milano, a gothic cathedral that pierced the sky with its spires. As I marveled at its intricate facades, the bustling Piazza del Duomo spread before me, where chic locals mingled with eager tourists. The energy was palpable, with street performers adding to the vibrant ambiance. For a reasonable 10 euros, I ascended to the rooftop, where the city‚Äôs panorama offered glimpses of both medieval structures and contemporary skyscrapers. I‚Äôve never felt such a unique blend of past and present.
Exploring the streets, I encountered high-end fashion boutiques nestled beside centuries-old cafes, symbolizing Milan‚Äôs knack for harmonizing tradition with the avant-garde. An evening aperitivo in the Navigli district was an unforgettable experience ‚Äî think canal-side bars with a backdrop of golden sunsets, a spread of delicious appetizers for just 12 euros, and lively conversations with fellow travelers from all over the world. I exchanged stories with an architect from Tokyo who came to Milan to study its renowned design styles. These interactions and the city‚Äôs dynamic atmosphere deepened my appreciation for Milan‚Äôs role as a global cultural hub. Even during the quieter hours, the city‚Äôs spirit remained vibrant, resonating with the whispers of history intertwined with the buzz of contemporary life.
Naples, ah, what an unforgettable adventure it was! Stepping off the train, the city welcomed me with its vibrant and bustling energy. The air felt electric, rich with the smell of fresh pizza wafting through narrow, cobblestone streets lined with Vespas and ancient buildings, effortlessly blending the old with the new. I found myself among a varied crowd ‚Äî from stylishly dressed locals to backpacking tourists, all contributing to a chaotic, yet harmonious atmosphere. A slice of authentic Margherita pizza cost me a modest 4 euros and was worth every penny. As I meandered through the cities alleyways, I stumbled upon an impromptu street performance that turned a casual evening into a lively, shared experience, underscoring Naples‚Äô vibrant social culture.
During quieter moments, like early mornings before the city fully awakes, I could almost hear the whispers of history amidst the stillness. Walking along the waterfront, with Mount Vesuvius majestically framing the skyline, I felt a mixture of awe and peace. An encounter with a friendly fellow traveler at a small, family-run caf√© led to an intriguing conversation about Naples‚Äô transformation over the years. Their insights into the juxtaposition of the city‚Äôs time-honored traditions with modern flair deepened my appreciation for Naples‚Äô unique character ‚Äî a city where past and present coexist in perfect symphony. Whether exploring the ancient ruins of Pompeii just a train ride away, or marveling at contemporary street art, Naples enchanted me with its seamless blend of history, culture, and vitality.
Stepping into Amalfi felt like walking straight into a living postcard. Nestled between the rugged cliffs and cerulean waters, the town exudes both nostalgia and vibrant energy. The atmosphere was intoxicating ‚Äî sun-drenched piazzas brimming with locals and tourists alike, mingling as the scent of fresh lemon groves wafted through the air. With a budget of around ‚Ç¨120 per day, I managed to grab gelato on the bustling main street and watched as couples and families chatter animatedly over espresso at sidewalk cafes. The quaint shops boasted everything from hand-painted ceramics to luxurious silk scarves, standing as a testament to Amalfi‚Äôs seamless blend of tradition with modern splendor.
Despite the lively crowds, there were tranquil moments during the early morning and late afternoon. Wandering through the narrow alleyways when they were almost deserted, I felt an intimate connection to the soul of the town. An elder local, noticing my curiosity about the stunning Duomo di Sant‚ÄôAndrea, shared tales of the cathedral‚Äôs storied past, enriching my appreciation for its architectural grandeur. As evening fell, I joined a group of fellow travelers at a small trattoria where we feasted on fresh seafood and homemade pasta for less than ‚Ç¨30 each. Our conversations flowed effortlessly, bridging diverse backgrounds and languages. This encounter illuminated Amalfi‚Äôs unique charm ‚Äî a place where time-honored traditions coexist with the thriving pulse of contemporary life, fostering a deep sense of belonging and community. My visit wasn‚Äôt just a trip; it was a gateway to understanding the rich, multifaceted culture of Amalfi.
Stepping off the train at Sorrento felt like walking into a sun-drenched painting. The narrow streets burst with vibrant colors ‚Äî blue and yellow tiles lining the walls, vivid bougainvillea spilling over canopies. The air was a divine blend of citrus and sea salt, creating an intoxicating atmosphere that was both grounding and exhilarating. I strolled along the bustling Piazza Tasso, where locals and tourists melded in a lively dance of conversation. For just about 15 Euros, I enjoyed the creamiest gelato as I soaked in the scene ‚Äî a symphony of clinking glasses, laughing children, and the occasional Vespa zipping by. The town harmonizes timeworn traditions with modern charm effortlessly, from ancient architecture to chic cafes.
Off-hours revealed a quieter, more contemplative side of Sorrento. Early mornings were my favorite, as I wandered the virtually empty Marina Grande. The fishermen were returning with their catch, exchanging hearty greetings in musical Neapolitan dialects. A friendly local named Marco invited me to join a small group savoring freshly-cooked seafood ‚Äî free of charge! His stories of Sorrento‚Äôs history deepened my appreciation for the town‚Äôs timeless energy. Interacting with other visitors from around the globe, I relished discussions that ranged from travel tips to cultural insights. This unexpected camaraderie made me realize how Sorrento is not just a destination but a confluence of life, tradition, and modern pleasures that bring people together.
Walking through the cobblestone streets of Verona, the city feels alive with history and a touch of romantic whimsy. The air is filled with the soft hum of conversation, a symphony of Italian laced with laughter and the clang of espresso cups at corner cafes. The first thing that captures my attention is the Arena di Verona, an ancient Roman amphitheater that stands testament to both Verona‚Äôs past and its vibrant present as it still hosts operas and concerts. With a budget of around ‚Ç¨30 for a guided tour and another ‚Ç¨15 for a cappuccino and pastry at a charming caf√©, I felt like I was living in a dream. The blend of medieval architecture with chic boutiques and restaurants painted a vivid contrast of tradition and modernity.
As the evening sun dipped below the horizon, I wandered into a quaint piazza where locals gathered for aperitivo. The mix of people ‚Äî from elderly couples to young professionals and curious tourists like myself ‚Äî added a rich tapestry of stories and energy. Striking up a conversation with a fellow traveler from Brazil, we shared thoughts on Juliet‚Äôs House and whether touching her statue really brings love luck. As the night deepened, so did my appreciation for Verona‚Äôs fusion of past and present; its traditional roots were palpable even as the city embraced a contemporary, globalized spirit. This visit wasn‚Äôt just a sightseeing trip; it was a soulful dive into a culture that balances heritage and modernity with grace and flair. If you‚Äôre planning your trip, set aside some time to simply absorb and enjoy Verona‚Äôs unique vibe.
Walking through the charming streets of Bologna, I felt like I had stepped into a living, breathing museum. The terracotta-roofed buildings, medieval towers, and long porticoes painting a fascinating blend of the old and new. The energy was palpable as locals darted through Piazza Maggiore on their morning errands while tourists marveled at the Basilica di San Petronio. I joined in, exploring on foot, and ended up having an impromptu coffee chat with a group of friendly university students. They introduced me to the best gelato in town, costing only ‚Ç¨2.50, and shared stories of studying in this historic yet dynamic city.
As the day turned into night, Bologna transformed. The streets bustled with an eclectic mix of people ‚Äî young professionals unwinding after work, street performers enchanting passersby, and elderly couples strolling hand in hand. Dinner at a local trattoria, where I spent about ‚Ç¨15 for a plate of tagliatelle al rag√π, was an absolute delight. It was here that I met a Dutch couple who were on a culinary tour of Italy. Our lively conversation about Bolognese traditions versus their modern aspirations gave me a deeper appreciation for Bologna‚Äôs unique character. By the late evening, as the city quieted down, I appreciated the serene yet lively ambiance that made Bologna feel like a timeless gem waiting to be discovered over and over again.
Imagine stepping into a kaleidoscope of vibrant colors and intoxicating sounds as you walk through the bustling streets of Palermo. The aroma of freshly baked sfincione ‚Äî a local-style pizza ‚Äî mingles with the scent of citrus from the vendors at the Ballar√≤ Market. With a modest budget of ‚Ç¨50 a day, I indulged in street food, savored an espresso at an alfresco caf√©, and soaked up the local atmosphere. The streets were a lively mix of tourists and locals, each bringing their unique flair to the city‚Äôs intricate mosaic. The chatter in various dialects, combined with the honking of scooters zipping through narrow alleys, created a symphony that was quintessentially Palermo.
By evening, the city transitioned into a different rhythm. The grand Teatro Massimo was serenely lit, casting a majestic glow over the piazza. I met a fellow traveler from Argentina, and we shared our awe over Palermo‚Äôs confluence of ancient history and modern vitality. Wandering through the charming streets after hours, I marveled at how the city retained its old-world charm amidst modern cafes and boutiques. This visit truly deepened my appreciation for Palermo‚Äôs unique blend of tradition and innovation, making it a city that‚Äôs as timeless as it is contemporary. If you‚Äôre planning to visit, do spend an evening chatting with locals to fully savor this rich cultural tapestry.
As you can see, Italy is brimming with incredible experiences waiting to be discovered. But this is just the tip of the iceberg! Title: Is Life in Italy beautiful?
Content:

This article was originally published in Spanish and you are invited to read it as well in my beautiful language here
I am not a psychologist. I could read a bunch of books to find answers to questions like why we enjoy dreaming, and why we love idealizing places, people, and situations‚Ä¶ but I‚Äôm too lazy to do that.
All I know is that if you idealize your life, it‚Äôs probably because you like living in a self-generated Matrix avoiding some problem, denying it, or worse, you‚Äôve always lived that way.
Nowadays, however, we have a huge choice of online resources, and it‚Äôs possible to get a real sense of what a place might be like: ideal for living or vacationing, boring or lively, safe or dangerous. You have the chance to even interact with its inhabitants long distance or, simply ask travelers about their experiences.
A few months ago a video of a girl went viral because she was complaining about how to get to Amalfi. She said she had to fly to Naples, take a train to Sorrento, a ferry to Amalfi, and finally climb lots of stairs to reach her hotel ‚Äî all this in the height of summer, with that heat! Can you believe it?
She said influencers should be jailed for saying things that aren‚Äôt true‚Ä¶ (deep breath‚Ä¶)
Here‚Äôs the thing: living is easy with eyes closed, but today you don‚Äôt have excuses. You have to be in the here and now. Whether it‚Äôs Instagram, YouTube, a book, or an article, you must remember that someone‚Äôs version of a place or an experience is subjective and probably idealized. You need to be aware that what you‚Äôre being sold on social media is either driven by economic convenience or because the person in question is feeding their delusion, trying to rope others into their fantasy.
You can‚Äôt plan your vacations, your life, or your career based on the ideas others give you. You have to go out into the world, connect with people, try, smell, ask, think critically, question, and then decide what to think, how to act, what to do, and where to go.
Mistakes are always lurking around the corner ‚Äî you should always keep that in mind ‚Äî but I can assure you that you‚Äôll feel less frustrated knowing that you did everything yourself and consciously made the effort for your project to succeed.
Having said all this, I imagine you now understand why I said ‚ÄúNo‚Äù in response to the title of this article.
But maybe I‚Äôm not so good at explaining my thesis, so here it is:
No, it‚Äôs not beautiful in Italy or anywhere else if you‚Äôve decided to see life through filters, through the eyes of others ‚Äî call them dream sellers, rich kids who study or live abroad, or immigrants who haven‚Äôt adapted to a new lifestyle or who‚Äôve endured years of bitterness before achieving a decent standard of living and showing it off to you.
Life is beautiful only when you look at it with your own eyes and your ideas. It‚Äôs beautiful with both the good and the bad ‚Äî not just when you see it through the Deep Summer filter.
Wake up!

For me, it means skipping all the tourist places, wondering around the streets with a camera ‚Äî walking for many miles each day, just looking at the buildings and the people. For my daughter, it means going to museums and other tourist attractions. For her, it mean eating in restaurants to try out new tastes. Title: When in Rome‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäMy Experience in Italy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
I took a three-day trip to Italy on New Years. It was always my dream to visit the great Ancient Rome, so you can imagine how excited I was for this trip. Throughout my visit, I experienced some wonderful places, great food, and met new people. I want to share with you the rookie mistakes that I made, the things I did right, and ultimately what I learned from this experience. Here are some tips for navigating your way through the beautiful city of Rome.
Pack well (and right!!): Extra clothes, check, portable charger, check, type C, F, and L power outlet plugs, not check. Seriously, I spent the first half of my day there looking for electronic stores with the correct power outlet adapters. I made a rookie mistake, and hopefully, you will not have to.
Don‚Äôt pay extra. If anyone tries to convince you that you have to pay to get into the Vatican, I will assure you that you don‚Äôt. As soon as I arrived at the Vatican, I was unpleasantly approached by a man who apparently had only two tickets left to sell for the Vatican. Most might think that they ‚Äúgot lucky‚Äù and that they had just made it there in time before tickets were sold out, but that isn‚Äôt the case at all. Just keep your head up and walk right into the Vatican. It‚Äôs free. Thankfully, binge-watching travel videos on youtube helped me with that one.
Take lots of pictures. If you are traveling along, you can even ask tourists to take photos of you! As a solo traveler, I had plenty of time to soak in all the views and take my time appreciating all the sights and wonders. It is nice to take some pictures so you can reminisce later (who knows when you‚Äôll be back). If you want to take some pictures of yourself, ask tourists if they‚Äôd be willing to take it for you, you‚Äôd be surprised how much photography talent there is in the crowd. If you see someone who could use a hand, offer to help them take their picture, they might offer to take yours back. Well, hey, it worked for me.
Plan well! I packed my day with wonderful sightseeing adventures and activities. It is crucial to check openings of the different places, especially on holidays. Unfortunately, I missed out on the great opportunity of seeing the Sistine Chapel because it was closed on the new year.
Throw a coin (or two) into the Trevi Garden. Legend has it that if you throw a coin over your head into the Trevi Fountain, chances are, you will return to Rome. If you throw two, you will return to Rome and fall in love, and three, you will return to Rome, fall in love, and get married there. I don‚Äôt know if this has been proven correct, but it can‚Äôt hurt to take your chances either way. Unluckily, I didn‚Äôt get to throw coins into the fountain, but have no doubt; I shall return.
Check out what Italy is known for, then make sure not to miss out. I enjoyed some delicious Italian Ice Cream, Pizza, and House Wine. The wine is incredibly affordable in Italy. While in the restaurant, don‚Äôt rush to receive the bill. It is customary in Italy to stick around and have a conversation after a nice meal.
Fly Ryanair! This one is a little bit controversial. If you asked me then if I would fly Ryanair again, I would have said that I would absolutely not. Looking back though, I realize how convenient it was to have a cheap flight from London to Rome. Just make sure you read exactly what you need to do when buying the ticket so they won‚Äôt charge you extra for late check-in or carry-on bags. If you don‚Äôt want to experience flight delays though, don‚Äôt fly with Ryanair. They might have cheaper flights, but that doesn‚Äôt mean they come without a cost.
I hope asome of these travelling tips helped you out! I know that I need to take some of my own advice on my next trip to Rome.
Edit: This blog is a repost from 3 years ago when I first visited Rome. Hope you enjoy!

Title: EV Charging in Italy/EU
Content:

Sign up
Sign in

My family rented two Polestar 2 cars for a week long jaunt from Rome to Florence and around the Tuscan countryside, where we stayed at a beautiful villa for five nights, for a total around 1000 km. The catch was that the villa was sited for gorgeous views at the peak of a local hill on a farm that was accessed by 4‚Äì5 km of gravel road, depending on direction of approach. We obtained fast DC charging on the highway away from and back to Rome (more later), but there was no convenient fast charging near the villa.
The Polestars came with an EU wall outlet charging cable, so we were intent upon charging from outlets just inside the front and rear doors. Fortunately, the proprietors left out two grounding plug adaptors that mated with the Polestars‚Äô cable, and we were off. Both outlets were on a single breaker, so only one car could be charged at a time, but at 2.3 kW, wall charging is faster than in the USA, and we were able to share the juice and obtain enough for extensive day trips in Tuscany. The catch was that the owners were unhappy with our solution on grounds that it violates their solar array agreement, which specifies ‚Äúagricultural uses‚Äù. They did accept a nominal payment in compensation, however. We of course argued that they would benefit from offering this as a feature in their AirBnB listing.
On the highway, we charged at an Enel X charger at a shopping center, which offered only one 50 kW DC fast charging spigot with 5 slower Level 2 spigots. This was typical of most charging stations across Italy. So we had to time-share the two cars between a fast and a slow spigot, which seemed absurd coming from our experience with Tesla superchargers featuring at least 4‚Äì8 100‚Äì200 kW spigots per installation. A second session at a Evviva charging station benefitted from four fast spigots, but the initial 140 kW soon dropped to 70 kW when the second car was added.
Thankfully, the Evviva station recognized our Enel X app, but this was not at all apparent without some coaching from another EV driver who was incredibly helpful. The onboarding for Enel X charging had been quite painful, requiring download of an app, entry of quite a bit of personal information, and manual entry of credit card information. My attempt to register for an account was unsuccessful on three successive tries, but I was able to pay as guest, and the app put me in good shape for later charging on the Evviva chargers. But here‚Äôs the question:
Why is it possible to purchase fuel at most any gas station using only a credit card reader, but not at an EV charger? Who is blocking the adoption of a modern process for entering only the most rudimentary validating information (e.g. zip code), or more recently, simply tapping a card or a phone, without the frustrations of downloading apps or entering extensive personal information to set up ‚Äúaccounts‚Äù that are totally unnecessary?
For heaven‚Äôs sake, give me a charge and TAKE MY MONEY, already! We don‚Äôt owe you a database.

Title: Why Learning Italian Is a Game-Changer When You Move to Italy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
While it may seem obvious, if you do not already speak Italian to some degree, you will really need to buckle down and make learning the language your number one priority when you move permanently to Italy, as not being able to communicate freely with Italians could create some very challenging situations.
Recently, I spoke with an English-speaking foreigner who relocated to Italy approximately five years ago. Despite their limited knowledge of Italian, they made minimal efforts to enhance their language skills during this time. Unfortunately, this individual developed an illness that required communicating with multiple doctors. Due to the language barriers faced by the foreigner and the limited English spoken by the medical professionals, the individual believed they received a misdiagnosis and may now face a permanent health issue due to their inability to understand the doctors‚Äô diagnosis. Of course, there are two sides to the story, and without being present, one cannot know for sure what truly transpired, but one thing is for sure: not being able to speak Italian to a certain level certainly caused stress, worry, and a sense of isolation. This episode was such a negative experience for this person that they decided to leave Italy permanently.
Unfortunately, when I moved to Italy, I had no idea that it would become my permanent home. Had I known this, I would have arrived in Italy with a more extensive vocabulary than just ‚Äòciao‚Äô and ‚Äògrazie‚Äô. My first two years in Italy were particularly challenging because I didn‚Äôt have a solid grasp of Italian. This meant that I had to either seek out services where people spoke English, which often came at a premium, or I literally had to go around with a dictionary. Of course, with the advent of apps on one‚Äôs phone that can translate for you, things have become much easier. However convenient this can be, there is nothing, in my opinion, like being able to freely converse with another person.
The internet is now filled with articles that promote living a laid-back life in one of Italy‚Äôs small towns, where one can take advantage of the 7% tax program. However, given that these towns are made up of 20.000 or fewer inhabitants, and that many have older populations, it is safe to say that finding people who speak English may be rarer than a hen‚Äôs teeth. This could, despite one being happy with their life in such a town, lead to feelings of isolation if you do not speak Italian well enough to be able to hold a conversation, albeit a simple one, especially at the beginning. In addition to this, we, as foreigners who have chosen to make Italy our home, owe it to Italians to make the best effort we can to learn their language.
While Italians may be forgiving when you learn their language and make mistakes, there is no doubt that they truly appreciate it when a foreigner makes a genuine effort to learn Italian. This is particularly true in a business setting, where the Italian spoken can often be very formal. As a result, Italians generally value the ability of a foreigner to express themselves effectively in Italian and who fully understands the use of ‚ÄòLei‚Äô and ‚ÄòTu‚Äô in this context.
It is fair to say that some people and certain nationalities seem to be more gifted at learning languages, and the same is also true of Italian. That said, we owe it to ourselves, as well as to Italians, to learn the language as well as we possibly can, and here are five reasons why we should do that.
If the above five reasons are not enough, believe me when I say that you do not want to have a root canal, for example, or some other medical procedure if you do not fully understand the medical professional. You also don‚Äôt want to talk with an Italian accountant if you don‚Äôt understand completely what they‚Äôre saying. In addition to this, bonding with Italians and creating lifelong friendships are much easier if you can speak to them in their own language.
Learning Italian can take time and patience, but the rewards will be worth it. Don‚Äôt keep putting it off; start today. Even learning just one new word a day means you have learned three hundred and sixty-five new words in a year!

If you‚Äôre someone who daydreams about chasing la dolce vita, you should know that while many of us adore living in Italy, this country has plenty of problems. Some of these problems show signs of fixing, and others will likely take generations of cultural and behavioral changes to resolve.

Title: The Magic of Northern Italy: My Journey From Milan to Florence
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Last year I went on a month-long journey through the North of Italy. In this article, I want to share some of the highlights that I made on the tour. Additionally, I thought I‚Äôd complement my own thoughts with impressions of German writer and poet Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, who visited Italy from 1786 to 1788.
My journey began in Milan, which is the second largest city in Italy after Rome. My first impression of the city was a bit disappointing as I perceived it as quite dirty and ran down. Maybe this was due to the fact that my hostel was located next to the main station, which is not the best area in town.
The hostel itself, however, was very nice. I would do a lot of exploring around the center of the city. Two of the main sites are the Milan Cathedral and the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II. The former was built in 1386, and I highly recommend taking a tour through the Cathedral, including the rooftop.
The Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is Italy‚Äôs oldest active shopping gallery. It stands out due to its high ceilings, the glass dome in the center, and its luxurious shops and restaurants within the gallery. I found the architecture very fascinating, although it is obviously overrun by tourists.
After a short stay in Bergamo, I headed out to Verona, the city of Romeo and Juliett. Verona has a nice Mediterranean vibe and is home to the Verona Arena, one of the best-preserved Roman amphitheaters.
It was built in 30 AD and is still in use today. Goethe wrote about the amphitheater:
‚ÄúThe simplicity of the oval is palpable to every eye in the most pleasant way, and every head serves as a measure of how enormous the whole is. Now, when you see it empty, you have no measure; you do not know whether it is big or small.‚Äù
Although the amphitheater is one of the city‚Äôs main attractions, what stood out to me was the general architecture you can find throughout the city. There is a beautiful hill, home to the Castel San Pietro, from which you are able to overlook the city.
Lake Garda, which is easily reachable from Verona, was my next stop. What stood out to me was the panoramic view, with the majestical mountains of the Alps in the background. Goethe was also enraptured by this view:
‚ÄúHow much do I wish that my friends were with me for a moment to enjoy the prospect, which now lies before my eyes. I might have been in Verona this evening, but a magnificent natural phenomenon was in my vicinity ‚Äî Lake Garda, a splendid spectacle, which I did not want to miss, and now I am nobly rewarded for taking this circuitous route.‚Äù
I stayed in a small town called Desenzano del Garda, which is a great hub for exploring the surrounding areas. Even in late October, you are able to enjoy some hours at the lake‚Äôs beaches.
My next stop on the list was Venice ‚Äî a town I have seen so many times in various movies but never in person. So as soon as I left the train station and saw the canal in the beautiful sunshine, I had a big smile on my face. I stayed in a hostel called the Generator, which is located on one of the smaller side islands but offers a great view of the city.
Now, Venice really is a place of its own. You do not need to visit museums or galleries because the city itself is a piece of art. It gained wealth and power between the 9th and 12th centuries and had another very influential phase during the Renaissance. The boats, the houses, the canals. Everything in Venice feels magical, and you could easily believe that the city is a well-constructed theme park.
Note, however, that many tourists are moving through the narrow alleys of which Goethe wrote:
‚ÄúAfter dinner, I hurried to first get an impression of the whole, and threw myself (‚Ä¶) into the labyrinth of the city, which, although intersected by canals and small channels, is connected again by bridges and small bridges. One cannot imagine the narrowness and crowdedness of the whole without having seen it.‚Äù
After I left Venice and spent one night in Bologna, I headed further south to Florence. Now, if you‚Äôre a fan of DaVinci, Michelangelo, or art in general, this city is a must-see! Although I was already a bit tired of the hustling and bustling of all the cities I‚Äôd seen, I managed to visit the Uffizi, which hosts one of the most important collections of the Renaissance era.
What I enjoyed even more in Florence was the community kitchen of my hostel ‚Äî the Yellow Square. Every night a committed group of travelers would gather in the kitchen and share meals and stories of their day. Furthermore, the hostel has a nice rooftop terrace from where you can overlook the city.
Finally, it was time for me to head out into nature. I went to a place called LaVerna ‚Äî an old, mystical monastery that is located on the top of a mountain. From there, I would start on a week-long pilgrimage along the way of St. Francis, which ultimately led me to the town of his birth, Assisi.
Thank you for reading this article. If you enjoy my writing, please follow my profile on medium. See you soon!
--
--

Under the Tuscan Sun. Eat, Pray, Love. If these books are anthems that sing of your dreams of moving to Italy, join the club.
And yet, while many women (myself included) do successfully create a new life in the land of pasta and prosecco, many others return to their homeland after just a few months or years, unable to rectify the dream with the reality of living in Italy.
Before you sell everything you own and buy a one-way ticket, here are a few reasons you might want to reconsider this plan.
I get it. Politics/the economy/[insert something else here] suck where you live. You‚Äôre dreaming of escaping the rat race for a better life in Italy.
But I‚Äôll tell you a secret: things aren‚Äôt perfect in Italy either. In the south, there‚Äôs an extremely high unemployment rate (15% versus a national average of 8.2%). Politics are wonky here too, depending on your leanings. Oh, and then there‚Äôs the mafia.
When you run away from what you consider a less-than-ideal life, you aren‚Äôt setting yourself up for success in your new home. And as you know, problems follow you.

Title: Transparency matters: Italy moves against the secrecy surrounding the cost of medicines
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Silvia Mancini, MSF Advocacy Officer
How much do medicines cost to develop? The answer to this critical question is that we don‚Äôt know. What we do know is that the lack of transparency and secrecy surrounding these costs allows pharmaceutical companies to charge just about any price they want for their drugs. Now Italy has taken a pioneering step in requiring more transparency from the industry.
Currently pharmaceutical corporations are not required to disclose their research and development (R&D) costs, how much public money they receive to help develop medicines, or what prices they charge in different countries.
This means they can ‚Äî and do ‚Äî charge sky-high prices and make huge private profits off the back of public investments. The pharmaceutical industry justifies high drug prices by claiming the need to recoup the high costs they invest in R&D. However, they never publicly reveal those figures, preferring to keep us all in the dark about the actual costs involved. Consequently, countries and health systems have to negotiate ‚Äòblind‚Äô with companies while trying to secure an affordable price for medicines to treat their populations.
The last few years have seen escalating drug prices create increasingly global barriers for access to medicines ‚Äî these price barriers are not limited anymore to people living in developing countries. Cancer drugs, hepatitis C drugs, insulin ‚Äî sky-high prices for all of the above have created real life and death challenges for people and health systems in rich countries, too. Health systems are buckling under the prices of new medicines everywhere. The public is not getting its money‚Äôs worth and pharma has been getting rich at our expense as taxpayers.
Which is why ‚Äî after some pretty drawn-out and contentious negotiations ‚Äî there was a cause for celebration at the World Health Assembly back in 2019, when Member States finally adopted a resolution to demand more transparency from pharma over how they price their drugs.
Italy was at the forefront of that initiative in 2019 and today is taking a further important step forward to redress the power imbalance between pharma companies and the public, and require more transparency from an industry that deliberately cloaks itself in secrecy.
August saw the formal approval of a decree from Italy‚Äôs regulatory medicines agency (AIFA) that asks pharmaceutical corporations, before any major drugs purchase, to provide the agency with specific information about the company‚Äôs R&D costs, as well as the commercial conditions under which the same product is sold in other countries ‚Äî i.e. the prices the company is charging elsewhere.
The ‚ÄòPricing and Reimbursement‚Äô decree promises to disrupt a system which has allowed for far too long pharmaceutical corporations to impose exorbitant prices on governments for their innovative products, which are more often than not disconnected from actual R&D costs and funded with taxpayers‚Äô money.
Let‚Äôs take a closer look at the decree ‚Äî it requires corporations;
‚Üíto demonstrate the ‚Äòadded therapeutic value‚Äô of each drug under negotiation ‚Äî meaning corporations that want to bring a medicine onto the Italian market at higher prices than those of existing treatments, will now have to demonstrate that the new medicine also has increased therapeutic efficacy.
‚Üí to disclose the price at which the drug is sold in other countries ‚Äî until now, the information about prices in other countries has been ‚Äòprotected‚Äô by confidentiality clauses.
‚Üíto make public disclosure of the subsidies and public funds received by the corporation towards the R&D costs, as well as disclosure of the overall R&D costs.
‚Üíto reveal the status of patents that it holds on the drug.
‚Üíand ‚Äî the icing on the cake ‚Äî to provide the regulatory authority with annual data on profits and sales of each drug.
‚ÄúA spectacular ‚Äòwin‚Äô for public health‚Äù
It‚Äôs a spectacular ‚Äòwin‚Äô for public health and will undoubtably strengthen the negotiating position of AIFA with pharmaceutical corporations. However, we now need to see the principles on paper turned in to reality.
The task now for AIFA is to define clear means and guidelines for the implementation of the decree. For example, what steps are taken if the corporation does not produce the required documents? Will negotiations be blocked? If this applies for an essential and innovative drug, what consequences could it have on public health? Will AIFA keep its nerve and block negotiations on an essential and innovative drug, given the potential public health consequences of keeping it off the market? And who will verify the reliability of the documents produced by the corporations?
Who will follow in Italy‚Äôs footsteps?
There‚Äôs a road ahead to travel of course, but the publication of this decree is indeed a pioneering first step. And where Italy has acted, civil society groups elsewhere are now looking on closely, hoping this might encourage other governments to follow suit.
And in a time of COVID-19, there‚Äôs no more critical moment to ensure transparency of the costs of drug and vaccine development. Billions of dollars of public investment have already been poured into the race for new vaccines and treatment. We need corporations to come clean on prices and costs, and as well to share clinical data so that fair prices can be set that ensure affordability for everyone ‚Äî both people in our own projects and others too in need ‚Äî and that pharma doesn‚Äôt use the pandemic as another opportunity to line its pockets. Transparency matters.
Find out more about our work on transparency

Ciao, Italy.
You have started to hold a very special place in my juvenile heart. If there is anything I have ever dreamt of, it is you, Italy. The skies painted in the hues of the Adriatic Sea, the clouds like scoops of vanilla gelato, colorful rumbling vespas like rolling syllables of Italian, men kissed by Michelangelo, women blessed by the Tuscan sun.
I have been fascinated by many places, whom you might know too- UK with its historical charm, France with its elegance and German with its discipline; but there is something unique and different about you, Italy. You can be mandolin in a lively Tarantella on a summer night and the bagpipe in the quiet streets of Rome; and piano is the Ponte Vecchio of these instruments, entwined.
People fall in love with other people in France but I have fallen for you, Italy. It is as if you‚Äôve been sculpted in a way by the divine not to be admired, but to be felt. You have been created for me to awaken long-lost butterflies, the softest goosebumps I thought I‚Äôd forgotten. If there is anything I‚Äôve longed for, it has to be you, Italy. I dream to wake up and see your face, feel the morning summer breeze kiss my skin, spending lazy middays penning love letters to you, and dancing in the red-wined soaked air with beautiful souls you‚Äôve wrought.
You fill in the hollow voids of nothingness with ecstasy and a hope, a hope that one day I‚Äôll come to you. I hope to live the sunny daydreams in Tuscany, I hope to eat the best gelatos of my life, I hope to fall for a mark of your splendor, I hope to see Piazzale Michelangelo‚Äôs night sky with you, I hope to hear the Basilica‚Äôs bells as I pray, I hope to touch the sacred walls as if it‚Äôs the divine itself, I hope to smell the different pastas before devouring them, I hope to feel the hurt when I pinch myself, hoping this isn‚Äôt a dream.
You aren‚Äôt just a place, you‚Äôre a promise, a dream, a goal, the perfect end to a happy ending, my happy ending. I promise you that one day, I‚Äôll be coming to you, falling in love more and in your arms. I promise to cry my heart out when I finally meet you, I promise to rediscover the purpose of living there, I promise to unravel all the things you‚Äôve got to say to me, you mysterious gem, I promise to spend my life‚Äôs best days there, I promise to never wake up from this dream, I promise to never give up on you, my Italy.   Oh, my unlived d√©j√† vu, I‚Äôll be on my way to you.  One day.   Con amore, Pavitra

Title: Italy has Turned Me into a Food Snob
Content:

This publication is about taking off on foot, in a car, by plane or in the mind. It‚Äôs about taking off of work, school or life in general. Old stories, new stories and imagined stories that feature these various forms of taking off, including masks and hats, are all welcome.

Member-only story

Everyone has ‚Äúa thing‚Äù that they do upon their return home from a vacation. Usually, this involves an immense amount of laundry and getting caught up on unread emails.
I similarly follow this trend, except this time. I just returned from Italy, and as soon as I got home, I threw away all of our boxed pasta, canned pasta sauces, and Extra Virgin Olive Oil (EVOO).
Why?
Because I can clearly taste a difference between prepackaged pasta made with preservatives that I cannot pronounce. I also know that many Italian-sounding olive oils are misleading and not really from Italy at all. The ones I had stocked in my pantry were the kind that I got suckered into buying because it was on BOGO, and I will compare the consistency to motor oil now that I have had the real thing.
During my 10 days touring Italy, I tasted risottos, homemade bread, visited olive farms, gorged myself on homemade pasta, and I even had a four-course meal prepared by the well-known chef Maurizio Staiano of Salerno who has also worked with several Michelin Star Chefs.

I am a Finnish software developer who recently moved to Frascati, Italy. This is the fourth episode in a series of posts where I write about my experiences in living in my new home country.
The observations are written by someone who has lived most of his life in the Northern Europe: first around 30 years in Finland and then some years in the Netherlands.
At the time of writing I‚Äôve been living in Italy for 11 months. It‚Äôs time to look back, and see how it has been so far.
I‚Äôm working from home in a fully remote setup. My team mates are in the Netherlands, and my client project has people working all over Europe and some outside the continent. I try to go see my team mates and my friends in the Netherlands on a regular basis. Typically this has been about once every two-three months, which is a good cadence for me.
I don‚Äôt mind the remote work. During the covid-pandemic I got used to it. But I do notice that it would be nice to have the flexibility to go to the office more often and to see my colleagues and team mates face-to-face without too much preparation. I see them on calls every day obviously, but it‚Äôs not the same thing. During the calls or pair-programming sessions the communication is very much focused on work. You lose all the casual interactions and conversations around a coffee machine, which has an impact on the relationships, the feeling of empathy and closeness. Then again, none of this is coming to me as a surprise. I was expecting that working remotely would have this kind of an effect.
However, I did not expect that time has become a really valuable and scarce resource to me. I need to plan carefully where and how I want to invest my time in. Because I‚Äôm working remotely and I don‚Äôt have the normal community of colleagues around me, my social life has taken a big hit. After all, for an expat the office is an easy place to meet people and to make friends with a similar mindset. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, I‚Äôm a Finn so I enjoy spending time on my own in silence and isolation, and I don‚Äôt need too many people around me. But even a Finn sometimes needs someone else to share the silence with. And it‚Äôs healthy if that other person is not always the same as your partner.
So I need to find new friends. But that takes time, commitment and requires extra effort. And time away from Italy, like if I‚Äôm going to the Netherlands or Finland for example, is time away from making new connections in Italy. So it‚Äôs a difficult balancing act. And especially weekends are extremely precious. You need to make them count.
When I was living in the Netherlands, I had two countries that required my presence: Finland and the Netherlands. Now there are three. And I love visiting each of them and spending time with the people that are important to me. But travelling takes precious time and it‚Äôs not only that. It‚Äôs also time away from the place that is your home, your safe place with all your things, routines, gadgets, and your own bed. And being away from home too much and too often can be really tiring. Maybe I‚Äôm getting old, but I like my routines and my safe place.
I‚Äôve been studying Italian for a few years. After moving here there has been a huge leap of progress in learning the language. I‚Äôm able to follow conversations and understand pretty much everything, given that the people do not speak in a dialect, which makes understanding sometimes very difficult in the area around Rome. I once went to have a haircut in Frascati and the guys were speaking in such a heavy dialect that I understood nothing about what they were saying. It adds another layer of difficulty.
Also, I can follow TV series with Italian subtitles without any issues. Noticing these kinds of small things gives me motivation. Speaking, on the other hand, is still difficult, and I know that the problem is mostly in my head. I should just start speaking more but there is some kind of a mental block. It does get easier with time.
Anyway, I like the fact that in Italy you need to know the language in order to survive. The level of English (or even Finnish) isn‚Äôt high so you have no other choice. And learning the language is a key factor in integrating with the local culture and society. In general, the Italians appreciate the effort that I‚Äôm making in speaking the language. It can be really awkward and exhausting, but at the same time it‚Äôs a great learning experience.
And the people are genuinely helpful and warm. They might stop you in the street, have a quick chat, and tell you how nice you look. Or they might ask what you have been eating to be so tall. It‚Äôs a bit of a culture shock for a cold Finn from the far north but I like it.
I came to Italy expecting to find good weather, amazing food and wine, and beautiful landscapes filled with endless stories in history. I know that these are probably the most stereotypical things anyone would list about Italy. My apologies, it‚Äôs my lack of imagination. But that‚Äôs what I was looking for, and I‚Äôm happy to say that for the most part my expectations were met.
The weather has been very good. During the winter the coldest period lasted about three weeks. In Finland we would describe the winter in Lazio as ‚Äúlong October‚Äù. We barely had to turn on the heating in our apartment. Despite some anomalies in April and May, the sun has been shining and the temperatures have been steadily rising. In fact, at the time of writing there is a heat wave in Italy with temperatures climbing above 40 degrees. Frascati typically has a few degrees less than Rome, and the town is located on a hill so there is a bit more ventilation here. And luckily, our apartment is equipped with air-conditioning. Otherwise, this poor northern boy would be already cooked.
The food and the wine‚Ä¶ Well, let‚Äôs say the Italians know what they are doing. The food is amazing and the wine is delicious and in abundance. Eating out in a restaurant is affordable. During the week I try to limit myself from eating out, but on a weekend I allow myself to relax and eat all the carbonara available. They recently opened a summer street market next to our apartment, and they have a stand selling panini con la porchetta. It‚Äôs cheap, good, and it‚Äôs dangerously close.
I am a bit surprised about the prices in the supermarket though. It‚Äôs quite expensive, and I don‚Äôt notice a big difference compared to the prices in the Netherlands or Finland for example. But the quality of the products is really high.
I‚Äôm very satisfied with the amount of nature, the beautiful landscapes, and the hiking possibilities available in Lazio. I love the fact that I can easily go hiking on a lake or on top of a mountain, and just casually pass an ancient Roman amphitheatre or an aqueduct. Il Parco Regionale dei Castelli Romani next to Frascati has enough trails to keep you busy for a long time. I‚Äôve been also joining some guided hikes, and I‚Äôve found that it‚Äôs a good way to explore new places and to meet new people in my new home country.
Life is a balance of pros and cons, and life in Italy is no exception. I can make exaggerated jokes about the problems I‚Äôve had, but in all honesty I haven‚Äôt had any major issues.
When moving here I was expecting the bureaucracy to cause me terrible headaches. And yes, there have been some challenges, but mostly things have been resolved and there haven‚Äôt been any blocking obstacles. You need a bit of perseverance, a healthy level of pessimism, luck, and good connections. I guess having an Italian partner is also a gateway to success (in life in general). My tessera sanitaria is still lost in a limbo but at least I have a carta di identit√†. And I haven‚Äôt filed my taxes yet for last year. I expect this to be another fun adventure.
If you‚Äôve read my previous posts, you already know that I was a bit shocked about the traffic in Rome. Now I‚Äôm already somewhat used to it, but I still try to avoid driving a car in the city center. If you‚Äôre in need of excitement and adrenaline, there are better ways to get them.
But I‚Äôm happy to say that my plan of acquiring a scooter worked wonderfully! Well, not wonderfully. I placed the order in December but finally got the scooter in May after some major delivery issues. However, since then it has been the solution to all of my problems! I‚Äôm fully autonomous. I can get to Rome easily, and without wasting time in looking for a parking spot. Driving a scooter in Rome is more fun and way less stressful than driving a car. Plus passing the beautifully lighted Colosseum in the evening with a scooter is pretty damn nice.
Moving to a new country is not easy. And moving to a new country, which is culturally and climatically very different from what you‚Äôve used to, is even harder. You‚Äôre pulled out of your comfort zone and placed in an environment where everything is new. And it‚Äôs even warm. You need to set up all of your routines from the ground up. It is overwhelming and exhausting.
Personally, I learnt that you need to be patient, give yourself time, and celebrate every small achievement. You start from the basics, small things, and then gradually increase the difficulty level. After each achievement you can reward yourself with a glass of wine. For me this meant going through the following list in increasing level of difficulty:
Working through tasks in this manner creates a positive feedback loop, makes you more comfortable in using the language, and slowly builds up your confidence. You get an idea how things work and you are able to build a routine for yourself.
After 11 months of living here I have my routine pretty much set up. Italy feels like a home.
Really the only bigger struggle I have is finding my group of people to spend time with. It‚Äôs a solvable problem but might take some time. And what is life without a bit of challenge after all. Like my friend in Finland says ‚ÄúEi t√§nne helppoo oo tultu hakeen‚Äù which roughly translates to ‚ÄúWe‚Äòre not here because it‚Äôs easy‚Äù.
I‚Äôve been attending some expat events and I‚Äôve found them a good place to make connections. There is a risk in ending up in an expat bubble, but right now I feel that I‚Äôd like to meet people who are in a similar situation and who can relate to how it is living in a foreign country.
Obviously, I continue learning Italian, but it might take a lifetime until I can speak fluently and express myself in the same manner as I‚Äôm currently able to do in Finnish or in English. But I like the language and I appreciate the challenge.
I‚Äôm actually really happy for the life and the quality of life that I have. I would say that the pros outweigh the cons easily. I guess I might be still in the honeymoon period of living in another country but I might as well enjoy it to the fullest.
--
--
Finnish software developer living in Frascati, Italy. My special skills include converting carbonara and coffee into high-end software solutions.

For people living in Italy on a residenza elettiva (elective residence) visa, the cost to opt in to the national health service has more than doubled. A new law was enacted at the end of 2023 that established a minimum cost of ‚Ç¨2,000 and a maximum of ‚Ç¨2,700 for each person. Prior to this, costs varied wildly region to region, but in general it was about ‚Ç¨2,200 for both my wife and I per year based on a formula applied to gross income.
After a lot of back and forth, we got the final calculation confirmed and the combined cost for both my wife and I will now be ‚Ç¨4,000 for a year, which translates to about $180 per month for each of us.
The diagnostic and preventive exams provided by Medicare B in the U.S. appear to be better in most respects compared to what we will get in Italy. I guess the health care here is adequate, but it certainly isn‚Äôt a screaming bargain with top notch service. As an overview of the basic coverage, the Italian national health service pays for hospital stays, ambulance service, and visits to the emergency room. Figuring out the right visa to move to Italy can be overwhelming if you‚Äôre doing it alone, and if you make the wrong call, you could end up losing money and staying stuck in your home country.
That‚Äôs what‚Äôs happening to some people who are being told to apply for the Elective Residency visa. If an immigration attorney is encouraging you to apply for this visa and you‚Äôre not yet retired, read on.
The Elective Residency visa is a long-term visa for people who do not intend to work once they arrive in Italy. Typically these individuals are retired or generate passive income from sources like capital gains, dividends, retirement pensions, royalties, or rental property.
While this is ideal for someone who is retired, there are immigration attorneys who are encouraging people who still work (perhaps freelance) to apply for this visa‚Ä¶and they‚Äôre being denied.
Some of these attorneys ignore clients when they tell them that they will continue to work once they live in Italy. They focus on the bare requirement (‚Ç¨31k a year in passive income sources) and don‚Äôt address what will happen once the individual arrives in Italy and is‚Ä¶

Title: Was it selfish to move to Italy? A mother‚Äôs story about moving to another country without any solid reason
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
‚ÄúYes, I think I have found the house!‚Äù I announced enthusiastically to my children and partner. None of us could have predicted how that casual idea of finding a second home would unfold and transform our lives.
At the time, I was at a crossroads. After selling my house, I couldn‚Äôt see a clear way forward in my home country. The housing market had become wildly expensive, and renting was nearly impossible without a steady employment contract. Investing in a property felt practical, so I decided to look for a second home ‚Äî a place to wait out the unpredictable market. My three children were fully aware of my plans and shared in the excitement. After all, the idea of a holiday house in Spain or Italy sounded idyllic to everyone.
The house I found fit comfortably within the ‚Äúsecond home‚Äù budget. It wasn‚Äôt a larger investment that nudged me toward a permanent move ‚Äî it simply felt right. Honestly, I had never considered leaving the Netherlands before. Even moving to Peru, where my partner lives, had never seriously crossed my mind. But something shifted for me during the COVID-19 years; the Netherlands no longer felt the same.
Most people who move abroad have a clear reason: to study, pursue a job, start a dream business like a B&B, or retire in a new place. None of those reasons applied to me. I just felt an inner ‚Äúyes‚Äù ‚Äî a pull to go and experience something new.
Of course, I discussed it with my children, who were 19, 20, and 23 years old at the time. The two youngest had just returned from five-month solo trips to Asia, and my eldest had been living in the UK for five years. Their adventures abroad had made them supportive and enthusiastic about my move. But agreeing with the idea and facing the reality of their mother emigrating are two very different things.
Although my decision was guided by intuition, there was also a practical push. In the Netherlands, it‚Äôs not possible to live without a registered address. Spending between ‚Ç¨1,500 and ‚Ç¨2,500 a month on rent felt unsustainable, and moving in with my mother wasn‚Äôt a viable long-term solution. After six months of using her address as a temporary registration, I needed something permanent. The house in Italy became that solution. Once I made the decision, the next steps fell into place: moving my belongings out of storage, closing my business and tax number, and eventually selling my beloved old Volvo. (One Europe doesn‚Äôt feel very united when you‚Äôre faced with the bureaucracy of importing a car or changing a driver‚Äôs license!)
Even our dog, Sarah, became part of the plans. My ex-husband and I shared her care, as neither of us could manage full-time responsibility. Sarah traveled with me back and forth between countries. Although the 13-hour drive wasn‚Äôt her favorite, she loved her new life in Italy. Tragically, she passed away three months ago and now rests beneath the cherry tree in the garden. I still feel her presence watching over me and the house.
When my partner visited Italy to see the house, he wasn‚Äôt thrilled at first. Trading his favorite city, Amsterdam, for life in the middle of nowhere was not what he had envisioned. However, after a rocky start, he‚Äôs grown to love it. Working on the land, enjoying aperitivi at the local bar, meeting new friends, and exploring new places have gradually won him over.
And my children? It‚Äôs been a significant change for them. Although they were already living independently, my move nudged them further into self-reliance. There‚Äôs no longer a ‚Äúhome‚Äù to return to for a casual evening or a mother nearby when they‚Äôre feeling unwell. Visits are planned now. Yet, they love visiting Italy, and I treasure seeing them every six to eight weeks. They often bring friends, and we make the most of our time together, relaxing and appreciating the simple joys.
The dynamic of family life raises an interesting question: Where should we draw the line between living for others and choosing a path for ourselves? Was it selfish of me to move? Perhaps. But I believe it was a healthy kind of selfishness. In modern society, we often place enormous expectations on each other for care and support, yet these aren‚Äôt always balanced or reciprocated. For years, I shaped my life around my children, blending work and caregiving seamlessly. Now, it feels like the right time to embrace a new phase.
And what about caring for our parents? Do we adjust our lives for them, or do they move in with us? In an ideal world, family-based communities would allow for a natural exchange of care ‚Äî elders helping with the little ones, and younger generations supporting the elderly when the time comes. But in today‚Äôs Western society, that‚Äôs not always our reality. We‚Äôre often left juggling guilt and judgment when making choices for ourselves.
In my book The Ripple Effect: Know How Powerful You Are, I explore how our struggles to grow into emotionally responsible, independent adults can create friction in families. These dynamics are complex and deeply personal. I don‚Äôt claim to have the perfect answer, but I‚Äôve made peace with my decisions. Whether I stayed in the Netherlands or moved to Italy, there would have been positive and negative consequences for everyone involved.
I‚Äôm incredibly proud of how my children have embraced my choices, and I‚Äôm grateful for the new experiences we share here in Italy. Right now, I‚Äôm preparing the house for a lively New Year‚Äôs gathering with my two youngest and their friends. The house will be full, and I couldn‚Äôt be happier.
Follow this blog for weekly updates, surprises, and stories as I navigate the joys and challenges of building a family home and business sanctuary in Italy. There‚Äôs so much more to come!

It all started with a conversation in a caf√©. It‚Äôs the end of October, and with no previous plans, a friend and I were just sitting idly, enjoying a good pastry croissant and catching up.

‚ÄúWe should travel.‚Äù, and my friend immediately pulled out her phone and started searching cities in Europe from the most expensive to the cheapest. ‚ÄúOslo ‚Äî too expensive; Stockholm ‚Äî too expensive; Dublin ‚Äî a bit expensive at the time; Barcelona or Madrid ‚Äî expensive at the time; Rome ‚Äî the same story. What about Bologne?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhy Bologne?‚Äù, I asked.
