Ciao, Italy.
You have started to hold a very special place in my juvenile heart. If there is anything I have ever dreamt of, it is you, Italy. The skies painted in the hues of the Adriatic Sea, the clouds like scoops of vanilla gelato, colorful rumbling vespas like rolling syllables of Italian, men kissed by Michelangelo, women blessed by the Tuscan sun.
I have been fascinated by many places, whom you might know too- UK with its historical charm, France with its elegance and German with its discipline; but there is something unique and different about you, Italy. You can be mandolin in a lively Tarantella on a summer night and the bagpipe in the quiet streets of Rome; and piano is the Ponte Vecchio of these instruments, entwined.
People fall in love with other people in France but I have fallen for you, Italy. It is as if you‚Äôve been sculpted in a way by the divine not to be admired, but to be felt. You have been created for me to awaken long-lost butterflies, the softest goosebumps I thought I‚Äôd forgotten. If there is anything I‚Äôve longed for, it has to be you, Italy. I dream to wake up and see your face, feel the morning summer breeze kiss my skin, spending lazy middays penning love letters to you, and dancing in the red-wined soaked air with beautiful souls you‚Äôve wrought.
You fill in the hollow voids of nothingness with ecstasy and a hope, a hope that one day I‚Äôll come to you. I hope to live the sunny daydreams in Tuscany, I hope to eat the best gelatos of my life, I hope to fall for a mark of your splendor, I hope to see Piazzale Michelangelo‚Äôs night sky with you, I hope to hear the Basilica‚Äôs bells as I pray, I hope to touch the sacred walls as if it‚Äôs the divine itself, I hope to smell the different pastas before devouring them, I hope to feel the hurt when I pinch myself, hoping this isn‚Äôt a dream.
You aren‚Äôt just a place, you‚Äôre a promise, a dream, a goal, the perfect end to a happy ending, my happy ending. I promise you that one day, I‚Äôll be coming to you, falling in love more and in your arms. I promise to cry my heart out when I finally meet you, I promise to rediscover the purpose of living there, I promise to unravel all the things you‚Äôve got to say to me, you mysterious gem, I promise to spend my life‚Äôs best days there, I promise to never wake up from this dream, I promise to never give up on you, my Italy.   Oh, my unlived d√©j√† vu, I‚Äôll be on my way to you.  One day.   Con amore, Pavitra

Title: Italy has Turned Me into a Food Snob
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in

Member-only story

Everyone has ‚Äúa thing‚Äù that they do upon their return home from a vacation. Usually, this involves an immense amount of laundry and getting caught up on unread emails.
I similarly follow this trend, except this time. I just returned from Italy, and as soon as I got home, I threw away all of our boxed pasta, canned pasta sauces, and Extra Virgin Olive Oil (EVOO).
Why?
Because I can clearly taste a difference between prepackaged pasta made with preservatives that I cannot pronounce. I also know that many Italian-sounding olive oils are misleading and not really from Italy at all. The ones I had stocked in my pantry were the kind that I got suckered into buying because it was on BOGO, and I will compare the consistency to motor oil now that I have had the real thing.
During my 10 days touring Italy, I tasted risottos, homemade bread, visited olive farms, gorged myself on homemade pasta, and I even had a four-course meal prepared by the well-known chef Maurizio Staiano of Salerno who has also worked with several Michelin Star Chefs.

Title: Transparency matters: Italy moves against the secrecy surrounding the cost of medicines
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Silvia Mancini, MSF Advocacy Officer
How much do medicines cost to develop? The answer to this critical question is that we don‚Äôt know. What we do know is that the lack of transparency and secrecy surrounding these costs allows pharmaceutical companies to charge just about any price they want for their drugs. Now Italy has taken a pioneering step in requiring more transparency from the industry.
Currently pharmaceutical corporations are not required to disclose their research and development (R&D) costs, how much public money they receive to help develop medicines, or what prices they charge in different countries.
This means they can ‚Äî and do ‚Äî charge sky-high prices and make huge private profits off the back of public investments. The pharmaceutical industry justifies high drug prices by claiming the need to recoup the high costs they invest in R&D. However, they never publicly reveal those figures, preferring to keep us all in the dark about the actual costs involved. Consequently, countries and health systems have to negotiate ‚Äòblind‚Äô with companies while trying to secure an affordable price for medicines to treat their populations.
The last few years have seen escalating drug prices create increasingly global barriers for access to medicines ‚Äî these price barriers are not limited anymore to people living in developing countries. Cancer drugs, hepatitis C drugs, insulin ‚Äî sky-high prices for all of the above have created real life and death challenges for people and health systems in rich countries, too. Health systems are buckling under the prices of new medicines everywhere. The public is not getting its money‚Äôs worth and pharma has been getting rich at our expense as taxpayers.
Which is why ‚Äî after some pretty drawn-out and contentious negotiations ‚Äî there was a cause for celebration at the World Health Assembly back in 2019, when Member States finally adopted a resolution to demand more transparency from pharma over how they price their drugs.
Italy was at the forefront of that initiative in 2019 and today is taking a further important step forward to redress the power imbalance between pharma companies and the public, and require more transparency from an industry that deliberately cloaks itself in secrecy.
August saw the formal approval of a decree from Italy‚Äôs regulatory medicines agency (AIFA) that asks pharmaceutical corporations, before any major drugs purchase, to provide the agency with specific information about the company‚Äôs R&D costs, as well as the commercial conditions under which the same product is sold in other countries ‚Äî i.e. the prices the company is charging elsewhere.
The ‚ÄòPricing and Reimbursement‚Äô decree promises to disrupt a system which has allowed for far too long pharmaceutical corporations to impose exorbitant prices on governments for their innovative products, which are more often than not disconnected from actual R&D costs and funded with taxpayers‚Äô money.
Let‚Äôs take a closer look at the decree ‚Äî it requires corporations;
‚Üíto demonstrate the ‚Äòadded therapeutic value‚Äô of each drug under negotiation ‚Äî meaning corporations that want to bring a medicine onto the Italian market at higher prices than those of existing treatments, will now have to demonstrate that the new medicine also has increased therapeutic efficacy.
‚Üí to disclose the price at which the drug is sold in other countries ‚Äî until now, the information about prices in other countries has been ‚Äòprotected‚Äô by confidentiality clauses.
‚Üíto make public disclosure of the subsidies and public funds received by the corporation towards the R&D costs, as well as disclosure of the overall R&D costs.
‚Üíto reveal the status of patents that it holds on the drug.
‚Üíand ‚Äî the icing on the cake ‚Äî to provide the regulatory authority with annual data on profits and sales of each drug.
‚ÄúA spectacular ‚Äòwin‚Äô for public health‚Äù
It‚Äôs a spectacular ‚Äòwin‚Äô for public health and will undoubtably strengthen the negotiating position of AIFA with pharmaceutical corporations. However, we now need to see the principles on paper turned in to reality.
The task now for AIFA is to define clear means and guidelines for the implementation of the decree. For example, what steps are taken if the corporation does not produce the required documents? Will negotiations be blocked? If this applies for an essential and innovative drug, what consequences could it have on public health? Will AIFA keep its nerve and block negotiations on an essential and innovative drug, given the potential public health consequences of keeping it off the market? And who will verify the reliability of the documents produced by the corporations?
Who will follow in Italy‚Äôs footsteps?
There‚Äôs a road ahead to travel of course, but the publication of this decree is indeed a pioneering first step. And where Italy has acted, civil society groups elsewhere are now looking on closely, hoping this might encourage other governments to follow suit.
And in a time of COVID-19, there‚Äôs no more critical moment to ensure transparency of the costs of drug and vaccine development. Billions of dollars of public investment have already been poured into the race for new vaccines and treatment. We need corporations to come clean on prices and costs, and as well to share clinical data so that fair prices can be set that ensure affordability for everyone ‚Äî both people in our own projects and others too in need ‚Äî and that pharma doesn‚Äôt use the pandemic as another opportunity to line its pockets. Transparency matters.
Find out more about our work on transparency

Title: How Two Italian Founders Pointed Their Dutch Startup back to Italy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Since I was a kid, I always had a strong drive to go abroad. English fascinated me as a language, and, being born in a small village in the mountains, I‚Äôve always been eager to know what the larger world has to offer. During my studies, I had the opportunity to travel to Scotland, and learn a few facts about the business world abroad. Everything sounded more honest, open and direct than Italy, good points for me.
The choice of going abroad again to complete my education was then easy. Rotterdam was a natural choice, one of the best M.Sc.s in finance in Europe. That brought together me and Mr. Valentini and ended up with us starting Equidam.
Even before Equidam, we shared a passion for private companies. I think it probably stems out of the fact that they have larger opportunities to grow, they are more flexible and more responsive to market needs. We also shared an assumption. The assumption is that finance is under-utilised by private companies. We thought, and still do, that by knowing more about finance and having the right tools, private companies around the world can grow faster, bring their innovation to market in a better way and finally help millions of people sooner.
It was this drive and shared assumption that brought us to start Equidam. Through our little consulting days, valuation came up more and more as a topic with large disparities of knowledge between parties. Entrepreneurs and founders are not used to the valuation discussion as much as investors are. They can end up leaving money on the table or
not close a deal at all because of this miscommunication and information asymmetry. We thought (and still do!) that we could solve that. And that is how Equidam started.
Through the years we grew Equidam trying to help as many founders as possible, and I‚Äôm extremely proud of our results!
And it is on this mission, that today we launched the Italian language. After Dutch, German, and French, Italian was a natural addition. Valuation is a though topic and a though negotiation. If we want to provide companies with the best tools, these tools have to speak the language of the discussion. This increases trust, reliability and simplicity.
So why does Italian come so late, after all we are both Italian right? wasn‚Äôt it a natural choice to have Italian as first foreign language?
Yes, it might have been, but something interesting has happened. To my surprise, the Italian companies and founders demonstrated a very good English proficiency! This, coupled with a larger number of customer requests for translations in German, French etc made us change our priorities. This couldn‚Äôt go on for too long though. The Italian startup scene is happening now, and we hope to be part of it as much as possible. Lately, there‚Äôs been talk of increasing number of VC funds, angel investment clubs, accelerators and most importantly startups emerging all over Italy. Italian startups raised roughly ‚Ç¨100 million for 2015 alone and Italian‚Äôs equity crowdfunding law was one of the first ones to come out, and still a solid base for other regulations around the world.
As a startup that is focused on helping other startups all over the world, we have been on the lookout for new developments in the global
startup scene.From the tech unicorns in the Silicon Valley to the European startup hubs such as London, Paris and Berlin, to the Israeli tech scene, we have been witnessing the boom of unicorns and smaller companies going public.We wish nothing but the utmost success to the Italian hub, and with the addition of Italian to our languages, we‚Äôll strive even more to make it happen!
P.S. Un grazie enorme va rivolto agli utenti italiani che ci hanno aiutato ad adattare la piattaforma e finalizzarla in questi ultimi mesi, grandissimi!
--

Founder @ Equidam. Startup enthusiast with experience in Finance and Product Dev. Passionate about reading, sailing and traveling

Title: One Year in Italy ‚Äî Retrospective
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I am a Finnish software developer who recently moved to Frascati, Italy. This is the fourth episode in a series of posts where I write about my experiences in living in my new home country.
The observations are written by someone who has lived most of his life in the Northern Europe: first around 30 years in Finland and then some years in the Netherlands.
At the time of writing I‚Äôve been living in Italy for 11 months. It‚Äôs time to look back, and see how it has been so far.
I‚Äôm working from home in a fully remote setup. My team mates are in the Netherlands, and my client project has people working all over Europe and some outside the continent. I try to go see my team mates and my friends in the Netherlands on a regular basis. Typically this has been about once every two-three months, which is a good cadence for me.
I don‚Äôt mind the remote work. During the covid-pandemic I got used to it. But I do notice that it would be nice to have the flexibility to go to the office more often and to see my colleagues and team mates face-to-face without too much preparation. I see them on calls every day obviously, but it‚Äôs not the same thing. During the calls or pair-programming sessions the communication is very much focused on work. You lose all the casual interactions and conversations around a coffee machine, which has an impact on the relationships, the feeling of empathy and closeness. Then again, none of this is coming to me as a surprise. I was expecting that working remotely would have this kind of an effect.
However, I did not expect that time has become a really valuable and scarce resource to me. I need to plan carefully where and how I want to invest my time in. Because I‚Äôm working remotely and I don‚Äôt have the normal community of colleagues around me, my social life has taken a big hit. After all, for an expat the office is an easy place to meet people and to make friends with a similar mindset. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, I‚Äôm a Finn so I enjoy spending time on my own in silence and isolation, and I don‚Äôt need too many people around me. But even a Finn sometimes needs someone else to share the silence with. And it‚Äôs healthy if that other person is not always the same as your partner.
So I need to find new friends. But that takes time, commitment and requires extra effort. And time away from Italy, like if I‚Äôm going to the Netherlands or Finland for example, is time away from making new connections in Italy. So it‚Äôs a difficult balancing act. And especially weekends are extremely precious. You need to make them count.
When I was living in the Netherlands, I had two countries that required my presence: Finland and the Netherlands. Now there are three. And I love visiting each of them and spending time with the people that are important to me. But travelling takes precious time and it‚Äôs not only that. It‚Äôs also time away from the place that is your home, your safe place with all your things, routines, gadgets, and your own bed. And being away from home too much and too often can be really tiring. Maybe I‚Äôm getting old, but I like my routines and my safe place.
I‚Äôve been studying Italian for a few years. After moving here there has been a huge leap of progress in learning the language. I‚Äôm able to follow conversations and understand pretty much everything, given that the people do not speak in a dialect, which makes understanding sometimes very difficult in the area around Rome. I once went to have a haircut in Frascati and the guys were speaking in such a heavy dialect that I understood nothing about what they were saying. It adds another layer of difficulty.
Also, I can follow TV series with Italian subtitles without any issues. Noticing these kinds of small things gives me motivation. Speaking, on the other hand, is still difficult, and I know that the problem is mostly in my head. I should just start speaking more but there is some kind of a mental block. It does get easier with time.
Anyway, I like the fact that in Italy you need to know the language in order to survive. The level of English (or even Finnish) isn‚Äôt high so you have no other choice. And learning the language is a key factor in integrating with the local culture and society. In general, the Italians appreciate the effort that I‚Äôm making in speaking the language. It can be really awkward and exhausting, but at the same time it‚Äôs a great learning experience.
And the people are genuinely helpful and warm. They might stop you in the street, have a quick chat, and tell you how nice you look. Or they might ask what you have been eating to be so tall. It‚Äôs a bit of a culture shock for a cold Finn from the far north but I like it.
I came to Italy expecting to find good weather, amazing food and wine, and beautiful landscapes filled with endless stories in history. I know that these are probably the most stereotypical things anyone would list about Italy. My apologies, it‚Äôs my lack of imagination. But that‚Äôs what I was looking for, and I‚Äôm happy to say that for the most part my expectations were met.
The weather has been very good. During the winter the coldest period lasted about three weeks. In Finland we would describe the winter in Lazio as ‚Äúlong October‚Äù. We barely had to turn on the heating in our apartment. Despite some anomalies in April and May, the sun has been shining and the temperatures have been steadily rising. In fact, at the time of writing there is a heat wave in Italy with temperatures climbing above 40 degrees. Frascati typically has a few degrees less than Rome, and the town is located on a hill so there is a bit more ventilation here. And luckily, our apartment is equipped with air-conditioning. Otherwise, this poor northern boy would be already cooked.
The food and the wine‚Ä¶ Well, let‚Äôs say the Italians know what they are doing. The food is amazing and the wine is delicious and in abundance. Eating out in a restaurant is affordable. During the week I try to limit myself from eating out, but on a weekend I allow myself to relax and eat all the carbonara available. They recently opened a summer street market next to our apartment, and they have a stand selling panini con la porchetta. It‚Äôs cheap, good, and it‚Äôs dangerously close.
I am a bit surprised about the prices in the supermarket though. It‚Äôs quite expensive, and I don‚Äôt notice a big difference compared to the prices in the Netherlands or Finland for example. But the quality of the products is really high.
I‚Äôm very satisfied with the amount of nature, the beautiful landscapes, and the hiking possibilities available in Lazio. I love the fact that I can easily go hiking on a lake or on top of a mountain, and just casually pass an ancient Roman amphitheatre or an aqueduct. Il Parco Regionale dei Castelli Romani next to Frascati has enough trails to keep you busy for a long time. I‚Äôve been also joining some guided hikes, and I‚Äôve found that it‚Äôs a good way to explore new places and to meet new people in my new home country.
Life is a balance of pros and cons, and life in Italy is no exception. I can make exaggerated jokes about the problems I‚Äôve had, but in all honesty I haven‚Äôt had any major issues.
When moving here I was expecting the bureaucracy to cause me terrible headaches. And yes, there have been some challenges, but mostly things have been resolved and there haven‚Äôt been any blocking obstacles. You need a bit of perseverance, a healthy level of pessimism, luck, and good connections. I guess having an Italian partner is also a gateway to success (in life in general). My tessera sanitaria is still lost in a limbo but at least I have a carta di identit√†. And I haven‚Äôt filed my taxes yet for last year. I expect this to be another fun adventure.
If you‚Äôve read my previous posts, you already know that I was a bit shocked about the traffic in Rome. Now I‚Äôm already somewhat used to it, but I still try to avoid driving a car in the city center. If you‚Äôre in need of excitement and adrenaline, there are better ways to get them.
But I‚Äôm happy to say that my plan of acquiring a scooter worked wonderfully! Well, not wonderfully. I placed the order in December but finally got the scooter in May after some major delivery issues. However, since then it has been the solution to all of my problems! I‚Äôm fully autonomous. I can get to Rome easily, and without wasting time in looking for a parking spot. Driving a scooter in Rome is more fun and way less stressful than driving a car. Plus passing the beautifully lighted Colosseum in the evening with a scooter is pretty damn nice.
Moving to a new country is not easy. And moving to a new country, which is culturally and climatically very different from what you‚Äôve used to, is even harder. You‚Äôre pulled out of your comfort zone and placed in an environment where everything is new. And it‚Äôs even warm. You need to set up all of your routines from the ground up. It is overwhelming and exhausting.
Personally, I learnt that you need to be patient, give yourself time, and celebrate every small achievement. You start from the basics, small things, and then gradually increase the difficulty level. After each achievement you can reward yourself with a glass of wine. For me this meant going through the following list in increasing level of difficulty:
Working through tasks in this manner creates a positive feedback loop, makes you more comfortable in using the language, and slowly builds up your confidence. You get an idea how things work and you are able to build a routine for yourself.
After 11 months of living here I have my routine pretty much set up. Italy feels like a home.
Really the only bigger struggle I have is finding my group of people to spend time with. It‚Äôs a solvable problem but might take some time. And what is life without a bit of challenge after all. Like my friend in Finland says ‚ÄúEi t√§nne helppoo oo tultu hakeen‚Äù which roughly translates to ‚ÄúWe‚Äòre not here because it‚Äôs easy‚Äù.
I‚Äôve been attending some expat events and I‚Äôve found them a good place to make connections. There is a risk in ending up in an expat bubble, but right now I feel that I‚Äôd like to meet people who are in a similar situation and who can relate to how it is living in a foreign country.
Obviously, I continue learning Italian, but it might take a lifetime until I can speak fluently and express myself in the same manner as I‚Äôm currently able to do in Finnish or in English. But I like the language and I appreciate the challenge.
I‚Äôm actually really happy for the life and the quality of life that I have. I would say that the pros outweigh the cons easily. I guess I might be still in the honeymoon period of living in another country but I might as well enjoy it to the fullest.
--
--
Finnish software developer living in Frascati, Italy. My special skills include converting carbonara and coffee into high-end software solutions.

Title: Nostalgia and Decadence Permeate Through Every Pore of Small-Town Italy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Medium‚Äôs best creative nonfiction‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämemoirs and personal essays. Eclectic, nuanced, entertaining. Follow us, or join our writers‚Äô collective.

Member-only story
--
15
Share
As an Italian immigrant who has lived in an at first family-imposed and now self-imposed exile for over eighty percent of his life, I have gotten used to experiencing Italy as a tourist. On many occasions, I have found myself on holiday enjoying la dolce vita and yearning for more of Italy in my life only to then be reminded that il bel paese is much more bello to visit than to live in.
There are many stark reminders that the Italy we visit ‚Äî even as Italians ‚Äî is not the Italy that Italians reside in. There are the luxury five-star spa retreats on Capri and Ischia and there are the violent neighborhoods a short ferry ride away in Secondigliano. There are the Belmond collection hotels in the middle of the picturesque Colli Sennesi and then there are the small decadent towns where other Tuscans live. To experience this contrast, one just needs to veer slightly off the beaten path.
In April, I accompanied my mother from our family home in San Gimignano to visit a bookstore in Colle Val D‚ÄôElsa. The so-called‚Ä¶

Title: From Venice to Taormina, the G7 in Italy
Content:

Dispatches from the G7 by the Embassy of Italy in the United States. For more, follow us on Twitter at @G7inUS and @ItalyinUS. For the 2017  Italian Presidency of the G7, follow the official channel on Twitter @G7Italy2017.

--

The Sicilian town of Taormina will be the 5th Italian city to host the G7 since it was first formed in 1975 ‚Äî then called G6 as Canada officially joined the following year, in 1976.
The first time the G7 leaders met in Italy was in 1980 for the 6th G7 summit, the first chaired by the Italian government. They met again in Venice in 1987 for the 13th summit.
After two summits in Venice, in 1994 the 20th G7 took place in Naples, in the Campania region of Italy. Genoa, in the Liguria region, followed in 2001 for the 27th meeting of the then-G8. The Genoa summit, in fact, also included Russia, which became an official full member in 1998 ‚Äî Russia‚Äôs membership however was cancelled in 2014 under the Crimea crisis.
In 2009, the Italian government organized the 35th summit of the then-G8 in the city of L‚ÄôAquila. The meeting was originally planned in La Maddalena, Sardinia, but moved to L‚ÄôAquila to show support to the city and the region after the terrible earthquake that hit the area on April 6, 2009.
The G8 in l‚ÄôAquila was the first summit attended by US President Barack Obama who assumed office earlier that year, on January 20, 2009.
As announced earlier this month by Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi, the 43rd summit of the G7, will take place in Taormina, Sicily, on May 26‚Äì27, 2017.

Figuring out the right visa to move to Italy can be overwhelming if you‚Äôre doing it alone, and if you make the wrong call, you could end up losing money and staying stuck in your home country.
That‚Äôs what‚Äôs happening to some people who are being told to apply for the Elective Residency visa. If an immigration attorney is encouraging you to apply for this visa and you‚Äôre not yet retired, read on.
The Elective Residency visa is a long-term visa for people who do not intend to work once they arrive in Italy. Typically these individuals are retired or generate passive income from sources like capital gains, dividends, retirement pensions, royalties, or rental property.
While this is ideal for someone who is retired, there are immigration attorneys who are encouraging people who still work (perhaps freelance) to apply for this visa‚Ä¶and they‚Äôre being denied.
Some of these attorneys ignore clients when they tell them that they will continue to work once they live in Italy. They focus on the bare requirement (‚Ç¨31k a year in passive income sources) and don‚Äôt address what will happen once the individual arrives in Italy and is‚Ä¶

For people living in Italy on a residenza elettiva (elective residence) visa, the cost to opt in to the national health service has more than doubled. A new law was enacted at the end of 2023 that established a minimum cost of ‚Ç¨2,000 and a maximum of ‚Ç¨2,700 for each person. Prior to this, costs varied wildly region to region, but in general it was about ‚Ç¨2,200 for both my wife and I per year based on a formula applied to gross income.
After a lot of back and forth, we got the final calculation confirmed and the combined cost for both my wife and I will now be ‚Ç¨4,000 for a year, which translates to about $180 per month for each of us.
The diagnostic and preventive exams provided by Medicare B in the U.S. appear to be better in most respects compared to what we will get in Italy. I guess the health care here is adequate, but it certainly isn‚Äôt a screaming bargain with top notch service. As an overview of the basic coverage, the Italian national health service pays for hospital stays, ambulance service, and visits to the emergency room. About once a year the doctor prescribes extensive routine blood and urine panels and the lab work is fast. This costs‚Ä¶

Title: Was it selfish to move to Italy? A mother‚Äôs story about moving to another country without any solid reason
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
‚ÄúYes, I think I have found the house!‚Äù I announced enthusiastically to my children and partner. None of us could have predicted how that casual idea of finding a second home would unfold and transform our lives.
At the time, I was at a crossroads. After selling my house, I couldn‚Äôt see a clear way forward in my home country. The housing market had become wildly expensive, and renting was nearly impossible without a steady employment contract. Investing in a property felt practical, so I decided to look for a second home ‚Äî a place to wait out the unpredictable market. My three children were fully aware of my plans and shared in the excitement. After all, the idea of a holiday house in Spain or Italy sounded idyllic to everyone.
The house I found fit comfortably within the ‚Äúsecond home‚Äù budget. It wasn‚Äôt a larger investment that nudged me toward a permanent move ‚Äî it simply felt right. Honestly, I had never considered leaving the Netherlands before. Even moving to Peru, where my partner lives, had never seriously crossed my mind. But something shifted for me during the COVID-19 years; the Netherlands no longer felt the same.
Most people who move abroad have a clear reason: to study, pursue a job, start a dream business like a B&B, or retire in a new place. None of those reasons applied to me. I just felt an inner ‚Äúyes‚Äù ‚Äî a pull to go and experience something new.
Of course, I discussed it with my children, who were 19, 20, and 23 years old at the time. The two youngest had just returned from five-month solo trips to Asia, and my eldest had been living in the UK for five years. Their adventures abroad had made them supportive and enthusiastic about my move. But agreeing with the idea and facing the reality of their mother emigrating are two very different things.
Although my decision was guided by intuition, there was also a practical push. In the Netherlands, it‚Äôs not possible to live without a registered address. Spending between ‚Ç¨1,500 and ‚Ç¨2,500 a month on rent felt unsustainable, and moving in with my mother wasn‚Äôt a viable long-term solution. After six months of using her address as a temporary registration, I needed something permanent. The house in Italy became that solution. Once I made the decision, the next steps fell into place: moving my belongings out of storage, closing my business and tax number, and eventually selling my beloved old Volvo. (One Europe doesn‚Äôt feel very united when you‚Äôre faced with the bureaucracy of importing a car or changing a driver‚Äôs license!)
Even our dog, Sarah, became part of the plans. My ex-husband and I shared her care, as neither of us could manage full-time responsibility. Sarah traveled with me back and forth between countries. Although the 13-hour drive wasn‚Äôt her favorite, she loved her new life in Italy. Tragically, she passed away three months ago and now rests beneath the cherry tree in the garden. I still feel her presence watching over me and the house.
When my partner visited Italy to see the house, he wasn‚Äôt thrilled at first. Trading his favorite city, Amsterdam, for life in the middle of nowhere was not what he had envisioned. However, after a rocky start, he‚Äôs grown to love it. Working on the land, enjoying aperitivi at the local bar, meeting new friends, and exploring new places have gradually won him over.
And my children? It‚Äôs been a significant change for them. Although they were already living independently, my move nudged them further into self-reliance. There‚Äôs no longer a ‚Äúhome‚Äù to return to for a casual evening or a mother nearby when they‚Äôre feeling unwell. Visits are planned now. Yet, they love visiting Italy, and I treasure seeing them every six to eight weeks. They often bring friends, and we make the most of our time together, relaxing and appreciating the simple joys.
The dynamic of family life raises an interesting question: Where should we draw the line between living for others and choosing a path for ourselves? Was it selfish of me to move? Perhaps. But I believe it was a healthy kind of selfishness. In modern society, we often place enormous expectations on each other for care and support, yet these aren‚Äôt always balanced or reciprocated. For years, I shaped my life around my children, blending work and caregiving seamlessly. Now, it feels like the right time to embrace a new phase.
And what about caring for our parents? Do we adjust our lives for them, or do they move in with us? In an ideal world, family-based communities would allow for a natural exchange of care ‚Äî elders helping with the little ones, and younger generations supporting the elderly when the time comes. But in today‚Äôs Western society, that‚Äôs not always our reality. We‚Äôre often left juggling guilt and judgment when making choices for ourselves.
In my book The Ripple Effect: Know How Powerful You Are, I explore how our struggles to grow into emotionally responsible, independent adults can create friction in families. These dynamics are complex and deeply personal. I don‚Äôt claim to have the perfect answer, but I‚Äôve made peace with my decisions. Whether I stayed in the Netherlands or moved to Italy, there would have been positive and negative consequences for everyone involved.
I‚Äôm incredibly proud of how my children have embraced my choices, and I‚Äôm grateful for the new experiences we share here in Italy. Right now, I‚Äôm preparing the house for a lively New Year‚Äôs gathering with my two youngest and their friends. The house will be full, and I couldn‚Äôt be happier.
Follow this blog for weekly updates, surprises, and stories as I navigate the joys and challenges of building a family home and business sanctuary in Italy. There‚Äôs so much more to come!

People usually like Italy for its rich culture, stunning landscapes, and delicious cuisine, but the most precious are the people that live in this beautiful country. They can impart valuable lessons about living a healthier and more fulfilling life. Drawing inspiration from the Italian way of life, I have discovered some powerful lessons that have significantly improved my well-being. These lessons are rooted in my personal journey of moving from Ukraine to Italy and embracing a new lifestyle. Born in Ukraine, I embarked on a life-changing adventure when I moved to Italy at 19 to pursue my studies at the university. It was a whole new world that challenged me. Sometimes I cried thinking of my life at home and my friends. However, this new world was filled with unfamiliar habits and customs that intrigued me.
Over the past 10 years of residing in Italy, I have experienced a remarkable transformation. New habits I‚Äôve learned and integrated into my daily routine improved my physical well-being and brought me a sense of contentment. Writing these words, I think of the transformative power of cultural experiences and the profound impact they can have on our well-being.

Title: Salerno and La Spezia
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
My wife and I traveled around Italy in late April and early May this year.
It was my first time in Italy, and we tried to find a balance between doing too much and too little: We wanted to visit multiple regions and see major highlights of the country, while also not feeling like we were in too much of a rush from place to place. Ultimately, we spent three nights in Rome, two in Naples, two in Salerno, three in Bologna, two in La Spezia, and a final night back in Rome.
I‚Äôm sure many travelers would still find this itinerary too rushed, and would judge that we didn‚Äôt give the cities and regions we visited all the time they deserved. On the other hand, I know plenty of travel itineraries that squeeze more places into a trip than we did, or do just as much as we did in a shorter amount of time. I think we struck a good balance, especially for my first time in the country. Whenever we get the chance to go back to Italy, I expect we will select only one or two regions to explore, and will spend much more time there.
After taking this tour of Italy, there are two places we visited that I‚Äôd really like to highlight ‚Äî Salerno and La Spezia.
Salerno and La Spezia are over 300 miles apart, in very different regions of Italy. Salerno is in Campagnia, in southern Italy, while La Spezia is in Liguria, in northern Italy. Nonetheless, they are incredibly similar cities, and they are similarly overlooked in travel blogs, videos, and guidebooks. Salerno and La Spezia were, in fact, the two places I most enjoyed spending time on our trip. I think they are unjustly overlooked.
Salerno and La Spezia are smaller-sized Italian cities, with populations of 132,000 and 92,000 people, respectively, making them #30 and #53 in this list of Italy‚Äôs largest cities. While Salerno is southern and La Spezia northern, they are both port cities on Italy‚Äôs west coast, Salerno on the Tyrrhenian Sea and La Spezia on the Ligurian Sea. (Both seas are smaller parts of the Mediterranean, of course.)
The cities have some remarkable similarities in their orientation and amenities: Both face largely southward toward the sea. Both have extensive pedestrianized or mostly-pedestrianized streets offering a great variety of shopping and dining that caters to locals and visitors alike. Both even have historic castles overlooking the cities.
But let‚Äôs cut to the chase: The reason that Salerno and La Spezia get overlooked is because travel writers and visitors generally treat these cities only as jumping-off points for more famous coastal areas, not as destinations in their own right. If Salerno gets mentioned at all in travel guides, it is only as a place to get transportation to the Amalfi Coast. When La Spezia gets mentioned, it‚Äôs only because it‚Äôs the primary city used to access the Cinque Terre.
Naturally, these are the original reasons why my wife and I spent two nights in Salerno and two nights in La Spezia in the first place. We knew the Amalfi Coast and Cinque Terre were renowned destinations, but we also wanted to save money and trouble by not staying in one of the towns of the Amalfi Coast or Cinque Terre themselves, so we planned to stay in the nearby hub cities instead.
As it turned out, we loved the hub cities more than the world-famous destination areas.
Now, the purpose of this article is not to disparage the Amalfi Coast or Cinque Terre. We appreciated how beautiful the mountainous coastal landscapes of these areas were, and the picturesque little towns built along them. However, we were also disappointed by how crowded these areas were, which definitely lessened our experience.
I understand that early May is certainly not the ‚Äúlow season‚Äù or even a ‚Äúshoulder season‚Äù for tourism in Italy. The weather is great, and plenty of people clearly had the same idea we did that spring is a perfect time to visit. But, given what these areas were like in early May, I found it difficult to imagine how crowded the boats, buses, and trains traveling to the Amalfi Coast and Cinque Terre would be in June and July ‚Äî not to mention the hotels, restaurants, and streets of the towns themselves.
By contrast, Salerno and La Spezia did not have such problems with crowding. And ‚Äî despite being paid so little attention in guidebooks ‚Äî it wasn‚Äôt for lack of people. There were plenty of tourists passing through Salerno and La Spezia ‚Äî especially La Spezia. Both are cruise ship ports: There was at least one smaller cruise ship in Salerno while we were there, and two larger ships were in port the day we left La Spezia.
The key to the issue isn‚Äôt the number of people, but the capacity communities have to accommodate those people. The famous towns of the Amalfi Coast and Cinque Terre are quite small: The largest towns on the Amalfi Coast, Maiori and Amalfi, have just over 5,000 residents each. The five towns of the Cinque Terre, meanwhile, have populations ranging from around 150 to little over 1,500. Bear in mind that my own town of Ketchikan, Alaska often seems overwhelmed by visitors, but Ketchikan has a summer population of around 15,000‚Äîthree times larger than the largest town on the Amalfi Coast, and ten times larger than the largest of the Cinque Terre.
Towns and villages this small have narrow streets and limited amenities, even when tourism drives demand for such amenities sky-high. The very mountainous landscapes that make these communities so beautiful and famous limit the amount of space available for tourists to fill.
Salerno and La Spezia, meanwhile, have plenty of space. They are, after all, cities that already have populations of around 100,000 people each. A few hundred visitors arriving at once can make a town like Amalfi or Monterosso al Mare feel swamped, but a few thousand visitors coming off a cruise ship can be fully accommodated in Salerno and La Spezia.
Tourism is not the raison d‚Äô√™tre of Salerno or La Spezia. While they both have cruise ship docks, they also both have industrial shipping ports, and La Spezia has a major naval base. The cities exist as sizeable, thriving communities regardless of whether foreign visitors know about them or not. I appreciate that.
That also means that, when you walk the streets of Salerno and La Spezia, or enter a restaurant, grocery store, or shop, there is no immediate assumption that you are a tourist (unless you make it really obvious, I suppose). During most of the time my wife and I spent in these cities, we were mostly among Italians. The major exception was the day we left La Spezia, when two cruise ships had arrived in port and major numbers of Germans, Americans, and others streamed into the pedestrian areas. Even then, however, there were still plenty of locals going to the same restaurants and walking the same streets.
Even at Arechi Castle above Salerno, where all the other visitors at the time I was there were foreign (Dutch and Spanish, as far as I could tell), it seemed the castle was still in large part geared toward welcoming locals and other Italians. Some of the displays in the castle museum were not translated into English, and there were advertisements for events clearly meant for locals.
My point in writing this article is not to say that travelers should skip the Amalfi Coast and Cinque Terre entirely and spend all their time in Salerno and La Spezia instead. The Amalfi Coast and Cinque Terre are unique and beautiful areas, rightly celebrated by many. However, would-be visitors should be well aware that these areas will be crowded any time outside of the off season, and eating, sleeping, and shopping there will be noticeably more expensive than elsewhere.
I think the Amalfi Coast and Cinque Terre still deserve to be visited through day trips from Salerno and La Spezia. However, paying to stay in any of the small towns there for one or more nights may not be worth your money, trouble, or time. Like Venice, the Amalfi Coast and Cinque Terre may soon reach breaking points of overtourism when communities will need to place limits on how visitors travel there, or how many people can visit at a time.
In the meantime, Salerno and La Spezia should continue to have plenty of capacity for visitors for a long time to come. They are robust communities in their own right, largely independent of tourism, with strong transportation connections, and affordable food and lodging. There‚Äôs plenty of interest in both places ‚Äî beaches, forest, art, architecture, and history. And, perhaps most importantly, they are authentic urban communities that give visitors plenty of opportunity to experience how many Italians really live.
Getting to Salerno or La Spezia is quite easy through the Italian train network, and most hotels or apartment rentals will be a short (mostly flat) walk away from the central train stations. Staying in a town on the Amalfi Coast or one of the towns of Cinque Terre, meanwhile, will require more transportation (a taxi, bus, or boat for the Amalfi Coast, or a boat or another train for Cinque Terre), and a lot more lugging around of luggage. Not to mention, those locations will almost certainly cost a great deal more. The apartment we stayed in in La Spezia was the largest we stayed in during our entire trip (a two-bedroom), and one of the most affordable. Our apartment in Salerno was the second most spacious, and similarly affordable.
The biggest difference between Salerno and La Spezia I can think of is their history. While both areas have been inhabited since ancient times, Salerno has been a major community for a much longer period, as the Normans who ruled southern Italy in the middle ages made it their capital. It‚Äôs incredible to think that back in 1050 A.D., Salerno was the second-largest community in Italy, more populated than Rome and only smaller than Venice. La Spezia, meanwhile, did not come to prominence as a community until the age of Italian unification in the nineteenth century, because of the naval base built there. Nonetheless, both Salerno and La Spezia have plenty of culture and charm, even if Salerno was more significant in centuries past.
If I had to pick a single favorite moment from my entire trip to Italy, it might well be exploring Castle Arechi and the surrounding forest. I met some sheep, goats, and herding dogs, spent time contemplating the history of Byzantine and Norman rule in the region, and loved looking out at gorgeous views of Salerno ‚Äî a truly authentic Italian city ‚Äî from numerous viewpoints.
The only reason I knew about the castle and the amazing views it offers was because of a vlog on YouTube, not made by a typical travel vlogger, but rather by a South African man living in Italy who was merely taking a day trip to the city. If I‚Äôd only paid attention to standard travel websites, I wouldn‚Äôt have realized I should go to Castle Arechi, or known much about Salerno at all.
The next time my wife and I get the chance to visit Italy, we likely won‚Äôt range across the country from south to north, but will choose one or two regions to spend more time in. We might want to revisit Salerno or La Spezia, but we likely won‚Äôt see both in the same trip.
If you‚Äôre planning your own trip to Italy, I‚Äôd encourage you to look for places a little off the beaten path. Or, find places that are on the beaten path, but don‚Äôt receive the attention and credit they deserve as communities worth visiting in their own right. That‚Äôs what I think Salerno and La Spezia are ‚Äî beautiful and authentic Italian cities overlooked because of the more famous tourist destinations nearby.
Instead of just passing through, consider staying there a while!
Do you prefer to spend time in smaller towns geared toward tourists, or larger communities filled with locals? Leave a comment below with your own thoughts and travel experiences.

Nice is a great place to live, as you can reach so many European and Mediterranean destinations by low-cost plane, train, or car, in just a few hours. Italy is right next door, but the northern part is difficult to reach by train, so we rented a car to meet up with family and friends. It took 4 1/2 hours travel on the fantastic Italian autostrade (highways) to reach the northern tip of beautiful Lago d‚ÄôOrta.
Lago d‚ÄôOrta is sometimes called the Cinderella of the Italian lakes. It is much smaller that Lake Maggiore and Lake Como (that I have not visited yet), but it is charming and beautiful, even in the rain (we came last year in chilly wet weather) ‚Äì however, not to be missed in the sunshine.
Tip nr.1: the fastest way to get a meal on the road is by stopping at an Autogrill (highway rest stops). The food is not very good, and not cheap at all. On the other hand, shopping for Italian specialties can be nice.
We rented an Airbnb in the suburbs of Omegna. This was my first Italian Airbnb. It was a bit old-fashioned and the kitchen‚Äôs only condiments were salt and pepper. There was no oil, which was unpractical, as I‚Äôd come to expect it in any Airbnb. There was also no kitchen mitt; we promptly burned a towel, which I replaced. I tried to buy a mitt, but searched in several stores, and a market, unsuccessfully !
Our first day was sunny, and I asked the group if we could go to Orta San Giulio, that I had toured in the rain last year. It was a magical day. We parked in a public lot (you pay via a machine and it‚Äôs not very expensive) and set off to see the town. First stop (after a short visit to a tiny church): Arte del Gelato on Via Olina.
The gelato is absolutely wonderful. I had Fondente (dark chocolate sorbet) and mirtilia (blackberry ‚Äî I think). Others had Panna Cotta (delicious), lemon sorbet‚Ä¶ my friend swears by mango and pistachio. Tip 2: 6 cones/cups cost ‚Ç¨15. (June 2023)
It was Wednesday, market day. Stalls sold clothing, produce, jewelry. Just beware of the olives/antipasti stall: it was ridiculously expensive and not all that delicious.
We hopped into a ferry (‚Ç¨5 a person) to visit the small island in the middle of the lake. We walked all around it, through narrow winding streets and steps, with glimpses of the water. The Basilica of San Giulio was beautiful: an 11th-12th century church built on a crypt dating back to the 5th century, with the tomb of a saint. As a lapsed Catholic (technically Maronite), I still like to light candles in churches (the real kind, not the fake battery-operated ones), and here they only cost ‚Ç¨0.30, but I had already used up my change in the aforementioned tiny church, where they were ‚Ç¨0.50. Compare that to ‚Ç¨2‚Äì3 in German and Swiss churches!
Much as Orta San Giulio was wonderful, the town where our Airbnb was, Omegna, begged to be discovered, too.I walked to Omegna a bit before noon, downhill all the way, on roads with very little in the way of sidewalks, and cars zooming down ‚Äì after all, this is Italy.
The view of the mountains was magnificent. When I reached town, a street market was in action. It went on for so long that I turned back at one point. Housewares (kitchen tools, towels, etc.), clothing for adults and children, and much more was on display. I headed into the city proper, through narrow streets, and finally came out at the canal. At least that‚Äôs what it appears to be: I found no river on the map.There is a very tiny beach at Canottiere, a restaurant, cafe and boat rental outfit. Teens were splashing around (including those in my group).I walked further into town, on the hunt for kitchen mitts (surprisingly hard to find in supermarkets!), and realized that there was a pedestrian walk along the canal.
After leaving Omegna, we drove to visit our friends in Baragiotta. It‚Äôs a tiny village with over 100 year old buildings, some of which are crumbling. Our friends renovated theirs to create a modern upper floor loft, with a medical practice on the ground floor. Most of the rest is still under construction. In the basement, we saw very old dusty bottles.(wine?) There is also an old-fashioned, perhaps 1950s kitchen.
Last year we had the pleasure of tasting the very excellent Erbaluce wine at Costa di Sera, and we wanted to buy a box to give some to our Nice friends. Once again, we were invited to a meal of cheeses, salamis, vegetables, bread, and breadsticks, in the Rock-music themed room of our Heavy Metal fan winemaker, Alfonso Rinaldi. Thisntime, my ear had become a little more attuned to Italian, and I think I understood about 30% of what he said (and he had a lot to say, including, incredibly, that one of the world‚Äôs best songs was ¬´ Blue Spanish Eyes ¬ª!
Our stomachs full, and our crate of wine safe in the car, we went on to visit the Agroturisma Fano‚Äôs Farm Bed and Breakfast. If you can snag a room or an apartment, it‚Äôs a one stop vacation, especially if you have children. Horses, ponies, chickens, a swimming pool and a vegetable garden await!
My friend (whom I know since high school in Germany ‚Äì a very long time ago) reminded me that I expressed a desire for one more thing. After several guesses, I remembered: gelato from Cafe Agarla in Romagnano. The owner gets the freshest ingredients, and if the ingredients aren‚Äôt available that day at the market, that flavor will be unavailable. I had grapefruit/ginger and pistachio. The grapefruit was excellent, the pistachio IMHO a bit boring. Fondente wasn‚Äôt available! (Ice cream for 4 people cost ‚Ç¨8.)
It was sadly time to leave the next day (Sunday). We tried to stop for coffee at one of the seaside towns near Genoa, but everyone was out (a sunny Sunday in June, after all) and there was nowhere to park. We had our capuccino at yet another highway Autogrill, with the delicious homemade grilled zucchini-mozzarella sandwiches our friend packed for us. It was still Italian capuccino in Italy ‚Äì a notch above capuccino anywhere else! (The Autogrill lady probably thought I was crazy for grinning ‚Äì but she smiled back nevertheless.)

Born in the USA, raised in Europe and the Middle East, lived in Sub-Saharan Africa. In travelogues, I share travel tips + costs. Co-author The African Dwelling.

After a week exploring the Alsace in France, I drove south through Switzerland to my new home base in the Aosta Valley of Italy. Today‚Äôs drive took me across borders, through tunnels and into spectacular Alpine scenery.
Switzerland maintains its historic neutrality and is not part of the European Union. As I left France, I had to stop at the border crossing in Basel and purchase a vignette (~$40) to place on the inside my windshield. It was basically a toll for the privilege of driving on Swiss roads.
The stoic Swiss border agent took my credit card and inserted it into his portable device but it was not connecting. I mentioned (in German) something about this being a Monday and he chuckled. I considered that a major achievement.
After securing my payment and applying my vignette, I was free to hit the Swiss highways. I drove from Basel, through Bern, down to Lake Geneva. I stopped in the lakeside town of Montreux and explored its famous castle, the Ch√¢teau de Chillon. What an incredible sight.
The views of the castle along the shimmering lake with the snow-capped Alps towering in the distance were jaw-dropping. The views were still incredible from inside the castle as I peaked out the windows.
I also admired the modern Swiss engineering involved in the highway that curved gracefully above the lake.
As I continued my journey south, the road continued to climb. It also narrowed and devolved into a series of hairpin turns. The temperature steadily dropped and soon I was passing above the tree line through snow.
I crossed over the border from Switzerland to Italy somewhere deep below a mountain inside the Great St Bernard Tunnel. When I finally emerged back into daylight, the signs had switched from French to Italian.
It didn‚Äôt take long for the road to begin its steep descent into the Aosta Valley. The Romans conquered this region around 25 BC, building roads and bridges. Valle d‚ÄôAosta literally means ‚ÄúValley of Augustus‚Äù.
I have a grand view of this ancient valley from the balcony of my Airbnb.
My proprietor, Anne-Marie, is actually Belgian and she spoke excellent English. Her property is set up perfect for me, she even included a bottle of local wine and a wedge of Aosta (pronounced ‚Äúow-oh-stuh‚Äù) cheese.
After unpacking, I stretched my legs by hiking around the neighborhood. Most of the houses clung to the side of the mountain and all enjoyed this incredible view. Even through we‚Äôre at a higher elevation, it‚Äôs warmer here than France due to the special micro-climate protected by mountains on both sides.
As I was out hiking, a farmer rumbled by on his tractor and gave me a friendly Ciao. I‚Äôm generalizing here but the Italians always seem more approachable to me, especially after I‚Äôve spent time with the typically reserved French and Germans. I need to brush up on my Italian phrases.
After the long drive through the mountains, I‚Äôm ready to call it a day.
It should be interesting to explore this area considering it offers Roman ruins and plenty of castles plus Mont Blanc and the Matterhorn are nearby.

If you tread slowly over cobblestoned streets and walkways in Matera, Italy you can feel the very bones of its past. Take your time. Observe and appreciate that you are standing in one of the oldest functioning human habitations in the world.
It is a place of history, beauty, and people. It is the city of the Sassi, one of Italy‚Äôs heritage sites built of stone with evidence from the Paleolithic era to more recent finds.
It is rumoured that Jesus of Nazareth visited Matera although no one knows exactly where. Its pre-Roman expansion from hunter-gatherer to pastoral farming suggests a peaceful abundant existence.
Perhaps Jesus found it suited him for a time during his travels, like a much-needed time-out from constant Roman oppression. Who didn‚Äôt need that?
Most residents love to talk about Matera and its history. Once called the shame of Italy much of its oldest dwellings cut into the stone hillsides have been restored and now house restaurants and hotels.
